name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item of order of the day is the Commission's statement on the decision of the United States to impose duties on steel and aluminum (2018/2629 (RSP)).

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, we have taken note of the decision of the US President last week to impose tariffs on imports of steel and aluminium to the United States. We have also taken note of the possibility for allies to be excluded from the scope of such measures. We expect that the EU as a whole will be excluded, as a key political, security and economic partner that trades fairly with the United States. The EU and the US are strong historic allies. We share and promote fundamental values such as democracy, the rule of law and human rights. We also believe in, and stand for, an undistorted market economy, as well as open, rule-based and fair trade. In past years, both the US and the EU have faced increased imports and dumping of steel and aluminium – mostly from Asia. To a large extent, this has been the consequence of global overcapacity, in particular in China, fuelled by massive domestic subsidies. As a response, both the EU and the United States have taken action against this in the form of anti-dumping measures on Chinese steel and aluminium imports, which are allowed by the WTO. Thanks to this, our industry has been able to survive for the time being. The problem is not over yet, and this is why we have created a Global Forum on Steel Excess Capacity in which the EU and US work together with China and others to address the root causes of the problem. This group aims at identifying and eliminating overcapacity and the support measures that fuel it. Such work should be expedited. We should also better enforce WTO rules and, ideally, update rules on subsidies which are incomplete and do not cover all situations well. This would provide stronger discipline on massive subsidies that can create distortions and hurt EU and US companies. The EU has already started to work with the US on this agenda. This is why we have created a trilateral cooperation on a level playing field with Japan as well. The first meeting took place this weekend in Brussels, on which Commissioner Malmström will debrief you. Work will accelerate and intensify in the near future. We hope that China will understand the value of a strong rules-based order and join our effort, even if it means going further in the reform of their economic model, where the state still has a strong role. In the meantime, we sincerely hope that the process of exclusion of EU steel and aluminium exports from the scope of US measures will be expedited, transparent and smooth. We believe that our exports do not cause any threat to US security. Commissioner Malmström had a bilateral exchange with US Trade Representative Lighthizer on this matter in the margins of the trilateral meeting this weekend and can tell you more about this.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, as you know, President Trump signed off on import duties of 25% on steel and 10% on aluminium last week, under Section 232 of the 1962 Trade Expansion Act. This is a US law from the Cold War and it was justified on national security grounds. These measures will enter into force on the night between 22 and 23 March 2018.  We regret the adoption of these measures justifying tariffs on the basis of national security considerations. They risk undermining the multilateral trading system and, moreover, the European Union – which is made up of friends and allies in NATO – is not a threat to the national security of the US. During my meeting with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer this Saturday, I made it clear to him that we are very disappointed indeed that long-standing allies and security partners from Europe need to justify their exports of steel and aluminium and prove that they are not a threat to US security. We are of the firm view that the EU should be excluded as a whole from the Section 232 measures announced next week, and I made this very clear to Ambassador Lighthizer.  Unfortunately, I did not leave Saturday’s meeting with sufficient clarity regarding the exclusions. We are in contact with my US counterpart to obtain more clarity as soon as possible and we have been told that the US Trade Representative will publish a more detailed outline of the procedures for the exclusions very soon on their website.  This would be very damaging to transatlantic relations and to the global rules system, which is based on a common global order that we have constructed together with our US partners. If the EU is not exempted from the measures, there will have to be a firm and resolute, but proportionate, response. We are continuing the preparations to ensure that we can respond, in line with WTO rules, in the event that we are not excluded from the scope of the Section 232 measures. Last week, the College of Commissioners discussed three strands of work for future measures that would defend our interests and those of the trading system. They will be fully in line with international obligations and in accordance with WTO procedures.  The first strand is that we would exercise our rights in the WTO. We are talking to friends and partners across the world who are also affected by the Section 232 decisions and who would be impacted by this measure. We are seeing if we can coordinate our rights in the WTO. But WTO proceedings take time, so we are also looking at other, more immediate, measures. The second track would be to protect our market from potentially significant trade diversion.  By the US’s own assessment, steel imports should be reduced by 13 million tonnes, and there could be a surge of steel or aluminium imports into the EU following US tariffs. We are therefore preparing to put in our own safeguard measures while maximising our openness. We urge our trading partners to do likewise. We do not want to encourage further closing of the steel and aluminium markets.  We suspect that the US’s steps are not actually based on security considerations, but that they are economic safeguard measures in disguise. We are therefore entitled to use the WTO safeguard agreement to rebalance the benefits we have granted to the US in the past. These allow for measures corresponding to the economic loss suffered, and we are discussing different US products.  So these are the three tracks we are discussing. We are ready to act in a proportionate way according to WTO rules. We do not want things to escalate. We do not share the view that trade wars are good and that they are easy to win. On the contrary, they are very bad for the world and they are very easy to lose. So things should not be escalated; we will manoeuvre carefully, but of course we need to protect the interests of the citizens and our jobs.  Dialogue with the US is intense. It is continuing this week, and we hope that very soon we can report to you in more detail on the outcome of this. Thank you very much, and I am looking forward to the debate. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The Group of the European People's Party has requested today's debate and has been gratefully supported by the other colleagues. Today's signal we need is that the European Parliament is fully behind the European Commission. We are united as Europeans and we want to respond together to the challenge of tariffs on steel and aluminium. My group, the European People's Party, stands for free world trade. We have documented and demonstrated this in recent votes, for example on CETA, and we know that in recent decades, trade has led to the world as a whole becoming richer. South Korea, Turkey, many countries in Africa, including China, have benefited massively from world trade, making the world more prosperous overall. And Europe's prosperity is also deliberately based on trade. We are competitive, we have good products, we are creative, and the world envies us for these products. The third positive argument in favour of world trade is the impact on the consumer: the choice is increasing, the products will be cheaper — all will benefit. So, yes to world trade. The second thing that is important to us is the question: what is happening in the US and how do we assess the measures? From the point of view of the Group of the European People's Party, there is no justification for the current measures against the European Union. What security interests should be affected? There is no dumping in the European Union. The measures are unjustified and it affects jobs. The EPP will not tolerate this. A third point is important to us that we are now discussing adequate measures, as Cecilia Malmström presented them. We in the Group of the European People's Party believe that the measures that are being discussed in the Commission are adequate measures are. We must not overreact, but we must respond decisively. We therefore believe that this is going in the right direction. We need unity and determination now. And for the fourth, we need to talk. We have to argue and convince each other, for example, that in the US 33 000 jobs are linked to the production of steel, but more than 180 000 jobs are attached to the processing of steel. That means Donald Trump is also damaging his jobs. And we need to finally talk about the real problem, which is China. We need a cap for the European market, direct measures so that there is no overcapacity and even more dumping on the European market. And we need to be able to talk to the US together about China and its overproduction. If we offset the iPhones with the BMW, then there will be a laughing third party, and that's China. This can't happen to us. That is why I would like to thank Paul Ryan and many friends in the United States who, thank God, initiated the discussion. Finally, we should also recognise the opportunities from these debates with the United States. The world is confused about what is happening in Washington. This is true for Mexico, Canada, Japan, Mercosur — they are confused. That is why the European Union can be the region that now offers the partnership with the rest of the world. We feel in the talks that there is a new openness. If Donald Trump wants to build walls, then we Europeans will have to build bridges all the stronger.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. It is clear that Mr Trump has imposed these foreclosure tariffs for purely domestic reasons. The election in Pennsylvania, the mid-term review elections in November, are the reasons. Even under American law, it is highly controversial whether these measures are covered by this 1962 Cold War law with national security. There will be some processes. But it cannot be that international law is ultimately being undermined on the basis of domestic policy considerations. And that's what it's about. He has taken measures against the rest of the world, 25% on steel and 10% on aluminium against all importers. That is why the crucial momentum for us Social Democrats is to get back on the road to justice. This means that we are sending out a clear signal, and here we support the Commission's action, but we also support strong joint action with the partners that are also affected, such as Japan, Brazil, Mexico and other countries. We must say together to Mr Trump: we stand by the law and not on the validity of the law of the strongest. In this respect, it is important to act together here and also to discuss with the critical forces in the United States that this domestically motivated action is being stopped by the US Congress.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Malmström, thank you for your statement this morning. The United Kingdom and the European Union are close allies of the United States – the UK both as a Permanent Member of the UN Security Council, and as a nuclear power. The close cooperation between the UK, the EU and the US through NATO and other international forums is the cornerstone of international peace and security. So it is with great regret that we now see the impact that the US decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminium will have on us here in the EU.  The ECR therefore welcomes the UK and the EU’s clarity that tariffs are not the right way to address the global problem of steel overcapacity. Instead, a multilateral solution is needed. Nonetheless, it is right that the UK and the EU seek to defend our domestic industries from US tariffs, but any countermeasures by the EU must be in accordance with international trade law and should not exacerbate an already tense situation. We should lead by example, to demonstrate that we believe in free trade and the rules-based multilateral trade system. I would like to reiterate the UK’s commitment to working closely with the EU and its partners to consider the scope for exemptions as outlined by the US. However, I would like clarification on three points. Firstly, Canada, Mexico and Australia have been excluded from these measures, with the US citing their close security alliances for this decision. Does the Commission believes that the US is seeking for the EU to negotiate a security agreement to address those concerns? Secondly, is the Commission re-evaluating its measures to tackle the overcapacity of steel? Thirdly, which EU markets will be most affected by diverted trade to Europe because of these tariffs?

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, trade rules and negotiations are complex. We saw this during years of negotiating the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), negotiations that are stalled after a dramatic change in the American approach. Normally trade arrangements are certainly not the kind of topic to be shaped in a number of angry tweets one morning – tweets that sent stock markets plummeting and Gary Cohn resigning. We condemn the harsh accusations in the EU’s direction and frankly are puzzled by what we see. Adding insult to injury, the President’s tweets now also speculate about imposing tariffs on European cars and other accusations. For a country that exports so many German cars, this is at least a bad business proposition. Many jobs are created in the US by European companies and vice versa. We don’t live in a zero-sum world but we are actually mutually dependent. Senior officials have suggested national security is the reason to impose broad steel and aluminium tariffs also in Europe, and as allies we believe these arguments are misguided and not justified. The same goes for the notion that individual Member States may negotiate exemptions. American hints at undermining the EU as well as British hints at being open to special treatment can only be read as being made in bad faith and must be challenged, where the British governments will find out soon, if necessary, what the benefits of a common approach globally in the EU are (or were, in their case). For decades the US and the EU have worked together to craft a rules-based system: rules for human rights, war and peace, and also trade. Does that mean that the system or the World Trade Organisation (WTO) is perfect? Not at all. But does history suggest that our citizens benefit from shaping globalisation, from being rule makers instead of rule takers? Absolutely. That is precisely what makes the soundbites of the current US administration so disturbing. Right at the time we need to work together as the liberal democracies of this world to curb unfair trade practices of China and others, we are divided. As Vice-President of the Transatlantic Legislators Dialogue, I look to members of Congress in particular for their leadership and solid affirmation of the Transatlantic Relation. We do not need a trade war and will do what we can to stop it. The Commission has my Group’s full support as well. But we are ready to adapt proportionate and WTO-compliance countermeasures when it’s necessary.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Vice-President, after the Paris Agreement, after the Iranian nuclear agreement, President Trump wants to exonerate himself from common rules, wants to exempt himself from multilateralism and this is a danger for all of us. It is a danger for all of us that forces us to have a firm reaction, obviously through the World Trade Organisation and multilateral rules, but if that is not enough, particularly as regards deadlines, the European reaction will have to be commensurate with the damage suffered. No commercial escalation, but no more and no less than the harm suffered. We have to be firm from that point of view. While Trump's decision is unacceptable, it also refers the European Union to its own shortcomings. We have a common commercial policy, which you carry, but we do not have a common commercial diplomacy. We do not have a common commercial diplomacy, we have seen it. With each case of significant dumping from China or other countries, European states are divided. Everyone reacts, everyone tries to save their economic sector, here the machine tools, there wine, or there the Chinese investments in the port of Piraeus. If we do not have a common commercial diplomacy, it is because there is a major flaw in this Europe. We do not have a common industrial policy. As long as we have 28 national sovereignty in industrial matters, we will be divided and we will not weigh. We have tried, including in this Parliament, with the Martin report, to say what we had to do on the steel industry to modernise it, to innovate, to make carbon efficiency and energy efficiency, including perhaps with a carbon tax at the borders, but if we do not do that, then we will always be in difficulty vis-à-vis the United States, China and all others. The the American decision is an opportunity for Europe to finally have a common industrial policy and commercial diplomacy.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Vice-President. Yes, Mr Katainen, you are quite right that this current debate on the trade conflict is about much more than just US plans to increase tariffs on steel and aluminium. We live in a global economy, and we have to face it, both in terms of production, sales, trade — a fair world trade — as well as in terms of social and related environmental conditions and impacts. If the hour requires us to act with a degree of prominence, then it cannot be about an eye for an eye or everyone against everyone, but it must really be about wrestling with the US, China and other producers in the global, international forums that we have at the WTO, in the Steel Forum that they call. how this global economy needs to be organized. That's why I agree with you. Let us call the WTO arbitration tribunal to investigate what the US President will decide at the end of yesterday's elections and the vote in Pittsburgh! Let us prepare for the rapid operational viability of our WTO-compatible protection measures in the volume range of EUR 2.8 billion if a foreclosure of the US market by Trump in the meantime leads to the diversion of surpluses to the steel market into Europe! Above all, we are looking for common solutions there! It must be solutions for people who are actually experiencing disadvantages from the development of world trade. There is poverty, there is social decline, there is environmental degradation on all continents. We will not allow Trump to use these grievances in his own country to use selfishness on his agenda. I believe that we must implement this solution together, and you also have the support of the GUE/NGL.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I have tried to tolerate an extension of the time of speech by 15—20 seconds on behalf of political groups, because I think it is a specific, particularly genre-important occurrence. By contrast, exceeding time by 30 seconds is too long, Mr. Scholz, and for the future, avoid it. There was also a proposal for a blue card question, but I would like to ask Mr Rubig, who asked for it, and other colleagues, to use this procedure very carefully in the Member debate, because it is rather a presentation of the positions of political groups . So I very much ask the Honourable Mr Rubig to forgive and possibly refrain from the blue card in this part of the debate between MPs. At the same time, I would also like to ask you to take into account the fact that we need to conclude the debate by 10.00. Then there will be a long debate involving Portugal's prime minister. So I wish we could fit within the time limit. Thank you for your understanding.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, first of all some basic facts. China has been dumping steel. The European Steel Association (EUROFER) set this out in a statement in October 2015. Secondly, in the United States there are whole communities – indeed large towns – whose industry has been hollowed out, indeed devastated, by competition, competition that has likely been unfair. Thirdly, when running for election, the President of the United States made promises. These promises included tariffs.  Now we, as a party, favour free trade. Indeed, one compelling reason for Brexit is that the European Union is itself protectionist, despite what Mr Weber said. Before anybody blue cards me, that is what the customs union is – there is an external tariff wall. To give just one example, the EU imposes duties on agricultural goods that can be up to 67%. We would of course prefer it if the President of the United States did not introduce new tariffs. Nevertheless, it is important to understand the reasons.  If I may make a suggestion to the EU national governments, the United States would be much more likely to take note of what continental European governments want on tariffs if those same European governments were to spend the two percent of gross domestic product on security that is their obligation. That would be better for a peaceful world than the large EU tariff walls.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, yes! You're going to have to do it, President Trump keeps the promises of candidate Trump. While the trade balance experienced a record deficit of $566 billion last year, the United States is responding with strong measures to protect its economy, especially its steel and aluminum industry. Donald Trump announced this counter-offensive in Da Nang, Vietnam, in a speech I mentioned here last November. Today, the European Commission is responding to the US President with senseless threats. And now the high priests of free trade give us their usual sermons, like Mr Moscovici, who declares “protectionism is nationalism and nationalism, it is war”. But that Mr Moscovici, who was one of the most calamitous French ministers of the economy, spare us his hollow and upset formulas. For decades we have been rebeaten with the catechism of the total opening of borders, but these utopias are now crashing on the wall of reality because our continent continues to deindustrialize and hundreds of thousands of jobs have been sacrificed. In France, to speak only of the steel industry, it was the factories in Florange and Gandrange that have been liquidated and our steel production continues to plunge, since it has been halved in ten years. All the world's major powers protect their economy. An American car imported into China is taxed at 25% while a Chinese car in the United States is currently taxed at only 2.5%, that is, ten times less. As a result of Trump's decree, there was much talk about the departure of his advisor, Gary Cohn, but much less of the support given to him by Elon Musk, if any, avant-garde entrepreneur. On the day Trump announced these measures, the European Commission launched a new plan of action against global warming. But the Commission's environmental claims are now in total contradiction with its forced free trade. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions requires relocating economies and bringing production centres closer to places of consumption. That is why the measures of this President, certainly a billionaire, but who defends the middle and popular classes of his country, are legitimate. They must invite us to rethink our economic model. We must end this system of widespread impoverishment in which it is the poor of the rich countries who enrich the rich in poor countries. The future is protections and regulations, it is the necessary condition for any balanced commercial relationship.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, President Trump's decision to impose customs duties on steel and aluminium imports is a preannounced, very correct move for the United States themselves and the citizens. He prioritizes American industries. The Union should also give priority to the citizens of Europe and not promote the migration of Europe's industries. Furthermore, Mr Juncker has not understood that neither are the leaders of the States of the Union, let alone the President of the United States. As for the alleged indignation of the European countries over their non-exemption from the tariff regime, let almost everyone remember their statements against Trump, as well as the fact that, with few exceptions, such as Greece, no EU country meets the requirement of 2% of the defensive spending under NATO. So they have no problem allowing the United States to bear the financial burden of its security, but at the same time they ask, within the Alliance, that the United States should not take measures to stimulate and protect its economy so that the major European multinationals continue to speculating. You have to make a decision that the policy of globalisation, which you have served with vigour, for the interests of multinationals, is beginning to collapse.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, I would like to commend the Commission for being prudent and prudent over the past few days, rather than succumbing to the temptation to join the saber rattling of the American President. At the same time, we can't just anxiously put our hands in the lap and hope that if we do not react at all, the storm will just pass us by. We are living in a different situation than in 2002, where we did not respond to the actions of the then Bush Presidency and simply dismissed them. That is why it is now right that the EU is currently discussing countermeasures which not only want to be moderated and thoughtful, but also, of course, must also be WTO compliant. In this situation, the WTO Statutes give us sufficient leeway to respond appropriately. Donald Trump's protectionist strategy will not work out in the medium term in times of globally networked value chains, and this is a message to all colleagues here too: protective tariffs and protectionism are to the detriment of their own workers. So here we stay global and open-minded. The problem is not particularly close to the US and the EU anyway, which is in very different parts of the world. (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen and commissioners, the message must be very clear today: trade wars are not the answer to the growing and legitimate demand for protection of workers. Trade wars harm the very citizens who are promised protection. In the face of a slight increase in employment in steel mills, the measures can create a net loss, at least, of 140 000 jobs in the United States, and the consequences will be the first of all workers of the companies that produce derivatives of steel and aluminum. As a reaction to the duties will follow the raising of duties on American exports, and even then the American workers and consumers with less labor and higher costs will pay for the costs. We Europeans must not get dragged into this escalation. We have to fight not to get to a world of walls. At the same time our answer will have to be firm: it must be clear that everyone, President Trump included, is called upon to comply with the rules and to eliminate all distortive behavior for one proper competition. Well, the Commission has done to keep this firm balance. It will be vital that all member countries move together and compact. It is an opportunity to show that the EU is strong and can be the most responsible in promoting a fair and sustainable global order. Today, more than ever, it is necessary to work at the World Trade Organisation to give trade values of reciprocity and justice. Global problems need global solutions.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President! Trump wants to make his country big, but he's making it small. Those who protect industries that are shrinking because of the fact that competition is so strong worldwide does not make their country strong, but rather uncompetitive. Mr Lange pointed out which jobs would depend if we make steel so more expensive and which jobs would be lost. Trump is hurting his country. And if we take retorsion measures, no matter how proportioned they are, I don't think we can achieve anything with them. Mr Trump reacts like a defiant child and says, yeah, then I'll just do more. We should adopt a different strategy, namely the strategy of lowering tariffs. Why are American cars charged 10% duty, but only 2.5% in the US? Why don't we lower the 10%. Who is scared of American cars with us? That's a sign, let's do what's on TTIP and do it one-sided. Because if it is right for cheap imports to increase competitiveness, then we can only benefit from it. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Ask about the procedure of the “blue card”. — Dear Mr. Starbatty! I have listened with great interest to your proposal for a unilateral tariff reduction. Do you agree that, precisely in the context of the TTIP negotiations with the United States, we wanted to reduce tariffs not only on cars, but almost all tariffs between the European Union and the United States, and these negotiations are failing, above all, above all because of the US President's lack of willingness to negotiate? Secondly, agree with me that we cannot unilaterally reduce tariffs on cars from America, but that we always have to reduce tariffs for everyone, and that, of course, the competitive situation in countries with low social and environmental standards, such as in China or as in India, is very difficult for us, and that we are therefore very difficult. of course, would confuse everything if we unilaterally lowered tariffs on cars?

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Answer to a question about the procedure of the “blue card”. — Dear Mr. Caspary! I agree with you two thirds, but I cannot understand your final conclusions. If tariff reductions are really favourable to a country's competitiveness, then we should do it — no matter what Mr Trump thinks about them. I think it's right to set a signal: we do not want to increase tariffs, but we are setting down tariffs. This is a sign that Mr. Trump understands. When we say: we want to magnify our Europe not through protectionism, but through free trade — that is the language that Mr Trump may understand.

name: Nadja HIRSCH
text: – Mr President, the transatlantic relationship is much more than steel, peanut butter and orange juice. It is a profound strategic, political and economic bond, built by brave leaders and visionaries. Currently, President Trump is behaving neither like a leader, nor a visionary. The truth is that he won’t bring back jobs to the US steel and aluminium sector in any significant numbers. His confrontational actions, if not stopped, will only cost more jobs on both sides of the Atlantic.  Let’s be honest, it is not the European Union that is treating the US badly as in the case of most unfair trading practices China is to blame. If the EU were resorting to unfair practices then President Trump could have worked it out with the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, but he was the one who stopped the negotiations. He is responsible for our still having different tariffs on cars and he is responsible for our seeing almost no progress in recent years.  Dear President Trump, if you are ready to become a world leader in tackling unfair trade methods, you will have to look for allies, and you might find them here. I am a Member of the European Parliament, working every day for prosperous trade relations between our two continents – and by the way you, Mr Trump, can’t fire me for doing that.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President! We are all outraged by President Trump. How many times, actually? Some particularly outraged voices have even claimed that Donald Trump is about to make the US a rogue state. It can't be what is. But it is. I say, let's not hide in helpless anger. What we're experiencing right now is just the start. Donald Trump actually believes that the World Trade Order is a zero-sum game. He wants a world trade order that breaks with the previous one. He wants a world trade order in which the US can determine and then adapt the rules according to its interests. The ruthlessness with which he is currently taking action against Allies is intended to express his determination to this intention. But the addressee is not us, the addressee is China. Trump chooses a Chinese approach. A Chinese proverb says: you kill the chicken to scare the monkey. We're supposed to be the chicken. I believe that we must avoid a trade war while defending European interests. This is undoubtedly a very difficult task. This involves referring to the WTO arbitration tribunal as envisaged by the Commission. This also means that we are signalling that we do not let the US offer us everything, we are not just sticking the other cheek. I wish you, Commissioner, and the Commission as a whole, that the Member States will be united in their actions. Because if the US now succeed in dividing Europe according to different industrial interests, we would all lose. I wish you a happy hand.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: — Mr President, it is clear that Mr Trump's decision constitutes a declaration of war against the steel and aluminum industries of the European Union. It threatens tens of thousands of jobs and the lives of territories, cities, against a backdrop of weakening our industries. This protectionism is combined with lower capital taxes in the United States and competitive fluctuations in the dollar. This will boost the upward interest rates and inflation, which are taxes on the poor as they feed financial markets. These games combining trade war and monetary warfare can become very dangerous for workers on both sides of the Atlantic and for the whole world. The solution is therefore not in the economic war, of which the only infantrymen are the workers, here and in the United States. It is therefore necessary, in the immediate future, to trigger mechanisms for safeguarding our industries and employment, but at the same time a new project for a commercial partnership must be developed with a common European Union trade action, starting from the general human interest, with stable prices for steel and a new world monetary system .

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen and commissioners, precisely because I believe in trade, I believe that customs duties are an important tool when using them against countries that do not comply with the rules. But the problem, here, is that Trump's duties on steel and aluminum will also apply to those countries that the rules have always respected them, such as those in Europe that produce without unfair competition to the Americans. And then these are not duties born to protect the American economy, but they are duties that are needed to achieve something else. Yes, because the Americans have already made us realize that they will take them off if we invest more in Nato and military spending, maybe buying weapons or other F35s, or if we lower our quality laws of food, perhaps authorizing more GMO, glyphosate, hormone meat and whatnot in Europe. International trade, commissioner, should be incentivised when it brings prosperity, and limited when it hurts the economy, but never, ever goes used as an excuse to achieve something else. We must not yield to the United States on the precautionary principle, but we must also avoid at all costs this escalation to a trade war that will only bring harm to our citizens and our manufacturers. Europe must therefore find alternative solutions to make the Americans understand that we are always their allies, but we do not give in to blackmail.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the reactions to Mr Trump's duties are incredible. Hysterical those of the super lobby of Davos, but even more grotesque those of Communist China, which has become the leader of free trade. And then the strong reaction of Germany and Mrs Merkel, when the cause of it all is super exporting Germany, with a surplus of 287 billion in clear contrast to European rules. The lesson we have to draw from it is that free trade is an incapacitating myth, which produces — that yes — wars, and also poverty. Germany made a huge trade surplus, imposing things that made its export hypercompetitive, low wages and low euro exchange against the dollar. So rather than anti-US countermeasures, Germany is rather pledging to reduce its trade surplus. The EU initiates a safeguarding procedure on the import of steel and aluminium as soon as possible to protect EU companies from the influx to Europe of production from very fierce realities such as China, Brazil, Korea and India, which, in the face of the new American duties, will not fail to pour into the European market. And we defend our production, as in the case of the Embraco, which you leave alone! You won't talk about the Embraco? It's a disgrace! Enough with the transfer of production to the detriment of the protection of our workers! Shame! Let's defend the Embraco!

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, insulting world leaders, be it Trump or even Prime Minister May, appears to have become the norm. But let me just remind you of some key facts here before we start throwing bats and whatever at the USA. The European Union is the largest protectionist trade block in the world: EUR 17 billion a year charged to exporters via the common external tariff. Even the Commission admits to 5 000 non-tariff barriers. And then we have all of the red tape and the regulation, which equally acts as a tariff barrier or a barrier to trade in some context. Therefore, to keep criticising Mr Trump and the USA because of his trade policy is not going to be in the least bit helpful, because he’s going to be able to come back and say: ‘What about in your own backyard? Why don’t you sort out to own trade policy in the first instance?’ Diplomacy is going to be absolutely pivotal here. We don’t need revenge, we don’t need retaliation and we don’t need penalty. Just remember how important the USA market is for European Member States. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President! We are not responsible for China's overcapacity, nor are we responsible for the lack of competitiveness of the American steel industry. That is why these US measures against us are unjustified, wrong and harmful to both sides. But, ladies and gentlemen, it is our responsibility to work with all partners in the World Trade Organisation to ensure that global trade continues to have the power of law, not the power of the strongest. That is why it is a good thing that the European Commission is relying on talks. That is why it is a good thing that the European Commission is proposing countermeasures which send a clear signal, but which are prudent and which do not allow the situation to escalate further. I call on President Trump: Dear Mr. President, tear down this wall. Tear down those measures which are harming the transatlantic relations, and tear down those unjustified measures against your close friends and allies.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, reckless protectionism and nationalism can only isolate the United States and hurt the international rules-based trading system. Yes, a potential trade war can be triggered by new duties on steel and aluminium and can heavily impact first and foremost American jobs. Therefore, this Parliament can only invite President Trump and the US administration to take into consideration the potential damage before going any further. Do not forget: trade war can go global. Moreover, it is important for the EU to take all necessary measures – but well-calibrated in substance – to safeguard and to protect our internal market and workers and industries. I will finish, nevertheless, by stating the obvious. Whilst transatlantic relations are facing an important number of challenges and disruptions in the short term, the long-term fundamentals remain strong. The cooperation between the EU and US as like-minded partners remains crucial, notably when it comes to trade and investment, and any further action on both sides should remain balanced and take into consideration the importance of our strategic relations and for the sides’ role at world level.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Mr President, let us be honest with each other. America is taking more and more sides for itself, for America. They are increasingly finding that their ancient allies should be shouting their own minds. We see this in the Middle East, where Europe is expected to take the hot coals out of the fire. We see this in the debate on defence and NATO, where America believes that we should invest more ourselves. We also see this in free trade across the Atlantic, which does not become easier. TTIP has been discharged. And today we are talking about import tariffs on aluminium and steel. Let us not make that sense either: this is not a new evolution. We already saw this under Obama, we're seeing it again under Trump. I would therefore like to call for this: let us look at ourselves above all, let us not fall into the trap, not overreact, on the contrary. Let's take up the glove, proud, with confidence, confidence. We choose against a trade war. We choose against protectionism. We opt for fair and correct free trade, because it is good for our businesses, our jobs and our consumers. A trade war does not make America and Europe great again, but makes us all small. Not great again.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: - Mr President! I think that many of my colleagues have well described the merit of free trade and how important it is that we on the part of the European Union now do not push for a trade war. If there are measures that are aimed at us, we will obviously need to respond, but we are careful of a very, very unbalanced gentleman on the other side of the Atlantic who can act one way one day to go in a very different direction the next day. What makes me most distressed in this is not really the direct tariffs being proposed now, but it is the immediate consequences that are spreading. We see, for example, how Electrolux stops investment in the US, and this is just the beginning of the chain reaction we would see if there is a full-scale trade war. At the same time, the EU and the US are losing force to direct the energy that we should have done towards China and the very unfair trade conditions that China has. I therefore hope that we can get back to the negotiating table jointly with the US, work towards greater free trade and direct the shots where they are going, above all at China's unfair trade rules.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, Donald Trump does not care about lower-income workers, their jobs, their wages or their rights. We know this from his actions in providing tax breaks for the richest, and his regular attacks on vital services such as health care. But he was elected because he exploited the genuine concerns of many working people in the United States: people who haven’t received the benefits of free trade and globalisation, who in fact have lost their jobs and their faith in politics. Trump’s latest actions in imposing trade tariffs must be seen in this context. However, the European Commission is playing in to his game by promoting a dangerous trade agenda. Through deals such the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and Mercosur, the EU will actually increase the alienation and distrust that has already surged in many Member States. Any honest observer will attest that this agenda is, rather than enriching everyone, actually exacerbating the race to the bottom on global labour rights and standards. If we want to respond effectively to Trumpism then we need to abandon a trade agenda that will only widen inequalities in Europe and across the globe.

name: Franck PROUST
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, allow me to ask you a question: Do you think that all the meetings that you are doing now between the US and the European administrations really serve something, with Donald Trump? Of course, I'm not questioning you. I ask the question because I think his most loyal advisor seems to be his television set and his closest spokesperson is his Twitter account. When we share more than two centuries of history together, the President of the United States does not use Twitter to announce such serious measures for the economy. When fighting together with common goals, he must gather and not twist the arms of his allies. Do you need to “tweeter” in bold to be heard? We can ride on our great horses, ask for trade war or negotiate, it is in any case playing a stupid game that puts many sectors at great risk. After racing the one with the biggest nuclear button, Donald Trump plays the one with the biggest tariffs. Between this, unfair competition and globalisation without rules, Europe must rely on itself and, above all, assume itself. In any case, Donald Trump can concede one thing: he works miracles. Like Moses, he spits everything in his way, both his advisers and, unfortunately, even common sense.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, we all know that the post-World War order of free and fair rules-based trade is something we built together with the Americans, and therefore we also know that what Trump is doing right now is a major tactical and strategic mistake by unilaterally imposing tariffs that could disturb that rule-based order. That will be a long-term consequence if we enter into a trade war, so we should avoid that. We also have legitimate concerns about actors like China that are dumping steel on the global market, and we have to face them together – China and others – in the World Trade Organization. We agree upon that. Secondly, we live in integrated economies, and we see that globalisation is changing the nature of work and of our industries rapidly, and I think that conversation – how to help workers and industries to transform – is an important discussion that we share with the Americans, and we should have that discussion with them. Bilateral tariffs will only damage workers and will only make it more painful on both sides of the Atlantic, so let’s get to help the workers in a real way by discussing how they can be qualified and helped to get new jobs and live in a globalisation area where they are challenged.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, today we are discussing President Donald Trump's new activity on the fixing of tariffs on steel and aluminum. This decision, I think, towards international trade, is an unfortunate, wrong decision. It raises absolutely unnecessary emotions towards the economic cooperation of the United States of America and the European Union. Of course, there were immediately suggestions for retaliatory measures. Any trade war is dangerous and only brings casualties on both sides. It is therefore important to seek diplomatic solutions immediately before the domino effect is triggered. Clearly, global overproduction of steel can only be resolved by agreement of all stakeholders. I believe it is pointless to call on the Commission's top officials for urgent commercial diplomatic negotiations, and I thank the Commissioner for today's information. The impact on the steel industry can be dramatic, especially after very strong CO2 regulations and restrictions on coal use. Already today, the situation in steel is really on edge, and few realize the indispensability of steel, for example, in transport or construction. If we fail to address this problem of customs protection, I am concerned not only about possible similar actions in other areas, but also about serious damage to the European steel industry.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, I think you are right in identifying the commitment and the attempt to avoid an escalation and crisis in commercial relations with the U.S. But I believe that the most interesting and most important aspect, and at the same time dramatic, is to prevent Europe from being faced, for Trump's responsibility, for responsibility of these duties, a crisis that could arise, because only in 2017 we had to confront exaggerated imports, especially in the steel and steel sector, which come from countries outside Europe. I believe that this is a real attack on the European trading system. I believe that this attack is faced with diplomatic interlocution, with the search for solutions that prevent, precisely, the disaster of a real crisis, but at the same time I strongly agree on a compactness with respect to the safeguard clauses which the Commission intends to assume.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: Mr President, President Trump's measures on imports of aluminum and steel are unfair, unnecessary, and jeopardize transatlantic trade relations. They cannot be justified in defence of national security. It is a disloyalty that implies not considering the European Union as an ally of the United States. In the Union we also suffer the consequences of the global overcapacity of aluminium and steel because of the excess production of countries which do not act under market economy rules. It is therefore more necessary than ever to uphold rules-based regulation of globalization and trade: the law of the strongest must be prevented from prevailing, which aims to impose protectionist and populist measures by harming everyone. The Union does well to provide a strong but balanced response, acting intelligently, with a single voice and in coordination and cooperation with our WTO partners. It is everyone's responsibility to avoid a trade war that would only lead to less growth and loss of jobs. That is why we must all ask Trump to rethink.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: — Mr President, President Trump's decision was a bitter surprise for us, for the EPP Group, a supporter of free and fair trade put to the people. We know that protectionism does not solve problems, but creates them. A trade war has no winners, but only losers. American citizens, supporters of President Trump, will lose. American and European industries will lose. Eastern European countries, including Romania, my country, will suffer a lot. The major global steel producers, Russia, Ukraine, Turkey, are our neighbors. They will direct their exports to us. That is why we call on the European Commission to find the fastest, firm and convincing answer, at the same time proportionate, to defend European industries and avoid a trade war, which would cost us all the welfare of our citizens.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. In the beginning, aluminium and steel, then German cars and now already industrial and agricultural products. Trump's plans for punitive tariffs on European products are difficult to understand, but follow a perfididiously strategy. While all sectors are trembling around US sales markets, all trading partners are expected to byper for bilateral exemptions. This is in stark contrast to our vision of a multilateral trade policy based on values and foundations of law. It is clear that the announced punitive tariffs do not have a legal basis and Europe will not shy away from major countermeasures. A negotiated solution, however, can only succeed if we insist selfishly on exemptions for Europe, but also advocate fair and rules-based trade together with our allies. It's like in the schoolyard: bullying stops when no one participates.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, history teaches us that trade wars are not good even for those who propose them, even if it is said, superficially, that they are easy to win. Commissioner Malmström reminded us that we know how they start, but we do not know how they end. The Commission has reacted with restraint, preparing a catalogue of countermeasures in defence of the interests of our citizens and our businesses and in line with the rules of the World Trade Organisation. Today it is amazing to have to remember that trade is progress, that trade is peace, and that the walls, walls, barriers, unilateralism are now in the paleolithic of history and mean playing a clearly losing card. In these difficult circumstances, the Commission, its negotiating strategy for preferential agreements, must be supported and doubled the commitment to free trade and for a system of fair, predictable, stable rules that encourage and encourage world trade and trade.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Mr President, President Trump's decision to impose tariffs of 25% on steel imports and 10% on aluminium imports is a totally unacceptable declaration of trade war. This protectionist measure hides behind a false justification of national security, violates the rules of the World Trade Organisation, seriously affects the European economy and puts the global economy at risk. The European Commission therefore has the support of this Parliament to implement, if the decision remains, a proportionate but firm response that will defend the thousands of European jobs that are under threat. There is a problem on the world steel and aluminium market, but that problem is called China and requires a concerted response from the international community against Chinese dumping, not measures that miss the target and unfairly and unacceptable hit the European Union's economy.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: Mr President, I would like to take you to the town of IJmuiden on the North Sea, where 9 000 people work on the production of 7 million tonnes of steel. Because about them this debate is about, and about the difference between being right and getting right. Because, of course, we're right. No one can explain to us — and it is not clumsy — that European steel and aluminium in deodorant vans and canned cans in America would pose a threat to national security. Of course it's not. But whether we 'get' right is the question now. Especially now that there's someone in the White House who's ignoring international rules and appointments. By the way, if that boot comes from his daughter Ivanka's shoe collection, he's probably made from China. There is the hypocrisy of the Trump family. But to be right, we will have to act as the European Union. Obviously proportional, because no one has anything to do with escalation, but clearly. That means two things: safeguard measures in the very short term, so that our markets are not overrun, and tackling the real problem of overproduction and dumping from China. Not to be right, but for those people in IJmuiden and other places in Europe whose jobs depend on this.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: — Mr President, I would have liked to enlighten Mr Bay — but he is no longer there, it is a pity — and to inform him that in Florange there are still more than 2,000 workers who process nearly 3 million tonnes of steel every year. That being said, although it is true that Trump's unilateral measures are detestable, the substance of his decision deserves consideration. It is the question of the future of the industry that is being asked. Today the United States, tomorrow the European Union, because we suffer from the same symptoms: lack of investment and lack of anticipation. We are answered by jumping like cabris: free trade, free trade, free trade. But what free trade are we talking about? What is the fair price? If free trade is only about always pulling prices down, China will put us all on their knees. So it is not necessary to respond to provocation by provocation, on the contrary! You must and we must be on the offensive to urgently call for a revision of WTO rules to reintroduce social and environmental considerations into international pricing.

name: Romana TOMC
text: — The US forecasts regarding the introduction of customs duties, of course, worry me very much, but to say that they could not be expected would be naive. Unfortunately, we cannot command others how to behave, but we can influence how we will behave. Of course, I do not want any trade war, it would be harmful to everyone, but above all for our European citizens, but we must also ask ourselves what brought us into such a situation. Let's remember, about two years ago, it was from when there were very many protests, even in this hall, against the TTIP trade agreement. And today these get excited about free trade. We can no longer afford to find ourselves in a situation where we have to defend ourselves and it is obvious that Europe is becoming increasingly vulnerable in the economic, economic sphere and that we need to take such measures that will primarily protect European values, the European economy and European economy borders.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioners, our disappointment, sadness do not take place for measures to protect companies, Romanian products, Romanian citizens. Mr. Trump accustomed us to radical decisions. After all, he shows that he doesn't respect a partner. We are members of the World Trade Organisation and I believe, Commissioner, that out of the three measures, I would not start with the first, with legal action. You yourself said it takes a very long time. I believe that we must address the World Trade Organisation, negotiate and, of course, in particular, protect the market, because in other situations, when we asked in this plenary to have measures to protect the market, not to close the market, but to protect, because we have dumped products, this did not happen. Therefore, I believe that we do not need a trade war, but we need to come back very firmly, for the protection of European — obviously, and Romanian — products and European companies. That is why I am advocating negotiation and safeguard measures.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, the measures taken by Trump pose an economic threat to everyone and a democratic setback. The national security that justifies them hurts a historic ally. Therefore, these measures are unacceptable and old. Schuman already demonstrated, in 1950, that security and stability were enhanced by just the opposite path. American industry should take its part by reminding its president of what happened with similar measures taken by Bush in 2002, which ended in a disaster for the United States. I therefore support the proposals put forward by Commissioner Malmström, encourage them to be implemented with all relevant actors in the industrial field, and inform that the Basque Government has made itself fully available to the Community authorities to collaborate in the design of a shared strategy. The Basque Country is an industrial region strongly impacted by this announcement. He has already been involved in the design of measures in the face of the previous crisis — generated by Chinese overcapacity — and has just communicated to the European authorities his confidence and its offer to cooperate in order to avoid a trade war that is good for anyone.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, by decision of the President of the United States, additional taxes will be imposed on imports of steel products at a level of 25% and 10% on aluminium products next week. This decision was obviously taken to protect American industries from competition from imports, and I say 'obviously' because there is no question of national security in the United States. However, this decision poses problems both in European countries and in the United States. There is a risk that hundreds of thousands of jobs will be lost, production costs will increase and, more generally, there will be friction between the two parties. These measures are particularly affected by the Greek industries concerned. At a time when the country is in a crisis of economy, the steel and aluminium industries in Greece are spending large sums on investment in technology products to be able to meet the demands of the markets. But if the measures taken by the United States are taken countermeasures and there is an economic war, it will be to the detriment of all. That is why the European Union must demand that these products be excluded from the... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Milan ZVER
text: — Euro-Atlantic connections are of strategic long-term importance for the US and also for the European Union. It takes root in a common culture, a common cultural basis, shared values, in the economies that have connected us so far. The US action to drastically raise tariffs on steel and aluminium, however, goes in the opposite direction. It is certainly a new protectionism that, rather than cooperation, establishes a frontline confrontation. Let's remember where protectionism led one century ago. It means, above all, closing economies rather than cooperating and respecting competition. The European Union's response is good for the time being. I congratulate the European Commission on preparing a decisive and proportionate response within World Trade Organisation rules. But I would like to reiterate what our President Weber said in the morning: even if the U.S. or anyone else is building walls, we will continue to build bridges.

name: Maria ARENA
text: — Mr President, I have just three questions in relation to the debate we had. The first question, Commissioner, do you sincerely believe that today the WTO has the capacity to enforce the rules at international level and, if so, how do you intend to pursue this policy within the WTO? We have all said, we are in favour of multilateralism, but today we see that there is a lack of compliance with the rules. Secondly, as far as industry support is concerned: of course, we are not in favour of protectionism, but free trade puts our industries under enormous pressure today compared to competitors who do not comply with a number of rules. How can we support our industries if, indeed, we do not address this issue clearly? Thirdly, we will have derivative effects in relation to the closure of U.S. markets. We talked about Chinese overproduction. How are we going to apply the new trade defence instruments, but also the significant distortion? Are you ready, Commissioner, to activate the tools we have just voted here in this House?

name: Christian EHLER
text: – Mr President, interestingly, the tariffs are not based on the basic trade legislation from the 1980s, but on the National Security Act of 1962. The expected reaction of the Commission would be that we go to the World Trade Organization (WTO) and we might indicate retaliatory measures.  But couldn’t it be a tactical measure that this is being based on the 1962 Act? This is because we are not quite sure whether or not, in terms of the WTO, if we lose the case based on national security concerns, then this could make the WTO system explode. If the measures were based on the Trade Act of 1989, then a WTO decision would have vertical effect on this specific measure, but if you lose the case on that measure, based on the national security angle, then, in principle, there would be a horizontal effect and that would make the system explode. I am just asking what your perception is of the tactical aspect of what Mr Lighthizer is going to do.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this is an unfortunate situation. Everyone knows – and has been told here – that a trade war cannot be won. Maybe it is time, using this situation, to send the United States an invitation to a European Union—United States summit to discuss all these issues: political and diplomatic cooperation, the economy, trade, investments, security and defence. Maybe Mr Trump has forgotten that the closest allies of the United States are the European Union countries, not only Australia. Maybe we should use this situation in a positive way in order to have this summit. There have been too many situations recently where the European Union has had to respond to its close ally, the United States of America. It is probably time for discussions, and the President of the Council, the President of the Commission and Ms Mogherini should launch this initiative.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Trump's decision to impose customs duties on imports of steel and aluminium products should not surprise us. He and in the election period and later said that his policy is “America first”, and that means a closed economy in order to support American businesses, and has the potential to implement this policy because the U.S. market is a huge market and can withstand the closed borders. It is a question of what conclusions does the European Union draw, which has had a free trade policy in which we have allowed large imports, cheap imports of steel products from China, resulting in the dismantling of the steel industry in Europe. Specific measures must therefore be taken, particularly for the Greek steel and aluminium industries which are suffering and will suffer from these Trump policies.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the accounts are open and the conflicting interests of the monopolies are large. Overaccumulated capital that can't find a profitable way out, sparkling recovery, capitalist economies intertwined with power upheavals. Unfinished capital agreements, such as the transatlantic, transatlantic, interpeaceful, Paris climate, reveal the competition between the United States, China, Russia and the European Union, with the particular interests of Germany and France. Capital forces compete but agree and share a common line on how to intensify exploitation at the expense of workers. The duties that everyone exorcises and ultimately imposes on their competitor on behalf of the interests of profitability of their own groups are another tool of urban states with workers injured. It's not just war, it's not just commercial, it's called capitalism, the rotten exploitative system that can't be cured or humanized. As the deadlocks grow, the peoples with their class struggle not to accept victims on the altar of these antagonisms.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, my background is sport, and in sport we often say that you have short-term pain for long-term gain. In other words, if you train hard, you will reap the rewards in due course. But what we are seeing  in the United States now is short-term gain for long-term pain. But that does not really worry Donald Trump. He made promises in the election and, regardless of the consequences, he wants to be able to say: ‘I promised ABC, I have delivered ABC’. Long-term pain, short-term gain, perhaps. We have had a long relationship with the United States and we want that to continue. This week, for instance, in my own country we have our national holiday, St Patrick’s Day, and the United States will turn green. But there is more to the United States than Donald Trump. Nevertheless, we cannot roll over on this one, and it is important that the Commission – and I am quite sure they will – take a proportionate, mature attitude and, hopefully, the matter can be resolved.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, a little over a year ago we were discussing a free trade agreement with Obama. Today we are facing a budding trade war with Trump with unpredictable consequences. How times change! Europe has not started it, but Europe must try to defend itself and must try to avoid it. Companies and thousands of workers, many of them from my region, Galicia, are on the edge of the future of their jobs in an industry that is already shaken by China's overcapacity and dumping practices. If the United States wants to deal with the problem, that is where it should turn its eyes, not to its European partner. Prudence is imposed but, of course, firmness is also imposed. Companies and workers need the certainty that Europe will use all the diplomatic arsenal and everything it has at its disposal to ensure the future of this industry.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I will try to answer a few questions. The EU, together with Brazil, Canada and Mexico, are the countries most affected by this, but there are others who also export steel. Exactly how it strikes within the European Union: we do not have the figures here but we are of course in close dialogue with the Member States. There are about nine or ten countries affected in the European Union, but the consequences are, of course, much larger. We do not know much about the Australian exceptions. I have also read about it on Twitter. The exceptions for Canada and Mexico are related to a satisfactory outcome of the negotiations of NAFTA, so we are still looking for more information there. In the EU we are security partners to the United States. That goes a long way back. We work together in NATO; we have stood together in Iraq, Afghanistan and many other places in the world; we are cooperating in the fight against IS; and our friendship and strategic partnership goes way back. On tariffs, we need to clarify a few issues. Yes, the EU has tariffs on cars vis-à-vis the US and other countries, but the US has higher tariffs on other items. For instance, there are 25% tariffs on trucks and pickups, and you cannot discuss tariffs unilaterally. We try to take away tariffs in trade agreements. When there are no trade agreements, these are the tariffs, and they are not only vis-à-vis the US, but they are against all countries with whom we do not have a free trade agreement. So that is why you cannot negotiate them individually. It is part of a bigger picture. We believe that this measure is a safeguard in disguise and that the exception that does exist in the WTO, but which is meant to be used for wartime, is misused. So we are confident that we could win such a case in the WTO, and we are reaching out to other friends and allies to see if we can make a joint approach to the WTO. On trade distortions, Ms Arena, that is why we have the safeguard measures that we are ready to put into place. Whether a summit is the way to solve this is beyond my pay grade. I think we have to try to solve these issues quite urgently actually. But as long as the measures have not entered into force, we hope to avoid a significant trade dispute. The root problem, as many of you have said, is over-capacity in the steel and aluminium sectors. Certain countries are using massive subsidies and producing non-market conditions, so the EU and the US should work together on this, and we are doing so. The EU have, from our side, done our part. As you know, with your help, we have modernised the trade defence instruments. We are using them and we are trying to uphold rules against those countries which distort trade or which have unfair practices. That is why we met, together with the US Trade Representative and also with Minister Seko from Japan, this weekend to discuss how we jointly can work to face this challenge. We achieved a to-do list and an action plan and we will meet jointly again. It was a very constructive meeting, and the aim is, of course, to work to improve the level playing field. Protection is never a good answer, and that is why we are reaching out to other parties of the world in order to jointly stand up for the principles of the rules—based international global trading system and the multilateral organisations. WTO is not perfect, but it has served us well – us, the US and many other countries of the world – and we would rather work together to strengthen it and not weaken it. That is why we are also reaching out to other countries and have this very ambitious trading agenda. We are creating a circle of friends with parties across the world who are of the firm belief that trade is a good thing if we make good trade agreements based on fair, sustainable and transparent trade. That is good for our people and for our companies. That is why we stand up to do this within the framework of WTO rules and the global trading system. I want to thank you for the strong support you have given to the Commission and our approach to adopt WTO-compatible measures. We are doing this in a measured and calm way. I also want to thank you because I know many of you have reached out individually to US counterparts in Congress and elsewhere. That is indeed very useful. So thank you very much for this debate. (Applause)

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this House’s very strong support for the policy the Commission has adopted in this fight. It’s very important that the whole EU is united when addressing this kind of trade issues and difficulties. We also acknowledge in the Commission the good cooperation with the Congress of the United States. Both main parties – Republicans and Democrats – share the view on rules-based world order and rules-based trade with us. We have to acknowledge this good cooperation. The business sector in the United States also shares our views. So we have to acknowledge this. This is not a dispute between Europe and the United States as such. That is why the Commission will concentrate on problem-solving instead of provoking further problems in this fight. What do we want to do is to clear up this mess. I think there are good reasons which both sides will, at the end of the day, accept that we don’t need and we don’t want a trade war. Instead we should concentrate on improving our trading conditions between the two trading blocks and like-minded continents. This incident is a good reminder for all of us: when we want to build or harness globalisation, it must be based on rules-based world order instead of the rule of the strongest.  Trade agreements are good examples of building a rules-based world order. Actually, the reality is as simple as this: we have to choose between the two options. Either we want to have trade agreements which bring values to trade and strengthen the rules-based world order, or then we are in a situation where we are at the moment, where arbitrary decisions can harm all of us. We will try to find a solution as soon as possible, and we want to enhance our trading and security cooperation with the United States.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I'm closing the debate. (The sitting was suspended for a while.) Written statements (Article 162)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. — (PT) The decision announced by US President Donald Trump to introduce high import tariffs for steel and aluminium is a very worrying sign of a setback in the opening of trade and undermining the future of trade relations between the two largest world economies. The European Commission must act cautiously, but firmly. A trade war is not in the interest of either party.

name: Ivo BELET
text: in writing. — (NL) The US President is trying to play EU Member States against each other. The British have tried the same in the Brexit negotiations: they have come home from a cold carnival. Within the EU, there has been a growing awareness that we are much stronger than a united and united bloc in such conflict issues. If Trump continues with his adolescent measures, contrary to the advice of almost all of his economic advisers, then the EU has no choice to respond. In the meantime, we need to figure out how to roll out the concept of a border levy on CO2: that idea is built into the agreement on the reform of the ETS system that we recently concluded. It would mean paying a tax on CO2 intensive products sold in the EU at European borders. Products that have not been produced according to the cleanest production technologies will be subject to additional costs, as in the European ETS, the EU's emissions trading scheme. In addition, American steel and aluminium are in the crosshairs. In particular, however, the heavily polluting imports from China could be tackled. In the light of the planned American revival of the heavily polluting coal industry, this is a more than responsible exercise.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: in writing. — I support the Commission's approach. First of all, as is customary between partners, it is important to seek dialogue. However, if this fails, I support the possible countermeasures announced by the European Commission last week. Europe is competitive, we produce high quality products, we are inventive and creative, and therefore we do not allow ourselves to be put under pressure.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: in writing. — Today in the world, everyone wants to produce and sell favorably. This creates a deep financial imbalance — the debt of many countries and the economic collapse of numerous regions of the world. This unsustainable globalization and overproduction of many goods, including steel, triggered the adverse phenomenon of a return in the US to national protectionism in the form of a 25% duty on steel. China's massive steelmaking surplus could therefore be steering even more of a stream diverted at dumped prices to Europe. What will the condition of our (Polish) metallurgy be then? Is this the beginning of the world's trade war? Is this the beginning of a rip-off of post-war order on the Europe-US line? The world needs to sit down to a “round table” and reform the WHO or create a new international institution with wider remit. Otherwise, there will be economic chaos and political upheaval, and even local hot wars. In favour of rapid diplomatic steps from the EU to agree with EU partners: Japan, Brazil, Mexico and others, the rebalancing of the economies of EU countries will undoubtedly become an asumpt for future, optimal reindustrialisation and the establishment of a new global market.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: in writing. — Friends seem to be becoming enemies. US President Trump and the President of the European Commission Juncker are holding each other in a stranglehold as they continue and expand their protectionist trade measures. We, both here in the EU and in the US, must do everything to prevent a trade war. On the contrary, the US and the EU must work together to tackle the real problems associated with trade. I have been resisting steel dumping by countries like China for years. I'm worried about strategic acquisitions by foreign powers. I have been advocating the inclusion of social and environmental standards in trade agreements for a long time. I would therefore like to say to the gentlemen: keep your head cool, do not retreat behind their own dikes and work together.

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: in writing. — U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminium imports is economic nationalism.
