It's a populist and wrong policy that will give Trump support in simple grassroots circles for a while, but will not resolve economic issues while propelling a thorough rift between allies. This Decision entails a deliberate weakening of the international trade system, a breakdown of the World Trade Organisation and its rules. This will lead to a war of everything described by philosopher Thomas Hobbs against all. If Europe is not subject to an exception, it will have to respond with the same thing, which will further escalate the situation through a spiral upwards. As a result, China and Russia will initially benefit from the US-EU tensions in trade relations. The situation with Chinese imports of aluminum and steel should have been addressed by the US together with Europe and its allies. If necessary, the terms of trade may be changed, but we must not abandon them altogether. The EU should now make special efforts to strengthen rules-based trade, for example by ratifying agreements with Japan and Singapore.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. — The growing protectionist trends in the world could pose a serious threat to our producers. To counter this, the need to sort out globalization and liberalization processes. The way to this end is through the adoption of certain rules, rules, good practices at world level. Until recently, the World Trade Organisation (WTO) was the forum for adopting such rules, but it is gradually losing its importance, as exemplified by the December talks fiasco at the Ministerial Conference in Buenos Aires. A small role in dismantling the WTO is played by President Trump's administration. Protectionism violates the rules of trade adopted between partners. I did not use the term “violates the principles of the free market” because there are situations where, by bilateral or multilateral agreement, certain preferences for certain participants in the free market are accepted. Such a departure from free market principles, however, must have deep justification. It would be necessary to specify at international level what situation that threatens national interests or security must occur on the market in order to introduce such sharp safeguard arrangements in the form of unilateral decisions, without any arrangements, consultation. A principle in line with good commercial practices has been adopted in order to ensure that the actions taken are always proportionate to the situation. If this proportion is violated, then there is retaliatory action by the other side, which is actually the beginning of a trade war.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate with the Prime Minister of Portugal, António Costa, on the future of Europe (2018/2576 (RSP)). Before giving the floor to António Costa, I remind you that you can request the “catch-the-eye” using the electronic voting device. To introduce your request, enter the voting card and use any of the electronic voting buttons. I now proceed to the opening of the system which will remain open during the intervention of Prime Minister Costa.

name: António COSTA
text: Prime Minister of Portugal — Mr President of the European Parliament, Mr President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I thank President Tajani for the opportunity to address the European Parliament to discuss with you the future of Europe. It is a great pleasure for me to return to this House, where I served, albeit briefly, as a Member and Vice-President, and which has contributed so much, as the only institution directly elected by the citizens, to improving transparency and democracy in Europe. I also welcome the presence of the President of the Commission, whose vision, pragmatism and experience and his Europeanism have helped us find solutions, overcome divisions and strengthen our Union. In recent years, the European Union has been shaken by a succession of crises unprecedented in its history and which have shaken it at its foundations — from the great economic recession of 2008 to Brexit and the dramatic refugee crisis in summer 2016. We live now, indeed, a moment of appeasement. We can finally celebrate the return of economic growth and we have prevented Brexit from becoming a principle of breakdown. In any case, there is no reason for complacency. The European Union must live up to its historic responsibility. In Bratislava, the Member States committed themselves to stay united and to make the Union more attractive and worthy of the trust and support of our citizens. In Brussels, before this Parliament, President Juncker presented, on behalf of the Commission, an ambitious White Paper on the future of Europe. In Gothenburg, we proclaimed the 20 principles of the Social Pillar, and the leaders agenda proposed by President Tusk has allowed a frank and direct debate between Heads of State or Government. The question today is very simple: do we want to continue to promise much and do little, or are we able to honour the commitments we have made to our citizens? Do we have the courage to make choices and to provide the Union with the means and instruments to respond to the challenges we face? Perhaps because Portugal has returned to Europe, after 48 years of dictatorship and thirteen years of anachronistic colonial wars in Africa, and because we experienced the tensions of the revolutionary period that founded our democracy, Portugal knows well that being European is not just a geographical or historical coincidence. More than a single currency, rather than an internal market, Europe is above all a community of values. Being European means belonging to a system of values. Peace, the unconditional defence of democracy, the rule of law, freedom, equality, the dignity of the human person and solidarity — these are the values that brought Portugal to Europe. It was the desire to consolidate the regained democracy and to be able to share a common area of freedom, security, peace and prosperity. It was with this vision that Mário Soares signed Portugal's application for membership of the then EEC as early as 1977 and signed the accession treaty in 1985. I would therefore like to take this opportunity to thank President Tajani once again for the tribute this Parliament has paid to this great European and its former member. Sharing a common home, sharing the same values obviously does not mean giving up our own identity or renouncing the freedom of each one to make their own choices. The future of Europe is not compatible with a single thought, whatever it may be. Democracy in Europe cannot be shunted by a 'there is no alternative' idea. On the contrary, it means awakening, among all, a set of common rules of coexistence and giving each one the freedom to be able to follow his own path, in accordance with these common rules and for the benefit of all. As in a big family, living at 28 or 27 in the same house isn't always easy. That's why rules are needed. But these rules do not serve to standardize policies. The rules serve to ensure that common compromises can be achieved through the different policies that electorates choose, democratically and sovereignly. In Portugal, we have defined an alternative to austerity policy, focusing on more economic growth, more and better jobs and greater equality. The replenishment of incomes has restored confidence to economic operators, allowing for the greatest economic growth since the beginning of the century, sustained growth in private investment, exports and employment. It is true that we have done differently, but we adhere to the rules and today we have stronger public finances than we had three years ago. We came out of the excessive deficit procedure in 2017. Last year we had the lowest deficit of 43 years of our democracy, and last week the European Commission removed Portugal from the list of countries with excessive macroeconomic imbalances. (Applause) But most importantly, the affirmation of democratic sovereignty has restored confidence in democratic institutions and in the European Union, as the last barometer shows, with clear support from the Portuguese for the European Union. We therefore have no existential crisis. It is in the Union, and with all who want it, that we want to build our future. And we have many challenges ahead of us: climate change, instability at our external border, terrorism, globalisation, digital transition and migration. But we must be aware that none of the great challenges we face will be better solved outside the Union, by each Member State alone, however populous or prosperous it may be. Only the European Union, together, will be able to lead concerted action on a global scale to implement the Paris Agreement, which is vital to respond to the climate change that threatens humanity in its existence. Only united in permanent structured cooperation can we assume a increasing responsibility, in solidarity and complementarity with NATO, in the face of instability at our borders, which threatens peace and our security. Only together can we strengthen police cooperation, judicial cooperation and the exchange of data between our intelligence services to tackle terrorism, which spreads fear on the streets of our cities. Only the Union will give strength to a trade policy capable of helping to regulate global markets and protect the high social, environmental and food safety standards that we want to preserve, regulating globalisation, which challenges the sustainability of the European social model. Only the development of the Social Pillar and the Single Market and joint investment in the knowledge society and energy transition enable us to ensure growth and decent employment, the only effective response to the anguish that digital transition and automation pose about the future of work. (Applause.) Only on a European scale can we go to the root of the problem of migration, which alter the balance of our societies, by acting to promote inclusive growth and sustainable development, peace and human rights in Africa, in cooperation with countries of origin and transit, following the call of Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres, to a new global pact on migration, and only jointly and severally among all can we ensure the defence of our common external border against organised crime networks that promote trafficking in human beings and share, in solidarity, the duty to guarantee international protection to all those who need it. Yes, it is true that all these challenges exist and that we must face them. Not with major institutional debates or paralysing revisions of the treaties — the essential thing is to define what we want to do. Institutional architecture is just an instrument that will enable us to implement it. Invert order is counterproductive and divides us into the accessory before we unite on the essential. And time is pressing. Our focus must be on the citizens, listening to them and giving them back confidence in our ability to face and overcome each of these challenges. What distinguishes democratic politics from populism is that democratic politics does not exploit fears or lives off problems. On the contrary, democratic politics responds to problems, combats fear and anguish and returns hope to the future of all citizens. Globalization does not face itself by closing borders or erasing walls, going back into a protectionist logic or xenophobic drift. We must make it clear that these are not and will never be Europe's options. The European Union will only gain if it continues to project the vision of a Europe open to the world, from Japan to Mercosur. What globalisation requires of us is that we be able to invest in the skills, innovation and infrastructure that fit us into global networks, and only a cohesive society — economically, socially and territorially — guarantees sustained competitiveness. It is our political responsibility to respond to the legitimate wishes of European citizens, but we can only do so if we are able to build a genuine Union that is more cohesive economically, socially and politically. For this to be possible, there are two very clear priorities: completing Economic and Monetary Union — the most ambitious project we have ever been able to implement — and to provide the Union with resources tailored to its responsibilities and the challenges that we have to face. Ladies and gentlemen, convergence is the key to union in Europe. Only this can guarantee the necessary stability of the euro area by ensuring risk reduction and benefit-sharing. The financial crisis we are experiencing has exposed the weaknesses of the single currency. Faced with an emergency, we avoided, largely by enlightened action by the European Central Bank, the breakdown that it threatened us and we created, with the Juncker plan, a new instrument to support investment, which, with the contribution of this Parliament, would even be strengthened. However, even with these advances, the structural weaknesses in the euro area remain unresolved. The asymmetries and imbalances between its members reduce potential growth and call into question the stability of the single currency. As long as economic and monetary union remains incomplete, the risks of new crises will be greater. We need to take advantage of this moment of growth and optimism in the markets to give new impetus to Economic and Monetary Union, which strengthens convergence and prevents new crises. (Applause.) Economic and Monetary Union can never function satisfactorily based solely on its monetary pillar. As a matter of time, I am not going to develop here the issues of the Banking Union, which we have begun and which we must conclude, of the need to clarify obscure budgetary rules or the development of the European Stability Mechanism. I will focus on what I believe is essential in order to optimise the euro area as a monetary union, correcting the asymmetries and strengthening convergence. Every mature monetary union has a budgetary capacity, and that is why I am advocating the creation of a budgetary capacity of the euro area, linked to the exercise of the European Semester. This budgetary capacity could serve as a stabilisation instrument against external shocks, but its primary objective should be investment, providing the country-specific recommendations consolidated in the national reform programmes with financial instruments for their implementation. It is not a question of establishing a transfer union or financing mechanisms for national inefficiencies. I want to be clear: I do not advocate permanent transfers. The convergence mechanism that I propose, somewhat close to the reform instrument referred to recently by the Commission, should be based on a contractual basis, in order to implement reforms tailored to each country, based on its own structural blockades to improve its growth potential, with quantified and timed targets, the fulfilment of which determines the transfer phased out of the financing tranches. For example, looking at Portugal's country report, our priority should be investment in education, lifelong learning, research and development and innovation, setting success metrics and timetables for achievement. Support for convergence is the right step to hold each Member State accountable for carrying out the reforms it needs. It is the best instrument for ensuring the stability of the euro area and combining economic growth with budgetary discipline. It is about creating incentives for reforms, positive conditionality and not punitive conditionality. Because we cannot continue to look at the euro area as a set of economies that compete with each other and then with the rest of the world. We must treat the euro area as an integrated area, whose prosperity and cohesion benefit all its members, where the added value of the whole depends on the success of each and every one. (Applause.) The lasting and sustainable stabilisation of the euro area is the first condition for us to build Europe's future on a solid foundation. The second condition is that we give the Union a budget tailored to its demands and ambitions. In its recent report on the next multiannual financial framework, the European Parliament argued that more European policies and programmes can only be implemented with more resources and not less. We are following this Parliament and set out for this new round of negotiations on the multiannual financial framework with a clear position. We must strengthen the Union's own resources and we need an increase in contributions of all Member States. Portugal is available to increase its contribution and supports the creation of new own resources, as proposed in the Mário Monti report, the subject of multiple suggestions. Only in this way can we honour our commitment to citizens to ensure greater security against climate change, external threats and terrorism, and the future of our social model, employment and migration management, without sacrificing policies that are already part of the European Union's identity, such as the common agricultural policy or cohesion policy. It would be a grave mistake to sacrifice these policies. The success of the common agricultural policy is not limited to guaranteeing Europe's food security, and the success of cohesion policy is not limited to the contribution it has made to the economic and social modernisation of our territories. Its greatest added value was that it brought the European Union into the day-to-day life of its citizens, it has left Europe from being an abstraction to being something concrete in people's lives. With agricultural policy and cohesion policy, Europe has reached every village, every village, every part of our territory, from the large metropolises to the outermost regions. We have to tell our citizens the truth. We cannot want more from Europe without giving more to Europe. We cannot assign more responsibility to Europe without increasing our contributions and its own resources. But we can't obviously just want more, always more, more and more and more. We must also be able to do different and do better by exploiting the essential complementarity of policies and instruments and improving their efficiency. Firstly, between competitiveness and cohesion, there is no longer room for a Europe of productivity and a Europe of cohesion. We need a more competitive economy in the global market and a more cohesive society internally. But we must also be aware that the political agriculture must make a greater contribution to tackling climate change and cohesion policy must contribute to preventing radicalisation in urban peripheries and must focus more on people as an instrument of our social pillar. Similarly, the objective of cohesion must not be absent from programmes such as Horizon 2020 or the European Defence Fund, which must not aggravate the asymmetries between our economies. Only in complementarity with all these policies can we achieve greater convergence. That is why convergence should be the criterion of added value, which must be transversally present in all policies and instruments, which must complement each other, reinforcing the potential for added success. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all aware of the difficulty of these debates, both on the conclusion of Economic and Monetary Union and on the adoption of the next Multiannual Financial Framework. But nothing that is difficult today gains from being postponed. On the contrary, postponing will make everything even more difficult, because it will diminish the confidence that citizens have in our capacity to make decisions and respond to their needs, desires and aspirations. That is why we must do everything, but even everything, to close these debates during the current term of office of the current European Parliament. (Applause.) This is everyone's responsibility. We have to live up to our time. I speak, of course, for Portugal. You can count on us. Once again, as always, Portugal also has Europe, and Europe can count on Portugal. The challenges ahead are very demanding, but whenever we doubt our ability to overcome them together, let us remember and draw inspiration from a great woman, Simone Veil, the first President of the European Parliament directly elected by the citizens: 'Je suis, je reste toujours optimisste. La vie m'a appris qu'avec le temps, le progrès l'emporte toujours. C'est long, c'est lent, more en définitif, je fais confiance.” (Applause.)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. — (FR) Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased to take part in this third debate on the future of Europe in the presence and animated by the Portuguese Prime Minister, my friend António. I was in Portugal at the end of October last year and had the great honour of being invited by the President of the Portuguese Republic and to exchange views with the members of the Council of State on the same subject, the future of Europe. I also had the privilege of dialogue with the Prime Minister and in the context of a citizen dialogue with the students of Coimbra on the major European issues and their hopes for the future of the Union. That is to say how much this subject occupies, and rightly so, the minds of our Portuguese friends and not only their political leaders, but I think I can also say about a large part of Portuguese society. Portugal is a country that I love very much, I spent one of the most important moments of my life there. The Portuguese are very present in my country of origin, Luxembourg: 20% of the Luxembourg population is of Portuguese origin. Almost all of my neighbors are Portuguese. It is a joy every day to hear them speak Portuguese. Anecdote: very often, when I was Prime Minister in my country, our Portuguese friends stopped me in the streets and sidewalks to say: “Prime Minister, there are too many foreigners in Luxembourg”, which clearly shows that the integration of Portuguese citizens in Luxembourg is very successful. (Laughter) Furthermore, I cannot forget that it was the Portuguese people who, in April 1974, put an end to almost half a century of oppression and dictatorship, thus paving a peaceful path to democracy. An event that sparked relief and hope throughout our continent. Second anecdote: young man, i participated in demonstrations in front of the portuguese consulate. Towards the end of the dictatorship in your country, until now, the Grand Ducal Police investigates the following case: someone threw a stone on one of the windows of the Consulate General, the police did not find the responsible: he is in front of you. (Laughter) Portugal, after the carnation revolution, immediately and logically turned to Europe, under the inspired leadership of Mário Soares to anchor its young democracy in a solidarity ensemble. We share the same ambitions, peace — which is too often forgotten and without which nothing else would be possible — and respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. These are values of universal vocation on which our Union was built, and it is on the preservation of these values that we must build the future of our Union, for let us never forget that none of these values, peace, democracy, the rule of law is obvious. We must constantly defend them, and I know that we can count on our Portuguese friends who have always shown that they know how to give life and colour to our common values and in particular European solidarity. The reception of refugees by the Portuguese and the Portuguese Government demonstrates this very clearly. Portugal, doing more than its share, had relocated many refugees from Greece and Italy, which for the rest is an example some should draw on. (Applause) In recent years, Portugal has been particularly affected by the economic and financial crisis and I am pleased to see that Portugal is now showing good economic performance. Portugal left the excessive deficit procedure last year and last week the Commission concluded that macroeconomic imbalances are no longer excessive. Who would have believed it a few years ago? Who would have believed it? The truth is that the country has gone from one level deficit of 10 to 11% at a level of less than 2%. Unemployment is being corrected downwards and the employment rate is increasing dramatically day by day. The truth is that this progress has demanded from the Portuguese throughout these painful years considerable efforts that other Europeans do not always measure to their proper value. It is a beautiful collective performance that honours every Portuguese. I would therefore like to pay tribute here to the Portuguese, to those who have led the country throughout the years of crisis and who led it to the correction of imbalances and especially to the Portuguese people, especially the most modest. (Applause) Especially to the most modest Portuguese who contributed with admirable courage and with definite success to this great national effort. I would also like to point out that these remarkable results are wrong for those who criticized the European Commission for applying the Stability Pact with greater wisdom, even intelligence and heart by giving it a reading grid taking into account the many social challenges in Portugal. The situation has improved, but of course there is still a lot to be done. It is now a matter of consolidating efforts to permanently close the page on these dark years and resolutely turn to the future. Yes, Portugal is still experiencing imbalances, but which, in my view, are controllable. Greater productivity growth remains critical to improving competitiveness and debt reduction. Portugal knows that it can count on the Commission and our programme of support for structural reform to carry out its necessary reforms. In particular, I am working with the Prime Minister to define a pilot project to improve the qualifications and skills of adults with low levels of training. And I have confidence in the determination of the Portuguese authorities, responsible political forces to address the remaining structural weaknesses that may still hamper the full economic development of the country. These are issues that I have always discussed frankly, openly, amicably with the Prime Minister and I intend to continue this sometimes difficult but always frank, friendly and open effort because I have always thought that the future of Europe is not built by humiliating countries and not respecting the dignity of the peoples. I wanted, in the case of Portugal, as in other cases, to replace the anticipatory sanction with the constant dialogue which, moreover, leads, as Portugal's case shows, to better results. (Applause) The Prime Minister's speech before this Assembly showed that we share the same dream and love for Europe and that we all believe that the European Union remains the best future for ourselves and for generations to come. It will therefore be appropriate, in the coming months, that we together complete the work begun in recent years on the energy union, the digital union — the Prime Minister has mentioned this — on capital markets union and of course on the deepening of the economic and monetary zone, a subject on which we in the Commission have a broad intersection of views with our Portuguese friends. This is true, in particular, with regard to the need to put in place new instruments to ensure the stability, resilience of the euro area and to strengthen its internal convergence. The Commission has made very specific proposals on this subject, including a new instrument to support national reforms and a stabilization mechanism which allows us to deal with major asymmetrical shocks because it will be our duty, ladies and gentlemen, to give the next financial perspective the necessary resources to the future financial perspective. height of our ambitions. As António pointed out, we have many responsibilities, old or new, whether it be in immigration, defence policy, research, innovation or education. I understand that in Portugal the national budget represents 43% of gross national income and the share of that of the European Union is 1%, which means that out of 100 euros, 43 euros go to the Ministry of Finance in Lisbon, of which only one euro is for Europe. I welcome the Prime Minister's affirmed desire, reiterated today, to increase the Portuguese contribution to the European budget so that we can live up to our responsibilities. This is another Portuguese example to follow by — I hope — many others. But we know that often difficult choices remain to be made. The Europe we leave to our children will depend on these choices. It is up to us now to decide what Europe we want for tomorrow. Let me take one example: the Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Programme, which is not entirely innocent since Commissioner Carlos Moedas, who is lucky and happy to have Portuguese nationality and is proud to be Commissioner, is responsible for it and he is doing a job — I wanted to say — absolutely remarkable. But it is also a key programme for the growth and development of European enterprises. (Applause) We are devoting EUR 80 million, ladies and gentlemen, to this programme — the one I have just mentioned. If we decided to increase that amount to 120 million in the next financial framework, it would create an additional 420,000 jobs by 2040 and increase GDP by 0.3%. If we were to go — I dream — up to 160 million, that would result in the creation of 650,000 jobs by 2040 and an increase in GDP of 0.5%. If we do — in fact, I think we should — the European Union will become one of the world's leading players in the field of research and innovation. Finally, there is no need to say that the coming months will be crucial for the future of Europe. It is on the facts and not on the words that we will be judged, and Portugal, which, since its accession and even before, has been of all European progress, has largely demonstrated that it respects what it says, whatever the difficulties and they were great. The future of Europe also goes through Portugal. (Vivid applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Now the debate begins with the presidents representing on behalf of the political groups, please respect the time allocated to you to allow as many Members as possible to intervene in this debate and then allow António Costa to give answers. There are many topics under discussion and I am pleased that you supported the European Parliament's position on own resources; we have made some proposals, the web tax, the speculation tax financial and environmental tax. The word immediately to Manfred Weber on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group. Dear Prime Minister, welcome to the European Parliament. Because the President has pointed out that the number of topics is so great, we too will always focus our speeches. The last time Andrej Plenković was here, the Croatian colleague, I spoke on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party about the Christian values of this continent. Today I would like to talk about another issue on this continent, namely the feeling of anxiety of people on this continent, the fears of loss that are there, towards migration, globalisation, climate change, the changes that people are facing. Europe is in the midst of a debate between hope and fear, between partnership and selfishness, between Europe and nationalism. It is the debate we have on this continent. Portugal's history actually gives us a good indication. 500 years ago, when the Chinese burned their fleet and got involved, Portuguese people like Vasco da Gama set out into the world, discovered the India route and benefited from it for centuries. Your country has benefited from this for centuries. Even in the short period of history of recent years, Portugal has shown that the start of shaping, that bridge building is the right way forward in the financial crisis. Jean-Claude Juncker has already mentioned whether Portugal has given the right answers. I would like to mention a name that helped shape this, namely your predecessor, Pedro Passos Coelho, who played a major role in getting Portugal on this path today and has this economic data, that economic growth is there. The fact that Portugal is on this path of success is a common success, and therefore congratulations! Setting the sails right is the task. If we come back to this question of fear again, I'll take a look at back to the history of the continent how we dealt with the great anxiety issues of people. With the question of having poverty, with the question of getting poor in old age, with the question of not having insured the disease. 150 years ago, ladies and gentlemen, we developed the idea of a social market economy that the state should take care of taking up people's fears. I believe that today we have a duty to rethink how we can realise this social market economy in a globalised world, in a European world. We believe in the social partners. We are witnessing, however, that the companies are European and that, unfortunately, the trade unions are not yet organised in Europe to really form a counterbalance. Ladies and gentlemen, in the European budget we are alloying more than EUR 86 billion to the Social Fund to combat youth unemployment. For us as the EPP, social policy does not primarily mean supplying, but enabling it. That is why it is right that we are investing the money towards education, towards training, skills — not only for young people, but also for the 50+, for the older generation, which often has a hard time in the labour markets, for the disabled, for all the people who need support. Modern social policy is also a modern tax policy when craftsmen pay their bills, pay their taxes and large corporations stay out of it. Prime Minister, the issue of unanimity in tax policy in the Council is one of the major problems, one of the major challenges. The fact that we are regrasping social policy means more common legislation in tax policy. Almost 9% of workers in Europe currently do not have enough to live, they are at risk of poverty — people who go to work. That is why every worker of what he earns must also be in Would be able to live. That is why either the social partners or the state, if necessary, must provide the appropriate framework. Finally, let me say that the biggest social issue for us Europeans is perhaps not even the internal European issue, but the global issue. Pope Francis once wrote in one of his first encyclicals that kills this economy that we have today. A very strong charge of what we currently have as an economic system. That is why, if we move into the future, we Europeans need to consider how this economy will evolve and how this economic model will evolve. I would advocate not only talking about tariffs or tariffs on trade issues in future, but also about minimum social standards for trade contracts. If we can ensure that European supermarkets no longer sell a product for which children had to work, then it would be a big deal for Europe. (Applause)

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: em nome do Grupo S&D. – Senhor Presidente, o nosso caloroso bem-vindo ao Primeiro-Ministro de Portugal: um primeiro-ministro com uma longa carreira europeia, na realidade um líder europeu, que, com o seu discurso, acaba de nos provar duas coisas: primeiro, que tem sido possível, em Portugal, mostrar que há uma alternativa progressista, centrada na resposta aos cidadãos, àquilo que pretendem e àquilo a que eles aspiram. Mas, com o seu discurso, também provou que tem uma visão ambiciosa e progressista para a nova fase do projeto europeu. Por isso, bem-vindo, em nome do Grupo S&D, o único grupo do Parlamento Europeu que incorpora delegações dos 28 Estados-Membros. In fact, the European Union is confronted with new challenges. In this polarised world we are surrounded by nationalistic tones, and we need to make sure that the European Union is asserting itself as a beacon of international cooperation and of a progressive agenda. We need European-scale action to respond to climate change, to set new trade agreements, to make sure that we respond properly to the digital revolution and to the migration and refugee crises. For this, yes, we need a European scale. But in order to respond properly, we need to ensure the unity of European citizens, and this unity can only be based on implementing the European Social Pillar in such a way that children, young people, women and men can comply with their new needs. What is happening with the Social Pillar is that, if you really want to implement it, we need also to count on a powerful social-fairness package, which was presented yesterday by the Commission. But we really want to implement it. But this is not enough, because if we want to sustain the welfare system, we also need to push for investment turned to the future, creating more and better jobs. And let me come with a powerful truth: this will only happen if we have the proper means, and the proper means will be (and you have referred to this) to have a budget turned to the future, to have a eurozone coming back to convergence, and financing this with new resources. The new resources should be based on tax fairness. We, the S&D Group, want to go to these new sources of taxation, and they must be based on whatever is producing added value and is not benefiting the European Union as a whole. This is the case with large-scale companies, the digital economy, financial transactions. So this is our expectation. Today in Parliament we will vote on the Parliament position on the European budget for the future, and we are pleased to count on clear support from the Portuguese Government. But let me tell you, since we know that Europe needs to connect with European citizens: we intend to launch a large-scale debate across Europe at all levels – local, national and European – to connect with citizens, to come with our proposals and to listen to them. We, the S&D Group, will deploy our instruments to provide these large debates, because we have a democratic deficit, and a democratic deficit can only be reduced with large debates and delivering in the direction of what citizens really need.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, on behalf of the ECR Group. Prime Minister Costa, I learned today that we agree that the EU and the euro system are not working very well at the moment. But I'm afraid this is where our similarities end. While the grand coalition of pro-Europeans here wants centralisation, common coffers and, in the end, the EU superstate, I believe that this path is wrong. Centralization damages ownership and creativity. Europe needs ownership and creativity, not only in the product markets. Unfortunately, we see that the market economy players are being burdened by an increasing number of regulations and, at the same time, more and more state industrial planning is being carried out from Brussels. Europe also needs political competition. That's why Brexit is not just a threat. He's also an opportunity because the British need to get creative to solve their problems. This creativity can be a positive example for us and thus benefit us all. It is important that Switzerland, which sits at the heart of Europe and is not a member of this EU, shows our citizens every day that we can achieve exceptionally good economic results without the EU and without the euro. For us in Germany, Switzerland is now even important because there are German-language media that have not submitted to the ubiquitous political correctness in our country and which draw a different picture of reality. Alternative facts may be verbally an invention from the United States, but we have had to endure them in our countries for a long time, for example on the subject of the euro or even on the subject of migration. It is good if we keep many different voices in Europe, which will also receive media competition against the supersist of the state media. As you hear, I've talked about competition three times. On competition in product markets, where Europe is not innovating enough. About competition to better political solutions where equality from Brussels covers ownership and creativity. And on competition for better information and media, where too many journalists still adapt to the prevailing mainstream. However, so-called pro-Europeans, who are doing more harm to our continent than they may be aware of, are coming under increasing pressure, as the elections in many countries have shown in recent months. And we are very pleased that resistance to this centralisation is forming in the EU under the leadership of the Netherlands, Denmark, Finland, Ireland, Sweden and the three Baltic States. This really encourages me. Prime Minister Costa! I am and always will be an incorrigible optimist. And I will be optimistic that reason will prevail in the end.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, last week, Prime Minister, it was in China, President Xi Jinping crowned himself emperor for life of that enormous continent. Also last week, it was Donald Trump who started an old-fashioned, but, I think, dangerous trade war. And also last week, Vladimir Putin gets away with murders of former Russian spies on European soil. I should say: welcome back to the future. Welcome to the new world order, a world order based on empires and no longer on nation states, on the 196 nation states we count. It is clear that, in such a world older, we have to look to one thing if we want to talk about a reform of Europe. What is our interest? How can we defend our interests in this new world order? And how can we defend also our security? Because in the future we will only count on ourselves in this new world order. In such a new world order, the key question is: are we ready now with the European Union? My answer to this is: no! We are not ready for the moment, and I give always the example of how the Americans reacted to the financial crisis, Prime Minister, and how we reacted to the financial crisis in 2008. They, in nine months, Democrats and Republicans, decided a three-stage rocket: cleaning up the banks – 400 billion TARP; an investment programme three times bigger than ours – 900 billion (they are the capitalists and we are the so-called Keynesians, but the opposite is true); and at the same time, a quantitative easing programme of 1.2 trillion. And we, after nine years, are still discussing the banking union inside the European Union. And we have still not cleaned up all our banks in Europe. And that’s not the only example; the example is also valuable for other fields. The real problem we have is that we are still not a real Union as our founding fathers wanted. We are still a confederation of nation states that is based on the unanimity rule. So what we need as reform – and you have indicated in a lot of your interventions – are three things. First of all, a European Defence Community. We are alone in the world of tomorrow, so we need to do that homework. We are spending 40% of American military expenditure and we are only capable of doing 10% of the operations of the American army. So there is a field where we need absolutely to create that community as fast as possible. My second point – you have indicated it and I agree completely with you: the new euro governance, a euro budget, a fiscal capacity. It is completely ridiculous to have a single currency and not behind that single currency a fiscal capacity and a full authority. It is not only with the Stability and Growth Pact that we can do the business. Finally, and that’s my third point (and here I’m in disagreement a little bit with you and with the tone of your intervention): we need also institutional reform, a renewed European democracy. We need, for example, a European Parliament that is not only responsible for the expenditure but also for the income, as in any normal European democracy. We need also, in my opinion (as I said already to President Juncker) not a Commission of 28. Let’s bring it back to a real European government of 12 or 15 people. And we need to get rid of the unanimity rule. Let’s be honest, also in matters of foreign policy. I give the example now of what is happening in Britain: this attack on European, on British soil. We have still no opinion of the European Union. Ms Mogherini is completely silent about it. Why? Because she needs, for example, 28 agreements before she can take a position on such a crucial issue. I think it’s time that we did this reform now. Why, Mr Prime Minister? We have a window of opportunity of two years to do so. After Brexit there was no Nexit, no Frexit, no Dexit, fortunately. But it’s not won. There could be a Frexit, a Dexit and a Nexit if, in the coming two years, we don’t succeed. And that’s your responsibility, and that’s our responsibility, and that’s in fact our common responsibility. So let’s do it now, in the coming two years.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Prime Minister, when you came to the head of the Portuguese government in 2015, the hardest of the crisis was behind your back, but your country was still far from getting out of the storm zone. You have demonstrated, on the one hand, that right-wing parties do not have a monopoly over the responsible management of public finances and, on the other hand, that responsible management was not necessarily antinomic with progress towards greater social justice. This is evidenced by the measures taken in favour of small incomes and the upgrading of public services. If only for that, you deserve all our encouragement. Likewise, we share your determined ambition for the European project, the only way — as you have said — for Europeans to face the challenges of this century. If the European Union wants to regain overwhelming support from its citizens, it must resolutely change course and turn its back — and you have done so — on the austerity obsession with putting the package on investment. But be careful, not any investment: all investments that promote the possibility for everyone to live a dignified life while respecting the physical and biological limits that nature imposes on us. From this point of view, Prime Minister, it cannot be said that Portugal is, at this stage, a leader in the ecological transition. The proof of this is the oil exploration off your coast or the intensive sardine fishing methods. We are convinced that it is crucial for Europe to be at the forefront of the ecological transition of the economy, not only to meet climate imperatives but to become a solution provider to the rest of the world. These investments must be made both from the private sector, of course, but also from the public sector, including at European level. Here too, we share your ambition for a robust and ambitious European budget, fueled in particular by own resources. You talk about taxation on digital platforms, you also talk about all forms of pollution taxation, and the tax on financial transactions belongs to this category. Let me conclude with a downside: I never understood how your coalition spontaneously joined in support of a trade treaty like CETA. These types of neoliberal-inspired trade treaties are totally contrary to your social justice policies in this country. If all the Social Democrats in this House had voted against it, CETA would now be dead and buried.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, Mr Costa, Portugal today is a beacon of hope for those who dream of another Europe, of a truly social Europe, and the achievements of the Portuguese progressive forces are there for anyone who wants to see them. After reversing some of the measures imposed by the troika, Portugal is not only growing at a good pace, but also reducing unemployment and inequality. Portugal is tangible proof that austerity policies exacerbated the 2008 economic crisis, rather than alleviated it. From Spain, we look with envy at the pact signed in Portugal between the Socialist Party and the progressive forces, and we wonder why socialists in Spain have preferred other avenues, letting the People's Party rule rather than understanding themselves with the forces of change. However, Mr Costa, we do not lose hope and we are confident that, sooner than later, the obstacles that prevent us from following the same path as you will will be cleared. The economic recovery of southern Europe needs a different European Union — as I said — at the height of its responsibilities, more concerned about the well-being of its peoples and less about the profits of large financial institutions. When we witnessed the process of European integration, Europe was synonymous with well-being and prosperity. Today, following the implementation of austerity policies and social cuts, that perception has changed greatly. Three major reforms may be the pillars for building a Union that puts the equality and security of our populations at the centre of its business: a tax for financial transactions, the restructuring of the debt of the countries of the South and the transformation of the European Central Bank into an institution at the service of the economy real. There is no doubt that an Iberian peninsula governed by progressive forces would be a formidable alliance to promote democratic transformation which the European Union needs. In these times of xenophobia and skepticism, hope for a future that leaves no one behind must be stoke.

name: Jiří PAYNE
text: for the EFDD Group. — Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, we are experiencing a period of immense instability. Everything changes, we have no idea what's coming in a few years. We don't know what Europe will look like and propaganda of all sorts is spreading in this uncertainty. On the one hand, it is the fundamentalists of the European and Europhile politicians who say that with the European Union we must remain for eternal times, that the European Union is the only institution in the history of mankind, that will last forever. That's an irresponsible policy because that situation is very precarious and we really can't predict what will be a few years from now. Similarly, propaganda from other politicians who say there is a need to leave the European Union immediately, preferably tomorrow, whatever it takes, even if collapse and disaster were to follow. This is also irresponsible politics. Both are fundamentalism of the same kind. Perhaps there are also people who benefit from staying in the European Union as long as subsidies come in. All these approaches are wrong because the duty of a politician is to properly evaluate the current situation and make decisions accordingly every day. We can't start from fundamentalist notions that we know what's right. It is in times of politics that is more important because there is no standing answer for us to rethink the situation. The European Commission has indicated that the Lisbon Treaty is ending in principle. It presented a White Paper on the future of Europe and presented several scenarios for what the project might look like next. It calls for discussions on these alternatives and it is clear that the likelihood of maintaining the Lisbon Treaty is very limited. This uncertainty is also deepened by the unclarified position of Russia, the unclarified situation of China, the situation in North Africa, the Middle East, migration, weakened NATO, which as a result of the policy of the European Union He's still losing his weight and authority, and that's putting all of us at risk. The murders of journalists, the murders of former spies are contributing to this, and in this precarious situation, calls for democracy to be strengthened increasingly. Citizens of European states feel that the decision is made about us without us, that they have no influence whatsoever on what takes place in Brussels or here. There are voices calling for a real alternative to replace the Lisbon Treaty with some democratic establishment. It's not about creating conflicts, we all want cooperation from European states, but based on completely different principles than what we see here today. We're really looking for a different path. Prime Minister, we have described one such alternative, and you have received it through your embassy in Prague. We would very much like you to read it and to start discussing real alternatives, not just how to preserve power in Brussels. All the good that the European Union does can be done without these institutions. And that's the alternative we should be talking about.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, there will be no future for Europe as we know it, because there is no past or future in Islam. Every reminder of a non-Islamic past will be destroyed, every possibility of a non-Islamic future will be killed. The future of Europe will be the Caliphate. But first, Europe will be torn apart by religious and ideological wars, and that is the warning we get from almost every ex—Muslim who dares to speak out, who dares to speak out. Because ex—Muslims are murdered everywhere. That is the future of Europe, unless European countries start a programme of de-Islamising now. (Murmurs of dissent) The EU is not useless. The EU is not just an obstacle to fight this terrible threat. No. The EU itself is the threat to the future of Europe. It embraced the globalist agenda of self—destruction of European culture and the agenda of replacing the European people by people from Islamic countries. It opened its borders and spent billions to invite millions of uneducated people from a backward culture that will launch Europe straight back into the Middle Ages. Islam means gender inequality, polygamy, child marriage, slavery and honour killings. It means death for unbelievers. It means absolute power to a political and religious elite. The future of Europe must be a future of revolt against the EU, against the globalist agenda, against Islamisation. It must be a future for our cultural heritage, for our national identity, for our national sovereignty, or there will be no future at all. Therefore, I welcome the victory of the eurosceptic parties in Italy. I welcome the stubborn resistance of Viktor Orbán, who fights the disruptive agenda at source. I welcome the courage of the Visegrad Group in fighting the madness of Merkel’s open-border policy. Patriots fight together for the future of Europe, for the future of our children, and we will prevail.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: You may not agree, Mr Bütikofer, let's go ahead with the debate. The word to Mr Epitideios.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Mr President, in two sentences: what the colleague just did amounted to hate speech. I want you to look into that. (Applause)

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President — welcome, Prime Minister — one of the many issues which the European Union will be concerned in the future is its relationship with Turkey. I will highlight this issue, because this is precisely the issue that the European Union has made a huge failure. Its inexplicably and intolerably tolerant attitude has seduced Turkey, which is behaving like a pirate state. It invades the territory of Syria undisturbed, violates the EEZ of Cyprus, arrests citizens of various countries (United States, Germany, Czech Republic) and in order to release them requires them to accept its unreasonable demands and its latest challenge is the arrest of two Greek soldiers, whom he imprisoned in the highest security prisons in Adrianople, in order to blackmail Greece, which is indifferent to Turkey's other threats. I would ask you to condemn this attitude unequivocally and to demand the immediate release of the two Greek military troops. However, this seemingly inexplicable behaviour by Turkey has an explanation. And this explanation lies in the fact that Turkey has signed agreements on the purchase of military equipment with various countries of the European Union. He recently signed 31 such agreements with Germany. With Italy since 2007, under the Prodi government, the delivery of EUR 1 billion of military material to Turkey has been approved. In 2016, under the Renci government, Magusta surrendered 51 offensive helicopters to Turkey, worth 134m euros. But Spain also has similar agreements with Turkey. It builds a landing vessel on behalf of Turkey and is likely to build or build a helicopter carrier or Juan Carlos type aircraft carrier. I shall conclude by saying that the European Union must leave these cynicisms and crocodile tears that it sheds over the violation of human rights in Turkey... (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Hon. Epitideios, Please conclude. If you speak beyond the time allotted to you, take time away from the speeches of your colleagues, so I think it is everyone's interest to have more space within this debate. Now the floor to Prime Minister Costa. I also ask him to be brief in answers, so that there can be as many interventions as possible. He understood Italian, too.

name: António COSTA
text: Prime Minister of Portugal — I will try to focus on three key issues so as not to consume too much time. Firstly, in fact, the great challenge facing the European Union today is for hope to overcome fears that undermine confidence in Europe's future. In that battle, it is absolutely essential that we focus on concrete responses to the citizens, because either the citizens believe that, in European policies and the decisions we take, they materialise and respond to their desires, or we will indeed feed exclusively those who are against Europe, the speech populist and those have a protectionist view towards the future. In order for Europe to be more effective, we must first of all consolidate what is the most important we have ever achieved and which is the basis on which we can build our future: Economic and Monetary Union. Secondly, we must provide the Union with the necessary means so that the Union can do what we ask the Union to do, and that does mean strengthening the Union's budget. This means that we must have a vision that fooses convergence, because convergence is the key in the European Union as a whole. Convergence must be present in everything. It is true, we need a new industrial policy, and Horizon 2020 or structured defence cooperation is, moreover, a good opportunity for us to develop this industrial policy. But this industrial policy must not be used to aggravate the asymmetries. On the contrary, it must also bear in mind this objective of convergence and make us all participate in this joint effort. Certainly, some of the economies are good competitors in submarine production. There are others who will certainly be excellent competitors in the production of textiles or technical footwear. If we can gather the capacities of each one, we will strengthen convergence and we will not be weakening cohesion and the convergence. For this new Europe, I do not believe we need an empire. We will not be China, we will not be Russia, and I believe that we do not want to be China or Russia. Each has its own history and our history is a history of states and nations. This history of nation states has proved, since the post-war, that it has been able to build the most original and creative political creation that humanity has ever produced, which is the European Union. This must be done with respect for identity, with the resources necessary for the Union to be effective. The delay in responding to the 2008 crisis and the sovereign debt crisis in 2011 was not because the Commission has 28 Commissioners. This delay was due to deep political division and that we failed to realise in time that we had structural problems in the euro area to which we needed to respond. Now that we have learned our lesson, we cannot waste any more time, and now that there is no crisis at the moment on the table, let us make the right decisions to prevent any new crisis from coming. What Europe needs is not to close itself to the world, nor is it to do ethnic cleansing within Europe. Europe is a continent of diversity, and that diversity has been a factor of wealth. I believe it was Mr Weber who invoked Vasco da Gama's trip to India and how it benefited Europe. I would even say that I must be the biggest beneficiary of this trip in this Chamber, since, from Indian origin, I might not be here if Vasco da Gama had not gone to India. What has distinguished Europe and gives strength to Europe is indeed that we are a community of values. First of all, a fundamental value, which is that of tolerance, that of the capacity for inclusion, without multicultural relativism, because, of course, there are human rights which, being fundamental rights, are not likely to be discussed either in the name of the place of origin or in the name of religion. Gender equality is a value and there is no religion or religious value that can weaken Europe's defence of gender equality. (Applause.) But that does not mean that we sacrifice these values, which are also the founding values of Europe. Finally, I would like to say to Mr Verhofstadt the following: perhaps it does not distinguish between us whether or not we need institutional changes. It distinguishes us what should be the starting point. What I say is this: starting by discussing institutional changes divides us, paralyzes us and prevents us from making the essential decisions. Let us start with what is essential. Can we move forward in defence with structured cooperation? Let's move forward. Can we move forward with strengthening budgetary capacity, creating budgetary capacity in the euro area? Let's move forward. Let us not start by discussing whether a finance minister is needed. Let us begin by discussing and realising what is essential: having a budgetary capacity for the euro area. Once we have the budgetary capacity of the euro area, then perhaps there we will draw the obvious and necessary conclusion that we need a finance minister and we need greater control by the European Parliament over the implementation of economic policy across the euro area as a whole. Let us not start at the end, let us start at the beginning, and the principle must be to respond and resolve the problems of the citizens. (Applause.)

name: Nuno MELO
text: I would like to begin by greeting him on his presence in the European Parliament. Because I have little time, so I'm gonna focus on the essentials. I ask you if you think, as you said in Portugal, that, with the release of European taxes, the Portuguese will not be taxed and, finally, if you think that they will be, perhaps, the Martians, who may I tell you. I ask you whether you really think that, in order to achieve a 1.2% increase in the financial allocation for the European Union budget — and we advocate that increase, even more, we are talking about EUR 380 million — you need more taxes if you do not get the taxes you already collect and pay in Portugal. I would like to remind the Prime Minister that, when he was ruling the centre-right, not long ago, before you, applying an austerity programme that the Socialists approved after ruining public accounts until 2011, the Prime Minister, in the opposition, accused this government of going beyond the troika. Today, the Prime Minister, from one seat — he is not Mr Tajani, he is nobody — wants three taxes to be released at once. I would like to tell the Prime Minister that the Prime Minister does not go beyond the troika. The Prime Minister is the troika without a troika. Govern better, manage your budget well and no longer tax the Portuguese, who already pay too many taxes, too many taxes.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, for many years you have been telling us that there was no alternative in Europe, that austerity policies, policies of cuts and the policies of suffering that have affected the most needy were the only possibility. His Government had shown that another Europe was possible. There has been a policy of balancing public accounts, also enabling social growth: raising pensions, raising the minimum wage, making a social policy aimed at those who need it most. That is the Europe we want to build. And yes, Mrs González, I will answer you: I too would like to see a government of progress in Spain. And if there is no left-wing government in Spain today, it's because its political party, Podemos, preferred to win the PSOE in elections rather than evict the People's Party from the government. European Social Democracy will continue to work because another Europe is possible and because we need to give hope to so many citizens who are waiting for us to act.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome Mr Costa. Mr Costa, citizens look at us as a Union where fundamental rights and freedoms are at the core, and where there is no place for authoritarianism. That is why so many are worried by what is going on in Spain and in Catalonia, your neighbours. For more than four months, elected politicians and civil society leaders have been in prison – in pre-trial detention – for their political activities. There are political prisoners in Spain, and so I am asking you: do we really accept that EU governments repress political dissent through arbitrary detention? The Spanish Government imposed direct rule on Catalonia and called regional elections. It is now clear that it just does not accept the results of these elections. So I am asking you: can we allow Member States to suspend democracy? The Taoiseach, your Irish counterpart, told us here that not repression, but dialogue, is the only way out. I couldn’t agree more. Do you agree as well?

name: Charles GOERENS
text: — Mr President, today we know that the most convinced Europeans live across the Channel. We have rarely seen so many Europeans disappointed with having to leave the European Union, and it is all the more comforting to hear the speech you have just given. We know that the weak links in European integration today are, unfortunately, the Member States, which are allergic to the slightest dose of solidarity. The leaders of these states thrive on the difficulties — to use your terms — and at the same time they have the nerve to accuse Europe of being unable to provide answers while stopping four irons when it comes to giving the same Europe the skills it would need to meet the expectations of their citizens. What can be done, from your point of view, to prevent this form — yes, I weigh my words — of cretinism from being such as to block any revision of the treaties? Are we going to wait until the lower budget and the institutional lesser get to join the ranks of those who want to move forward, or are you advocating — if this situation is to continue — of a two-speed Europe?

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: — As a Galician, I am thrilled to speak in our language in the European Parliament. First of all, I would like to congratulate the political forces that have opened the way for the Government of Portugal. A way of facing and responding to austerity and social problems. Secondly, I would like to draw your attention to a very serious European problem common to our peoples: the tragedy of the fires suffered by Portugal, Galicia and other European peoples. We'll never forget pictures like this. Never, Mr President, never! Climate change and the lack of prevention deserve a political response that must be coordinated in Europe to address recurrent and emerging capacity deficits, because fires have no borders. Portugal has requested to activate the civil protection mechanism of the European Union. Not Spain. What do you think of the need to strengthen the European civil protection mechanism so that it is more flexible, timely and with more financial and human resources and to coordinate the fight against fires with agricultural, environment and transport policy? I also want to remind you of transport policy.

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, with the decisive contribution of the Communists, with the struggle of the workers and the people, it has been possible to embark on a path of recovery and the conquest of rights and income in Portugal. The European Union - we have not forgotten this - has expressed its opposition and threats to this path from an early age. Let us face the reality: two decades of euro, against all the promises made, meant for Portugal economic stagnation, debt, deficits, dependence, divergence, backward. If the constraints and impositions of the European Union, and in particular those of the euro, undermine the possibility of responding to the country's problems, the solution is not to succumb to strengthening these constraints and turning back on the problems, the solution is to tackle these constraints and impositions in order to solve the problems. The solution is not only, albeit with new clothes, because it exists in the old promises and illusions that life has laid down, it is to boldly break with the bonds that hinder the sovereign development of the country and this is the best contribution that Portugal can make to the construction of a Europe of cooperation, peace and progress.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: — Mr President, supporters of federal Europe are less and less often invoking peace to justify their plan, and for good reason their beautiful European Union has managed to blur us with great powers such as Russia and the United States, with future former members, such as the United Kingdom, and even with current members, such as the Poland. Nor did they invoke prosperity, and it is clear why when we see the situation in Portugal, whose gross domestic product remains below that of 2008, after an austerity cure of unprecedented hardness. There remains only the joke argument about the cost of non-Europe, that is, the idea that everything would go worse if the Union did not exist. Open your eyes, ladies and gentlemen Eurocrats, your federal union has failed, the people reject it. If you want to save what can be and move towards a Europe of nations, read again the White Paper on the future of Europe and take inspiration from its scenarios that suggest more respect for the aspirations of peoples.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Hon. Gardini. Here is marked his request. Well, then, Mr Rangel.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: — Prime Minister, I welcome your pro-European speech in which we review ourselves. It is a pity that its coalition partners are totally anti-European. I would also like to say that you left here a novelty and an omission. The novelty is that, being all of us in favour of own resources, we are very clear that there is no increase in the tax burden on them as usual. You left the door open here for a major increase in the tax burden on taxpayer citizens. Second is the omission Mr. Lamberts here should know. Portugal has the lowest deficit ever, but it also has the lowest public investment ever. Health, public services, particularly road safety, civil protection, infrastructure, have been completely forgotten in recent years in order to achieve European targets, and so I leave this challenge and a very clear question to the Prime Minister, which is a constructive question, although the balance sheet of Portuguese public services over the last 2/3 years is, in fact, a very, very negative balance sheet. And my question is this: having now an opportunity to reprogramming European funds, is prepared to do so in a way that the prevention of fires and support for affected areas are highly privileged, because the tragedy of the fires which has no precedent in Portuguese history and does not has precedent in European history - it has certainly only been possible because there has been a great divestment over the years, but also in these means, and so are you prepared to do a reprogramming that takes into account precisely the care of these people and care for these regions? If you do, you'll have our applause.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, it was very pleased to hear that you emphasised very strongly the common European values, the need to uphold the common rule of law, democratic values and equality. I am very concerned that many Member States of the European Union are worrying about slipping away from these common values. I would like to ask how you will act at the summit to ensure that all Member States are committed to these values. You also stressed the need to restore confidence in the European Union. I think the most important thing here is that the Member States also stick to the agreed rules together and do the things that have been agreed together. Only then will we be able to restore mutual trust between citizens and Member States in the European Union. I agree that we need to increase joint investment, among other things, in common security. We must play a powerful role in international trade policy and meet the challenges of immigration together. However, it also requires us to be able to abandon some of the earlier objectives, because it is not realistic that we will be able to increase the budget so that all the new challenges will be absorbed at the same time while we are investing in these new areas.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, you have become, Mr Costa, a new hope for Europe with the demonstration that, in the face of 'austericism ', it was possible to grow and correct the inequalities that have generated so much Euroscepticism, and thus increasing populism throughout Europe. But I, today, will challenge you for another question. You said — and I share it — that we have a big challenge, which is the fight against climate change: to promote an energy transition based on renewable energies. His country has been an example: it was a country that, last May, was able to survive for four days with wind, solar and maritime energy. But I would ask you, Mr Costa, to join in the Council with those countries that want more ambition on renewable energies to bring the European Union's objectives into line with the Paris objectives in this area. Give us a hand in the Council to move from words to deeds.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Mr President! Prime Minister, I listened very carefully to your speech and was very impressed for long distances. I took two pages of long notes on the question of the future EU budget. On the issue of the multiannual financial framework, some net contributors have a different opinion. We do not believe that a focus on more safety or on high-quality agriculture that is small-scale must mean more money. However, I would like to focus my question on something you have said about European values that the values of peace and democracy — Europe as a community of values — have led Portugal to the European Union. I would like to ask you what is Portugal's position on South-West Europe and South-Eastern Europe, where the European Commission has presented a Commission strategy for the Western Balkans, what can be the future scenarios for Albania, Bosnia, Kosovo, Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia — the six Western Balkans — and how we can manage to: that the European values you have mentioned can also pave the way for the European Union for South-Eastern Europe, so that both sides can do their homework. Since the Member States have a decisive say in the Council, that is my question to you.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, today in this Parliament we are going to approve a proposal that is excellent for Portugal and is five stars also for the European Union, which is the next multiannual financial framework, the next funds, which defend precisely the principles of solidarity, convergence and territorial economic and social cohesion. But these principles cannot be upheld — they must be practiced. Solidarity has to be practiced and it is important that it is not associated with the saying “do not look at what I do, look at what I say”. So I ask you, with regard to the financial reprogramming that is going to be done for Portugal 2020: will you take money from the inland and the poorest regions, such as the North, to give to the richest? Or is it going to give shape to the principles you have defended here of solidarity and territorial cohesion and will it help the regions that need the most, the poorest regions such as the North, the Centre, the Alentejo and the regions also in difficulty, such as the outermost regions? It is the question that remains here so that you answer us solemnly and that the principles are also in line with practice.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, I must congratulate you for agreeing to come to the European House of Democracy to discuss the Union and the challenges it faces at the moment. I am delighted to hear today the Prime Minister of my country advocating, despite the political forces supporting his governance solution, greater cohesion and integration in such essential areas as the reform of economic and monetary union and new sources of Community funding. I am pleased, Prime Minister, to see you here today advocating a return to the values that founded the European Union. All this is contrary to his initial tendency, so critical of Europe, which, as I recall, he even called the Empire of Austerity and which was so pleased to the extreme left-wing parties supporting its executive. The Prime Minister spoke of European solidarity and I counter him with the lack of solidarity in Portugal, the result of continued divestment in the protection of our fellow citizens, which translates into a lack of solidarity with the old and the new and for those living inside, and who, unfortunately, is the norm and drama of a desertified and aged country. How do you intend to counter this? I will conclude by thanking you for the act of contrition that the Prime Minister has done here today.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Mr. Prime Minister... (responding to the statements in the Chamber)... sorry. Thank you. Mr. Prime Minister, you convinced me: you are pro-European. Here they are. I visited your country many times. You have a tourist country. For me it is clear: you are a pro-European. I have a few questions; I don't want to repeat what was asked here. Prime Minister, how do you see the future of the European Union from the point of view of citizens' trust? What kind of Europe can we have? Do you believe in the need to give up this split into two Europe: Schengen/non-Schengen? Do you believe in the importance of informing citizens so as not to be Eurosceptical citizens? Do you believe in the common vision of having a migration policy? For example, you haven't touched what your vision for migration is. Do you believe that cohesion policy also includes the development of tourism in Europe?

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Who wants to talk? One piece of information, though, before you intervene. It was respected in proportion, in the “catch-the-eye”, the proportion... sorry, the calculations I didn't do them, all services did the calculations based on the proportion of groups, based on group numbers. It's not my whim, so please honorable. This is the data, you can come and count and I tell you how many have been, so it was done based on proportion. On the basis of proportion there were four... ladies, we cannot have a debate on Portugal. Please honorable.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, indeed this should not be a debate between Portuguese in Portuguese.
