Nevertheless, we are really regretting that three Portuguese Members of the EPP Group and one Portuguese Member of the ALDE Group were given the floor, and not one Portuguese Member from the S&D Group. This is completely unbalanced, and you need to correct this.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Honourable, I reply very gladly to you. Hon. Zorrinho, a second, I answer you very gladly. The numbers — if you make me answer I tell you what happened because so at least you know what happened — the numbers are, for catch-the-eye participants, in proportion to the consistency of political groups, If there were no parliamentarians other than Portuguese in the Group of the European People's Party is not my responsibility, I had to have the Group of the European People's Party speak, so much so that I had given the word to Mr Gardini, who was registered to me and was not registered, I have limited myself to respecting the proportions that are there, but for me we can move forward, if you want to postpone the vote, for me we can make it possible to make it possible for me talk as well all the subscribers. I have no problem, I can stay here, if you want to vote at one, if you want, we can sit another hour sitting here debating. It's not my problem. Hon. Zorrinho, if you want to say anything, but Mr Costa will know how to defend himself, it's not like he has any problems.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: Mr President, we have indeed had a magnificent debate here on the future of Europe. In the way the times have been distributed, four Portuguese Members of the PPE have been given the floor, who unfortunately did not use this time to discuss the future of Europe, but to discuss Portugal's past, which nobody wants, that nobody remembers, and which nobody misses. I would like to ask my Prime Minister, greeting him for being here, how he sees the application of the key that are convergence policies in the fight against populism and protectionism and to give better living conditions to citizens, because that is truly the secret of governance in Portugal and that is truly the secret we can have in order to have a Europe with a more future.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The Prime Minister of your country has had as long as possible, during the course of his speech, to explain the work that the government does. He has spoken at length and now I give him the opportunity to answer all the questions, so I don't think he has any concerns, Prime Minister António Costa, to also respond to the criticisms that have come from parliamentarians from other countries. (End of “catch the eye” procedure) I give the floor to Prime Minister Costa, please.

name: António COSTA
text: Prime Minister of Portugal — Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking you for the many and varied questions and the words of encouragement regarding the continuation of a policy that has not only allowed us to turn the page of austerity, but has enabled us to achieve good results: good results in consolidating public finances, a deficit that was close to 1.1% last year, with the beginning of the reduction in public debt, while we had the biggest growth since the beginning of the century, we have an unemployment rate that has been falling steadily and is currently below 8%. Your words encourage us and strengthen our energy to continue the success and outcome of these policies. I would like to stress something important here. The change of policy has not only had economic relevance. It has also shown that within Europe we are not doomed to a single thought and there is the freedom to develop political alternatives. This is essential for strengthening democracy and citizens' confidence. If, today, Euroceticism in Portugal has lowered again, it is a great deal for the Portuguese to understand that it is possible to be in Europe in different ways. Mr João Ferreira raised a question which has to do with the difficulties that the euro poses for countries such as Portugal. We know, at least since monetary union in the United States, that monetary unions do not diminish asymmetries — on the contrary, they accentuate them. All the preparatory studies of the euro, from the McLaughlin report to the 1989 Delors Report, clearly stated that, in order for the euro to have an asymmetrical effect, the euro area had to be given budgetary capacity. Two years ago, some thought we could not get out of austerity without leaving the euro, and others felt that we could not be in the euro coming out of austerity. Today, we know that it is possible to be in the euro without austerity. But what we also know is that everyone who said that budgetary capacity was needed were right, are still right, and that is what I hope — is that there will actually be budgetary capacity. What is not possible is to come to each of our countries and say that we want more money from Europe and then say, at the same time, that we want to give Europe less money. Europe does not produce money on its own. Europe's money comes from Europeans and comes in one of two ways: either because the Member States increase transfers at the expense of their national taxes, or we increase the European Union's own resources through taxes on the whole European economy. Or we find the right balance between these two sources of funding. I want the next budget to be a more robust budget, and to do that, you must have more resources. So I am not afraid to say: Portugal is available to give more money to the European Union. But we also support that, in addition to the reinforcement that is done at the expense of Portuguese taxes, there are new resources at European level, which, incidentally, will only be effective if they exist at European level. Or will a country be able to effectively tax American digital multinationals if we do not manage to do so on a European scale? Are we going to be able to tax anti-environmental products better at European or national level? Are we or won't we definitely have the courage to approve the tax on financial transactions? We must have courage and tax, and this is the real speech we must make to our citizens. Migration: Schengen is a major acquis of our Union. It was Schengen that gave freedom of movement within the European Union. Twelve years ago, I was Minister of the Interior and I prepared, in the Portuguese Presidency, for the extension of Schengen to the then new Member States, and I am very proud of the awards I received, from Poland to the Czech Republic, for extending Schengen to the new Member States, giving back the freedom of movement that these peoples have not had for decades, because they were closed beyond the iron curtain. It is this heritage of freedom of movement that we must be able to defend and which we must be able to continue to assert. I am asked whether Europe should be built at two speeds or, as I prefer to put it, in variable geometry. No. As far as possible, we must continue to build Europe at 28 or 27, but we must respect the freedom of those who do not want to do what others want to do. There's no way we can stick together without respecting freedom. But the freedom of those who do not want to go further cannot limit the freedom of those who want to go faster. So long as this variable geometry is not exclusive or definitive and always keeps the door open to which anyone who wants to join — as is the case with the euro, as is the case with Schengen — there is no reason to remain paralysed, just because some do not want to walk at the same pace, and that freedom we must also respect. Energy is a key issue. In Portugal, we have already reached 60% of renewable energy production and 30% of renewable energy consumption. We are well aware that we have natural conditions that others do not. But if we are to share these natural conditions, it is essential that we no longer delay the process of energy interconnections. We need to connect the Iberian Peninsula to the centre of Europe, connect France, France to Germany, and the whole of Europe, so that the whole of Europe can benefit from the excess capacity to produce renewable energies which naturally exist in the Iberian Peninsula and which can hardly exist, for purely reasons natural, in other regions of Europe. I would like to end with two specific questions. First of all, regarding the fires. I would like to thank Mrs Miranda for speaking in a magnificent Portuguese inspired Galician — I cannot give back in Galician, I will pay you back in Portuguese — and tell you this: the fires are a tragedy and the steps that the European Commission has already put forward to improve the European Civil Protection Mechanism are important. The existence of a European reserve that complements the national responsibility of each Member State in order to be able to take place in a situation of tragedy is absolutely fundamental. But more important or important, at least, is that we can act on the causes of fires, and what we need is for the next common agricultural policy to take account of the need to adapt the forest in southern Europe to the new climatic conditions and to make a significant change in the our forest composition. We need less eucalyptus trees, we need less pine and we need more cork oaks, we need more oaks, we need more olive trees, we need to have trees that are resilient to fire and that are able to contribute to sustainable rural development. This change, agricultural policy must also contribute to making. (Applause.) The last question I want to answer is the question of Catalonia. The issue of Catalonia is an internal issue of the Kingdom of Spain, which must certainly be managed by dialogue, but with respect for the value of the rule of law, the Spanish Constitution and the sovereignty and unity of Spain. What we must do, those who are defenders of the rule of law, is always to defend the rule of law, whether it is the autonomy of the judiciary, or when the dignity of the human person is at stake, or when it comes to the sovereignty of the Spanish Constitution, which we must all respect as a democratic and legal state which is an integral part of this Union of ours. (Applause. The Assembly stands to applaud the speaker.)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The discussion is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ana GOMES
text: Portugal is at PESCO to build a Europe of Defence and Security in the face of threats of terrorism and hybrid war. To finance it - and other policies - we need more own resources for the EU budget, but also for the funds of the Member States. These resources have been unjustly evaded - not only via tax blackouts such as the one that Portugal suffered at the hands of the government more Troikist than the Troika - but by the tax dumping in which Member States rival each other, in a race to the bottom that exploits scandalously large multinationals, fortunes, criminal organizations (including terrorists), to the detriment of citizens and SMEs burdened with taxes and receiving in return less social state and worse state in general. The Netherlands, for example, serves as the main “tax haven” for companies based in Portugal. The Prime Minister has proposed to impose European taxes on financial transactions, polluting companies and digital platforms. Do you not think that revenue from these taxes can and should also be shared with national budgets? Do you not think it is crucial for the EU to move forward with tax harmonisation and move towards a coherent and effective fight against tax havens, both inside and outside the EU, globally?

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — (PT) We began in Portugal, with the struggle of workers and the people, a path of replenishment and conquest of rights and income. This path relied on the opposition and threats of the European Union, which would prefer to keep Portugal tied to the decline and impoverishment of PSD-CDS governance and the troika. When the constraints and impositions of the European Union and in particular those of the Euro prevent the response to the country's problems, the solution is not to bend the constraints (possibly even strengthened) and turn your back on problems, but to tackle these constraints and impositions to solve the problems. The solution is not to insist, with new clothes, on the old promises and illusions that life has brought to the ground, but to boldly break the bonds that hinder the sovereign development of the country. This is the best contribution that Portugal can make to a Europe of cooperation, progress and peace.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Following the death of Jens Nilsson, Parliament shall see the holiday of his seat from 13 March 2018, in accordance with Article 4 (1) and (6) of the Rules of Procedure. *****

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Mr President, in the previous debate with the Portuguese Prime Minister, in the initial speeches by the chairmen of various groups, these speeches have far exceeded the time set. The first intervention of our group fulfilled the time set. If time has to be taken out of catch the eye — and I believe that this is the procedure that is agreed, but which has not been followed — then we need to take the time out of the catch the eye of the groups that overtook time in their first speech. Our group, having fulfilled the time allotted to it in the first speech, was deprived of time in the 'catch the eye' debate, and that is not in accordance with the rules that have been laid down and we did not wish to fail to hold our firm protest here.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Hon. Ferreira, the spaces were given in proportion to all groups, I have been elastic with all groups, but your group does not think any other interventions would be required. Honourable, you can say no, but that is the situation. You may disagree, I respect your disagreement, but the accounts were done mathematically, they were done by services, so it's not up to me. It depends only on what is the situation in the House. The competent authorities of the Hellenic Republic have forwarded me a request for the waiver of Mr Georgios Kyrtsos's parliamentary immunity in order to initiate criminal proceedings against him before him to the court of first instance in Athens. In accordance with the Rules of Procedure, this request shall be forwarded to Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, which has jurisdiction in this matter.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Let's now proceed to the votes. Let's start with the guidelines on the future relationship between the EU and the UK.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: Mr President, I just wanted to clarify the vote we are going to take on the objection to the list of projects of common interest. I wanted to clarify the effect that this vote will have: if the objection goes forward — which I encourage this House — it will not mean that all the drafts on the list fall, including those you consider positive, but that the European Commission will have to present us a new version of the list with fewer gas projects and therefore also, more electrical projects, which is what we signatories have asked for in this objection.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you Benito Ziluaga for his speech, but we are now starting to vote on the guidelines on the future relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom. Your comment was about a subsequent vote than we are about to launch.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, with reference to Rule 190(4), we would like to postpone this vote. Before this vote, the ECON coordinators tried to get additional parliamentary control rights for our House in the nomination of ECB board members. Unfortunately, we have received a very disappointing answer from the Eurogroup today regarding our demands for more gender diversity and for more say from this House about who will become board members, and regarding the question of more competition and transparency in the selection process. We hope for your support in order to put pressure on the Council to get more parliamentary say over the nomination of board members. Therefore, we should vote to postpone this vote for the nomination. We have every legal right to wait a bit longer.  (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: This is a request for a part-session under Rule 190 of the Rules of Procedure. Under Rule 185 of the Rules of Procedure, there is an opportunity for one speaker to speak against.

name: Brian HAYES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, on behalf of our group, I would like to oppose the proposition that has been made that we should postpone this vote. And I’d like to set out the reasons why we should proceed with this vote and ask this House to confirm this nomination. If we do not proceed with this vote and give an opinion on the proposal that has come from the Council, it means that the Council will not be able to make the appointment and a vacancy will continue. A vacuum will establish itself within the ECB. And I don’t think any of us support that principle on the basis of the independence and the credibility of monetary policy within the ECB. I would remind colleagues on all sides that the ECB has already given an opinion on this matter. The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) has supported the nomination that is before this House today by a significant majority. We have had two hearings, one in camera and one public hearing, where the candidate has demonstrated an excellent understanding of monetary policy and also demonstrated a commitment to the European Union. So it is our view that we should proceed with the vote because, if this House wants to be taken seriously, we should jealously guard all of the procedures that we have. We have followed the letter of the law. While there can always be improvements, and especially on the question of agenda – and that is a matter for Member States to improve – we should proceed with this vote and do the right thing for the long-term viability of the euro project. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: — Ladies and Mr Giegold in particular! I have now taken the vote here and I was in a bit of a hurry. I usually take everyone to speak for the counterspeech. I was then told that there was a written prior notification of a counterspeech by Mrs Berès. Mr. Giegold, if you have no concern? Thank you very much.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, this is such an important moment for the rights of this European Parliament. I would like to correct my colleague Brian Hayes, because the vote in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs was not a broad support. If you count the number of abstentions and the number of votes against, they were equivalent to the vote in favour, so I do not think that Mr de Guindos had a very large majority in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. But I want to go beyond this stage of our debate because I know the importance to our institution of what is being played out. In accordance with the full powers and legitimacy of the European Central Bank, we must strengthen transparency, balance and the timetable for appointing the members of this institution beyond what is written in the letter of the Treaty. And it is for this reason that I extend a hand to the other groups so that together we continue this battle as a united institution vis-à-vis the Council, the Eurogroup and the European Council, so that we can obtain, on the basis of the six criteria we have defined in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, a improvement of the procedure, and I hope to have your support in that regard.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: — This closes voting time.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Dear colleagues, Now I will allow myself to ask some. Mr Caspary and Weber, Mrs Bearder, Mr Weidenholzer, Mrs in't Veld. Can you hurry up, please? Colleagues don't seem to hear that. The oral explanations of vote follow.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Mr President, Brexit will bring change in the European Union for both citizens and businesses. For us Bulgarians, as for all Europeans, it is important in a short time to reach an agreement that guarantees the rights of citizens so that all these hundreds of thousands of Europeans can live without worries about their future. Over the past decade, the commodity exchange between Britain and Bulgaria has doubled to 1.2 billion euros on an annual basis. Without a post-Brexit deal, Bulgarian exports to the UK, equivalent to €500 million, are under threat. It is in our interest to keep this economic link at least at today's levels. I am sure that other countries also look with concern on the development of trade and political relations with Britain. We must abandon the language of political accusations and look pragmatically at the future relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, with Ms Theresa May making it clear last week that the EU’s access to the single market will be reduced, a hardening of the Irish border becomes inevitable. The risk is that this would be a step backwards in the peace process. The Good Friday Agreement strengthened the relationship between communities in Northern Ireland, between north and south, and across the Irish Sea, between communities that had been torn apart by violence and conflict. The Agreement was made possible because both countries were in the Union. The philosophy of it was that when you strengthen one of the relations, you strengthen all of them. The risk now is that by damaging one we can damage them all.  I therefore plead with the negotiators to be careful negotiating the future of the relations. I understand that every side is out to get as much as possible in the negotiations, but if we lose the peace, then the eventual gains are worth nothing.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr. President, I'm going to take another approach. British electoral legislation does not allow foreign funding, and until we are certain that the results of the June 2016 referendum are legal, we cannot talk about a future relationship between the European Union and the UK. Why am I saying that? The US Senate detailed how Kremlin agents financed the Brexit campaign with hundreds of millions of dollars from money laundering. According to the conclusions of Deutsche Bank and the Metropolitan Police, between 2010 and 2014 there was a considerable infusion of Russian capital into the UK. The UK Election Commission began investigating businessman Arron Banks into the origin of funds that allowed him to avoid bankruptcy and finance Brexit. As such, we are not sure that this referendum was correct and the investigation into Russian funding must be carried out.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, I support this resolution as a blueprint for governing the future relations between the European Union and the UK after the UK’s withdrawal takes place. It is important to provide maximum certainty for our citizens and businesses as soon as possible. Thus, the resolution proposes setting up a well—defined governance framework for a comprehensive association and partnership. It highlights four main pillars for our future relationship, such as economic relations, foreign affairs, security and thematic cooperation. However, if the citizens’ rights issues must be resolved on the basis of mutual respect and reciprocity, the future cooperation in the fields of security and defence should be based – and I hope it will happen – on the realistic assessment of European security needs.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr President! First of all, I wanted to express my satisfaction with the acceptance of the suggestions made by the Committee on Culture, which I was pleased to represent. I will remind you that our postulate was to clearly define in these negotiations the relation to programs such as Erasmus+ among others. It seems to me that separating two elements — Erasmus+ programs dedicated to young people, but also teachers, from programs dedicated to science is a good move. As such, it was possible to vote for these solutions without question. Once again, I wanted to thank you for accepting the suggestions prepared by the Committee on Culture.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: — I voted in favour of this important resolution, as indicated by almost all major party groups in the European Parliament, which demonstrates that, in terms of EU interests, the EP remains the most in limiting the inevitable losses on both sides of Brexit. is a consistent and responsible actor. That is why I supported the negotiating goal and the EP Directive to regulate the future of EU-British relations preferably through a modern association agreement, even if the British side's negotiating position does not allow it. In my view, the resolution also helps the European Parliament, under close supervision of the negotiating process, to ensure that the future exit agreement has a balance of obligations and rights, to ensure the integrity of the Single Internal Market, and to ensure the EU's legal and political shaping decision-making autonomy.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: — Mr President, we are voting here for the last time on the adjustment of the European Union and the United Kingdom's interrelations following his departure from the European Union, and I feel at every vote that there will be a few underthrown demands in each report that we all know will be hard to accept for the other side, the UK. I'm asking, why is that? I don't want to be subject to some stihomam, but I'm starting to get the impression that the European Parliament is using this as part of a negotiating tactic or that it wants to blurb the situation before some eventual final by voting or that even, in the worst possible scenario, no deal is worth either. I would very much wish that there was a mutual sensitivity and that we would conceived and construct every report balanced enough that such suspicions could not arise.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, we’ve had strong support for the resolution today from Members of this Parliament – the resolution on what the future relationship between the United Kingdom and Europe would be. I very much welcome the fact that the situation in Ireland has been underlined again in this resolution: that there should be no hard border between the north and the south in Ireland, and that the Good Friday Agreement in all its forms would be protected. We are now approaching the 20th anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement: an Agreement that was ratified by an overwhelming majority of people, both the north and south of the island. It was supervised by Mr George Mitchell, US Envoy at the time, and indeed the European Union gave it its strong support and has continued to do that. I very much welcomed the comments by the President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, yesterday when he said Europe stands with Ireland on this issue, and I think that’s a very important statement, a very strong statement, and that situation needs to be protected as we move forward to the next phase of negotiations.

name: Ashley FOX
text: – Mr President, we welcome the acknowledgment of the importance of our relationship, our common values, our close connections and our historical links. We share the aspiration for a strong and effective partnership covering trade, foreign policy, internal security and areas of thematic cooperation, but we cannot support a resolution which ignores the parameters set out by our Prime Minister. To suggest that the best solution would be membership of the single market and customs union, to pay into the budget and to accept the jurisdiction of the ECJ is to call for EU membership in everything but name. That would mean undertaking all the obligations of EU membership but with no say, which would be neither democratic nor sustainable. Differences remain and tough talks lie ahead, but I believe there is nothing preventing us from reaching a unique and mutually beneficial agreement, reflecting the new rights and obligations, apart from the political will and a sense of pragmatism. It is overwhelmingly in the interests of both the UK and the EU27 to have a unique deal with the freest possible trade and the closest possible security relationship. Let’s make it happen.

name: Jiří PAYNE
text: — Mr President, the negotiations with the UK so far are based on the notion that the UK will pay for Brexit. But looking at the reciprocal trade statistics, it turns out that the continent will pay far more than the UK on Brexit. Our businesses on the Continent need a clear and predictable business environment. We urgently need to know the information on how this will play out with free trade. We urgently need assurances that a free trade deal with the UK will be struck. By negotiating, the European Commission is gambling our destinies and deepening the negative consequences of Brexit for all.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: — The European Union wants to punish the United Kingdom, while discouraging other countries from a possible exit. It imposes conditions that the British Government cannot accept. It would retain jurisdiction of the Court of Justice of the European Union even after its withdrawal. Donald Tusk would solve the problem of the Irish-Northern Ireland border by practically ripping Northern Ireland out of the UK. The EU expects the British to comply with common tax legislation even after they leave. It would prohibit the conclusion of contracts with other countries until the end of the transitional period. If the European Union does not take into account the fair interests of the British, the withdrawal will take place without agreement. And that would be the worst for both sides.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, thank you as usual on the swift and sure way in which you got us through this lengthy vote. The British problem, or from our perspective the European problem, is very simply stated. Right from the beginning we wanted to be in a common market, not a common government. Even as late as February 2016, if David Cameron had been able to come back with any significant retrieval of power, it is clear that he would have won the referendum. But faced with the choice, the other 27 or the Commission, or from whatever breakdown, it was clear that people would rather lose the second-largest financial contributor than set the precedent that powers could float back rather than just upwards. So we find ourselves now having to look for such a deal from the outside. I have to say, there were a lot of voices in this House that before the referendum used to argue for precisely that, particularly among my federalist friends who used to say we need to find associate status for the United Kingdom: in the market but outside everything else. I understand that people are affronted, that the referendum has jangled nerves, but surely that’s still the best outcome for both sides.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: — The high objectives of the European Union can only be achieved by guaranteeing sufficient funding and support for both traditional and new politicians. A solidarity, flexible and future-oriented budgetary policy of the European Union can give the necessary impetus to the competitiveness, innovation and job creation of our economies. Finally, the budget of the European Union must be linked to the elections to the European Parliament, that is, the five-year political cycle, rather than the 7-year biological cycle of Europeans. It is clear that the further economic convergence of Member States, the non-distortion of internal markets and the measurement and transparency of the results achieved must remain at the heart of the budgetary planning of the European Union. The multiannual budget of the European Union must be the basis for the implementation of the political ideas and ambitions of the European Union.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: “Yesterday, Commissioner Oettinger expressed satisfaction with achieving 90% compliance between the European Parliament and the Commission. But it's always worth paying attention to what falls within the areas of disparity, which is in those 10%. Fortunately, it turns out that these are not the most important issues. What is crucial and what connects Parliament to the Commission is, first of all, the agreement, for example, to increase the expenditure on defence, on the security of maintaining cohesion policies — a policy that is extremely important, because covering local governments of different levels, as well as to maintain such important programs like Erasmus+. This, of course, is a detail in the big budget of the European Union, whereas from the point of view of the younger generation, it is very important that we are betting on education, on innovation, on creativity. For this, I wanted to sincerely thank you, once again asking Commissioner Oettinger to also take care of these 10%, because while these are not key issues, they may, at certain times, be relevant.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, the next Multiannual Financial Framework will set the tone for our action after 2020, and I am sorry to say that we didn’t seize the opportunity to reform how the budget is voted. I believe the budget should no longer be voted by unanimity in the Council. Unanimity means very often unsustainable compromises where every Member State competes to get the biggest rebate or to pay less. The EU budget is not, it should not be, the Christmas tree which every single Member States is decorating in its own way. It should, in contrast, reflect the priorities for the Union as a whole and it should enable us to close the democratic deficit. That’s why I am sorry that we didn’t take this opportunity.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of the report on the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period after 2020. Appropriate financial resources must also be allocated to the political efforts of the European Union. Without this, we are risking the further expansion of the Eurosceptic polulist forces and, ultimately, the entire European project. Accordingly, I particularly supported the increase of the Union's own resources. I also underline the importance of financial efficacity. On the one hand, this can be achieved through programmes such as the so-called 'smart villages', which could have a positive impact on several areas at once through the main priorities of the multiannual financial framework. On the other hand, greater emphasis should be placed on the transparency of the use of EU funds, so as not to allow cases such as large scams committed by the Hungarian Government.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's position on the financial framework beyond 2020. It is already clear under the amendments we have voted on for a long time that negotiating a joint position must have been very complex. Finally, the proposal also includes a proposal to extend the planning period from seven years to five plus five, to ten years. That's the part that I personally don't fully agree with, because I believe that a seven-year period is optimal, we have good experience with it. On the other hand, I very much appreciate the fact that the European Parliament has supported an increase in Erasmus+, which is key for young people, supported an increase in security expenditure and supported ultimately also a ticket for young and over eighteen years of age, which is such a pilot programme for youth of the European Union. So I appreciate the work of colleagues on this report, which I could have supported.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I too am happy to support the proposals here today as we move forward into the next round of MFF. We know that, post Brexit, if we are at that point, the funding will be reduced considerably, by about 12 billion, and how we are going to fill that gap. I think it is important we look at this, and I know the Prime Minister of my own country when he was here recently said that Ireland would be willing to increase contributions to the European Fund, and that is important. As a Member of the Committee on Transport Committee and Tourism I had an opportunity to try and influence and put wording into the proposals here. I think transport infrastructure, particularly if we are trying to address or are trying to improve territorial cohesion and address the peripherality issue for some Member States – I was speaking particularly about Ireland, which post Brexit will be further isolated geographically, and we need to address cooperation with third countries in this whole area of transport infrastructure.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: Mr President, I support this proposal. Cohesion policies and the common agricultural policy are fundamental to an inclusive Europe promoting equal opportunities. Reducing its financial allocations could increase the feeling of disbelief in the Union, making room for the proliferation of outbreaks of anti-European populism. It is absolutely necessary to strengthen the budget of the European Union. The proposal to increase countries' contributions, to a percentage which I think is absolutely feasible, and of own resources must be the battle horse for those who want to continue consolidating the European Union. In the case of the outermost regions, which I represent, it is important to ensure support for vital economic sectors such as fisheries and agriculture. But also tourism, research and innovation are crucial if regions such as the Azores continue to converge economically and socially with the European Union. It is part of the maintenance and possible increase of POSEI and the creation of a POSEI Fisheries, which is essential to ensure the common fisheries policy in the region.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Mr President, today we are approaching a qualitative change in the way European budgets are implemented and implemented. At the same time, we are at a critical point: European citizenship is watching us in the hope that these changes will include people at the centre of policies, now that an alleged recovery is proclaimed by decree. This hope would only be answered if the new multiannual financial framework embraced and endorsed the principles of the social pillar, for example by budgeting a minimum income or budgeting gender and equality policies, rather than increasing defence and security items. This would be possible if the Union were to provide itself with a robust, progressive and fair collection and redistribution system. This would also be a credible and accepted framework if greater means of political and citizen control were adopted, a control exercised in a transparent manner. All this, unfortunately, has not been reflected in the proposal, despite partial measures and good intentions. That's why I voted against it.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, the financial framework of the European Union after 2020 will determine the role that the EU will play in the lives of citizens. It is therefore important to maintain the amount of current resources of the common budget in spite of the withdrawal of the United Kingdom. I think that the Member States must also realise that greater contribution is needed if we are to achieve results. Our most important common policies are the EU for citizens. If the importance of cohesion or agricultural policy is reduced, and the EU cannot bring about valuable measures in areas that are important for societies, what is left? Maintaining EU institutions in the eyes of citizens is of no value in itself, only if they can improve their lives through the right tools, so whether we are thinking about the digital economy, the catching up of underdeveloped areas or the production of food in Europe, the EU and Europeans we're talking about the future.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, I am aware that we are on a certain reimagining that there are plenty of challenges ahead. That is why I have supported financial stability, going forward, and at the same time I support cohesion policy for the long term, because it is a policy that helps our cohesion and should be that a real reflection of European politics as such. For me, it was important that the role of cohesion policy was maintained in this report, as such, that Erasmus was strengthened, which is a very good programme for the young, and that we remain able to respond to challenges like Brexit as well as new challenges that translate into the Budget. I evaluate the report as being balanced overall, and that's why I supported it.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr President! Above all, I want to point out that the effort to backfill the budget hole that arises after the UK exits is indeed relevant and deserves respect. On this occasion, however, it is worth noting the efforts made to reform this entire resource of revenue enjoyed by the European Union. What am I paying attention to? First of all, the recommendation to maintain current own resources and the gradual introduction of new resources, which could be based on three completely new elements: first of all, VAT receipts in revised form, part of corporate tax revenue, mint pension, that is, the income earned from the central bank originating primarily from the issuance of money, but also on financial transactions tax, digital sector taxation or environmental taxes. It is very important to note that own resources, i.e. 80% consisting of two basic elements, are crucial and for that respect those who have developed this document.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, somewhere between 14 to 19% of the EU budget will be lacking when Brexit happens. It is obvious that this gap will be closed partly by raising the Member States’ national contributions and partly by cutting some costs, but there is a risk that it will be difficult to close it completely. We therefore have to explore new possibilities to finance the Union, such as collecting revenues from the emission trading schemes. Getting own resources is also a possible way of solving the problem that occurs every year in the Council when  27 or 28 Heads of State fight over who will pay less and get a rebate. Getting own resources will strengthen the Union, increase its capacity and lessen the burden we put on our citizens.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, like my colleagues, I supported the draft report on reforming our own resources, also taking into account that we need to address the effects of Brexit. Another reason is a certain clarity in the budget financing system. We agree that it is necessary to simplify, make the revenue sides of the budget more clear, this is undoubtedly spot on. I did not agree, and thus did not vote, to introduce some proposals for environmental taxes or corporate tax share. These matters are not sufficiently debated and need to be considered even far better. On the other hand, I agreed to call for the European Commission to bring forward relevant VAT legislation and a proposal to reform its own resource based on VAT within the framework of of the upcoming legislative package.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, I support the proposed reform of the European Union system of own resources which, among other things, addresses the Brexit budget gap arising after the UK’s withdrawal. Currently, national contributions based on the GNI resource represent around 83% of overall EU revenue which, regrettably, results in the ‘fewer returns’ logic which hijacks budgetary discussions in the Council, as everybody knows exactly how much they have put in.  The new own resources system will significantly reduce national contributions by Member States and would use a basket approach, reinforcing EU policies with added value. I believe this proposal would not only lead to more transparency, but, as well, a better understanding of the Union’s budget to all our citizens.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, the European Union needs a stable financial environment. It is very regrettable that the enhanced cooperation on the financial transaction tax is shared only by 11 Member States. This tax could raise EUR 57 billion per year if implemented across the entire EU. This money could be dedicated to the personal and professional development of our citizens, resource the demographic revitalisation of our regions and substantially strengthen our social pillar. This report, which I voted in favour of, invites the Commission to elaborate a new own resource for the Union budget. This rhetoric is good; however, we need to be realistic, otherwise enhanced cooperation will remain our lowest common denominator. We need, first of all, to create real incentives for the Member States to share more in order to get even more in return. Without mutual trust in the financial sectors, we will not be able to go any further than the enhanced cooperation.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, if Brexit proves legal and unfunded by Russian money, it will leave a gap that must be covered without reducing the Union's resources and without affecting the financing of European projects. It is very important that we bring the money we already have, but it is stolen, and I mean fraud. I repeat, VAT fraud on European funds alone is EUR 5 billion a year. This money we can get back. It must also be a priority to combat customs fraud, to combat any kind of fraud. The budget must also have policies with European added value and link revenue with the objectives of the Union, in particular in the areas of the single market, energy, environment and transport. A human resource reform is also needed - the future of EU funding must not be left in the hands of corrupt people. That is why I propose that we introduce the rule: no penals in the European Parliament and no penals in the European institutions, so that we have a relationship of trust with citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, as I said during the debate, the Troika in Greece has imposed a tough tax policy through memoranda with a particularly high VAT rate. In particular, it has imposed legislation which abolished the preferential reduced value added tax regime applicable to the Aegean islands. The low value added tax helped the island's economic development due to their distance from mainland Greece but also because of the competition from Turkey, which has a particularly low VAT rate. Based on current current, Lesvos, Chios, Samos, Ikaria and Leros will also lose the right to reduced value added tax from July 1st 2018. These islands are affected by huge migratory flows, so the reduced value added tax should be maintained in Lesvos, Chios, Samos, Ikaria and Leros and at the same time the reduced value added tax should be reinstated for the Aegean islands.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination. I agree with its findings on investment and growth. In particular, the need for more investment in research, development and innovation and technological modernisation in order to increase productivity. Investments in childcare, social housing, education, training, health, research, digital innovation and the circular economy would definitely increase productivity and employment. On convergence and inclusion, I also share the opinion of the rapporteur, including in relation to the tax system and young people not in employment, education and training. With regard to the report, it is regrettably necessary to mention, however, that the Hungarian Government is acting in direct contrast to what it says, thereby jeopardising Hungary's autonomous economic growth and employment improvement.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, have we treated a sick person with expired drugs that have worsened his condition and we still want to go with the same recipe? This is what emerges from the report: we focus on budgetary constraints, the insufficient implementation of the rules of European governance and the failure to implement structural reforms of member countries. But no word is spent on the inadequacy of the austerity measures that have stifled European citizens and companies. At the same time, there are calls for further efforts and sacrifices for fiscal consolidation and structural reforms, but we do not push on social policies and measures to combat evasion and avoidance Fiscal, just as there are no references to corrective actions for the management of macroeconomic imbalances induced by excessive trade surplus, such as in Germany. Now, if erring is human, persevering is another thing, and I feel that it was absolutely necessary to impress another direction to political choices and abandon the path that brought part of the Europe. For these considerations, my vote was down.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, the Commission's economic forecast shows continued growth in a changing political context. This growth is expected to remain in both the euro area and the European Union, at 2.1% in 2018 and 1.9% growth in 2019. The 2018 European Semester cycle involves harmonising European taxation and combating tax evasion. The Union's budgets must provide an incentive for sustainable growth, convergence, inclusion, so that we can create better working and living conditions for the citizens of the Union. It is also very important that we invest in research and innovation, because only so comes progress and leads to change and forward of the European Union and of each individual state, and this in all areas.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on the implementation of the European Semester. This report puts more emphasis on employment and social criteria. I consider the annual growth analysis to be a very important tool that provides Member States with important feedback on what areas to focus on and what reforms they are to implement. There is a need for more flexibility for working time and not to repudiate even typical forms of employment if we really want to help towards greater employment. These forms also allow employees to align work responsibilities with others. However, even these employees deserve sufficient social protection. Therefore, one of the biggest challenges of reform will always be finding a balance between flexibility and social protection. But education remains the most important tool for growth, and, of course, in digital technology, where there is not enough employee education.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are almost 19 million people out of work in Europe, with unemployment peaks of utterly worrying. Moreover, the figure of 119 million Europeans at risk of poverty and social exclusion is completely unacceptable. The fragmentation of the labour market, the precarious contractual forms, without protection, ends in themselves and completely unnecessary for a future employment path, and still the presence, not only in Italy, of The phenomenon of the caporalate, impose effective and long-lasting measures on the European Union and the governments of the Member States. I appreciate the fact that there is a greater focus on social aspects in the report, and therefore points to adequate social protection through minimum income or an unemployment benefit scheme . Unfortunately, however, there are also critical issues, starting from the supposed need for further structural reforms, to the continuation of the cage of the Stability and Growth Pact, up to the rise of age retireable. In this very regard, we had to vote “less”.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the European Semester reduces the national sovereignty of the Member States. In essence, it is a tool for controlling the economic policies of the States and, at the same time, a tool for enforcing the Stability Pact. It is assumed that the Member States have full powers in the field of employment and in the field of social policy. This is also provided for by the principle of donors of powers laid down in the Treaty and also by the principle of subsidiarity. At the same time, therefore, by intervening, the European Union does not institutionalise either a minimum European salary, a minimum European income or a minimum unemployment benefit, and of course the regulations it imposes with the European Semester neither deal with unemployment nor reduce social exclusion or bring about social justice. They keep precarious jobs. It's a failed policy.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: This closes the explanations of vote.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the topical debate (Rule 153a) on international cooperation in the fight against cybercrime – the threat to public services (2018/2627(RSP)).

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Author. — (NL) Mr President, the Internet has become almost indispensable in almost every aspect of our lives. We send a WhatsApp message to a loved one, plan a route through Google Maps, watch cat videos on YouTube, make online purchases and payments. Critical infrastructure, such as hospitals, can no longer function without the Internet. Just look at Eurocontrol: the communication of our European air traffic control uses the same Internet cables as Facebook and Amazon. But that internet is also used for less cheerful things. Almost daily there are incidents that provide dust for a good film scenario. Recently, for example, hackers remotely locked the electronic locks of all rooms of an Austrian hotel in exchange for ransom. We will increasingly be confronted with all kinds of cybercrime. Unfortunately, sometimes foreign authorities are also involved. We're much more vulnerable than we think. That is why national and European authorities must work together to ensure our safety online for today, but also for tomorrow. We need to invest much more in prevention, detection and response. We have already strengthened our legal framework. The new data protection regulation will increase data protection standards. The Commission's proposal on EU certification for safe ICT products is also included. We prefer to pursue a high and international security standard across the board. However, we will not come up with legislation alone, because it cannot always keep up with the rapid technological developments. Europol, the European Police Cooperation Agency, will soon have a Centre of Expertise for Decryption. That's good news. This should support smaller Member States in cracking encrypted messages. It allows them to track down cybercriminals who try to remain anonymous faster and to address. To do this, they will receive EUR 5 million in additional funds from the European Commission. The new Europol boss Catherine De Bolle already stated that the fight against crime and terrorism cannot be seen in isolation from the development and use of new technology. National authorities must also realise that old-fashioned police work must go hand in hand with the embrace of technological innovation. That concern also applies to justice. While criminals use the very latest gadgets, police and justice are often dependent on pursuing with dated material. But we also need to look at the citizens. Governments need to raise awareness of the risks posed by the Internet, so that they are more alerted to various forms of cybercrime. They should also be encouraged to always file a complaint if they become victims of cyber bullying, fishing or hacking, for example. That happens far too little, but without that notification the police cannot act. Notifications are therefore needed to better understand cybercrime, so that we can address them more specifically. Finally, I would like to point out that data is a valuable asset not only for the private user who wishes to protect them, but also for the police forces. Our police and intelligence services need access to data to detect crimes and detect terrorist conspiracies on time. A too dogmatic view on privacy prevents the police and the courts from doing their job. That is what I learned during my work as co-rapporteur in the Special Committee on Terrorism. Colleagues, in the interests of our citizens, we need to strike a good balance between privacy and security. It's not an or—or discussion, it's an and—and discussion. Both privacy and security are important. Police forces must be able to do their job, protecting us from terrorists and criminals, both offline and online.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, in 2017, internet access reached 51% of the world’s population. Devices connected to the internet reach 8.4 billion worldwide. With the number of targets expanding at such rates, cybercrime is likely to become the world’s number one threat, capable of causing serious economic damage estimated at no less than USD 6 trillion over the next two years alone.  Cybercrime and the criminal use of the internet violate privacy and human rights. They jeopardise the integrity of our data, attack the security of our critical infrastructures and seek to disrupt the provision of services vital for our security and economy. These are serious threats and they require our full and immediate attention. Already in 2013, the first EU Cybersecurity Strategy prioritised the fight against cybercrime. Since then, we have been constantly expanding the efforts we make to improve our resilience and our preparedness to counter these threats, so that citizens and businesses can fully enjoy the benefits of cyberspace. Allow me to briefly outline some of the efforts which demonstrate the prominent place that the matter occupies on our political agenda. The ambitious Cybersecurity Package presented by the Commission on 13 September 2017 was followed by a set of Council conclusions and an action plan for their implementation. They emphasise the need to enhance the EU’s capacity to prevent, deter and respond to cyber—attacks. In this regard, they encourage the exchange of best practices, investment in cybersecurity training, awareness raising and cyber hygiene. As part of this package, the Council has also started examining the proposal for a Cybersecurity Act that addresses the need for a strong and permanent mandate for ENISA, referred to as the EU Cybersecurity Agency, and for enhancing the EU cybersecurity certification to promote the availability of secure products and services. We are happy that the work on this file is progressing steadily in parallel with the work in Parliament. We are confident that the constructive dialogue will allow a swift closing of the negotiations and the timely adoption of the act. I would also like to recall that in September last year, the very first Digital Summit took place in Tallinn, allowing our political leaders to give strategic directions for future work in the digital domain. They confirmed the strong commitment of the European Union to fight cybercrime and the criminal use of the internet. This is part of the overall aim of making Europe a global leader in cybersecurity by 2025, in order to ensure the trust, confidence and protection of our citizens and businesses online. Thus, it is not surprising that discussion has concentrated on the need to achieve the highest level of resilience for digital infrastructure, industries and services, to create a competitive advantage and to attract investment. This was further developed by the October 2017 European Council, which placed combating terrorism and online crime among the prerequisites for successfully building a digital Europe together with a common approach to cybersecurity. I do not want to prolong my intervention, so I will limit myself to mentioning a number of other relevant initiatives including the EU Internal Security Strategy 2015—2020, which also prioritised the prevention of and fight against cybercrime as one of the three priorities of EU internal security. Secondly, the EU Policy Cycle, which is aimed at tackling the most important threats to the EU posed by organised and serious international crime, including cybercrime. I could also mention cyber dialogues between the European Union and key international partners, as well as cyber diplomacy on which the Council adopted conclusions in June 2017 towards a joint EU diplomatic response to malicious cyber activities. Very positive news is that, on 9 March 2018, Ministers reached a general approach in the Council on the directive on combating fraud and counterfeiting of non-cash means of payment. The Directive aims to update the current rules to ensure that a clear robust and technology-neutral legal framework is in place. It also eliminates operational obstacles that hamper investigations and prosecutions and provides for actions to enhance public awareness of techniques such as phishing or skimming. Trilogues are now ready to start as soon as you have your mandate from Parliament’s side.  Finally, let me conclude by briefly mentioning that in May this year, we expect Member States to finalise the transposition of the 2016 NIS Directive. It is the first legislative act that seeks to achieve a high common level of security of network in the information systems within the European Union and to improve the functioning of the internal market by creating trust. Let us keep in mind that strong and trusted encryption is of high importance, not only for establishing and maintaining such trust, but also for assuring respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. Their protection, including in cyberspace, is our paramount task and joint responsibility.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as we have heard, today it is not just computers and phones that are connected, but our homes, hospitals, governments, electricity grids, the news we read and the cars we drive. So we have to take cyber-attacks against our systems very seriously. They can have a huge economic impact. We have heard some of the examples. Bank and credit card fraud in the eurozone alone amounts to some EUR 1.5 billion a year. Every month, one in five industrial computers are attacked. Aviation systems are subject to an average of 1 000 cyber-attacks a month. But the threat continues to evolve and change. It is becoming more strategic. Cyber means have been used to undermine democratic institutions, to spread disinformation and to cast questions over elections. The internet of things means that tens of billions more devices are going online. This will inevitably create a huge number of extra potential vulnerabilities, and at the same time potential new tools to perform cyber-attacks. So what from the Commission side are we proposing to do about this? First of all, we continue to support Member States in the implementation of the NIS Directive, as we have heard, ahead of the transposition deadline in May. This will ensure operators of essential systems assess risk, prepare a strategy, and properly protect their systems. Some Member States are also extending these measures beyond the critical sectors already set out in legislation to other sectors at risk, in particular public administrations. The NIS Directive will also boost national capabilities and competence to promote the exchange of information about threats and incidents. In parallel, we are continue the implementation of the action set out in the cybersecurity package presented last September, based around strengthening resilience, creating effective deterrents and reinforcing international cooperation. The Cyber Security Act, which this House and the Council are currently discussing, focuses on making us more resilient. It aims at giving ENISA a permanent mandate and it is setting up an EU-wide framework for cybersecurity certification systems, again as we have heard. From the Commission side, we are convinced that a European certification process is an important step towards creating security by design. The Commission, the European Parliament and the Council have agreed that this is a priority file and it is of paramount importance that negotiations are concluded within the current mandate of Parliament. Making us more resilient also means making sure the EU retains and develops essential capabilities to secure its digital economy infrastructure and society and democracy. To this end, we have announced the creation of a network of European cybersecurity competence centres to reinforce capabilities across Europe and overcome the current fragmentation of research, with the cybersecurity research and competence hub at the heart of that. The network should bring together research and expertise in cybersecurity from across the European Union and lead to the scaling-up of existing research and technological capacities in the competence centres in Member States, while making sure that research is transformed into specific products and services that will directly increase our cybersecurity. On 1 February, the Commission launched a call for proposals for a EUR 50 million pilot project to support the creation of this network, an important step in its development. However, as we stressed in our joint communication last September, it is crucial to complement our efforts to build resilience with efforts to build effective deterrents. We need to make sure that cybercrime does not pay. That means making it easier to detect and easier to prosecute. As long as there is little or no chance of getting caught, cybercrime will remain an all-too-attractive option for criminals and hostile governments alike. We have already proposed a directive to strengthen the ability of law enforcement authorities to combat fraud and the counterfeiting of non-cash means of payment. To tackle barriers to prosecution, we are also working on a legislative proposal on obtaining electronic evidence for criminal investigations and prosecutions. Over the last two years we have carried out an extensive consultation process and conducted an impact assessment. This issue is complex and requires a carefully balanced approach, having an efficient instrument from law-enforcement point of view, while ensuring full respect for fundamental rights, data protection and ensuring legal certainty for business. I am confident that we will soon present a solid legislative proposal for consideration by the co-legislators. In parallel, we are advancing work on our practical measures to simplify cooperation between judicial authorities and cooperation between our law-enforcement authorities and service providers, based on the existing legal framework. This includes cooperation inside the European Union and with our key international partners, notably the United States. The Commission also actively participates in the ongoing preparatory work in the Council of Europe on the possible additional protocol to the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime, which will deal with cross-border access to e—evidence. On the side of operational efforts that have been underlined, we are beefing up capacity at Europol’s Cybercrime Centre. Law-enforcement capacities need to keep pace with fast-changing technological tools and cybercriminals’ ways of working. This means more cooperation and sharing of experience and reinforced cyber-forensics and detection capabilities. A strong cooperation framework with external partners is of the utmost importance, given the global nature of the threat. The Europol Cyber-crime centre provides technical and forensic support to a number of international investigations which have led, for instance, to the take-down last summer of two of the largest criminal dark web markets. Aside from making ourselves more resilient and building more deterrents, we need stronger international cooperation to make cyberspace stable and secure. This is why the cybersecurity package has an important international dimension. In order to shape this international cooperation, the EU has ongoing cyber-dialogues in place with the United States, Japan, India, South Korea, China and Brazil. Through these cyber-dialogues, the EU promotes the application of existing international law, the implementation of universal norms of responsible state behaviour, and regional cyber-confidence-building measures, as well as the international cooperation through the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime. The dialogues allow for the enhancement of cooperation with third countries to strengthen global cyber-resilience and the multi-stakeholder model of internet governance, as well as to advance the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. They contribute to global cyber-stability, including through the exchange on responses to malicious cyber-activities that should encourage cooperation, facilitate mitigation of immediate and longer-term threats, and influence the behaviour of potential aggressors. On all these proposals my colleagues and I are actively working with you for the speedy adoption and implementation of initiatives on the ground, and look forward to continuing this fruitful cooperation, to the benefit of all our citizens.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, let me start by thanking you, Commissioner, for your work on this issue. You will find us as a strong partner to continue to work forward on such an important subject, because the spike that we witnessed in online crimes over the last years should concern us all. Cybercrime and criminals have become more organised, more brazen and more serious. They are using the very tools that we have created to make people’s lives easier against us. We have seen computer systems that we thought impregnable hacked. We have seen the spread of government-controlled social media trolls blur the lines between propaganda and views. There are still too many credit cards and identities stolen and far too many children remain exploited. Tools created for the good of mankind, and which are largely used for good, are being abused, and we must respond by closing the loopholes. With the increasing number, nature and gravity of cybercrime, with the increasing prevalence of the dark net, we need more and better coordination between Member States at international level, as well as with the private sector, to protect EU citizens, companies and our critical infrastructure. We need to ensure that our law enforcement authorities are provided with the necessary tools, resources and staff in order to effectively investigate and prosecute cybercrimes, and that this is done in full respect of fundamental rights and privacy expectations. From here, let me call on the Member States which have not yet done so, to ratify the Council of Europe Convention on Cybercrime – as we call it, the Budapest Convention. We have to work together and, of course, we need Europol, CEPOL, Eurojust and ENISA to be granted sufficient resources and tools in order to allow them to build the necessary capabilities to cope with the increasing workload and to continue their valuable work in the area of cybercrime. Finally, together I know that we can find the solutions that keep people and companies secure online and respect citizens’ privacy, and go after the criminals who think that they can mask their identities. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, first let me congratulate the initiators of this discussion, our colleagues from the ECR. Really much needed discussion at the right time. The right time is because the European Commission has tabled its proposals, especially with regard to the mandate of ENISA, the European Cyber Security Agency. It is ambitious, it makes this mandate permanent. On the other hand, I would say a lot more could be asked for. I am very impressed that we are almost in the paradoxical situation in which Member States that are first in their cybersecurity are preventing the European Cyber Security Agency from being stronger. We have Member States that have their offices with 600, some with 1000 employees in this area. At the same time, the European Cyber Security Agency has 50 people, and with this proposal to double the budget, I suppose the most can reach 100 people as capacity. On the other hand, who else could organise the response at European level when there is an attack, a cyberattack on more Member States? Who, Commissioner, is currently responsible if we have a “Wan'a cry” attack on twenty Member States? Or we will let each country solve it individually and be rescued individually. We currently have individual Member States that have well-developed structures, and there are other Member States that do not put serious attention at all on organising their cyber services. The next question that stands is the question of standardisation: will European countries be able to agree to have their own certificate based on serious international standards, and whether this certificate will be so well opened that it can be enjoyed not only in the European Union, but also among our partners in the United States, India and other countries.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, the gradual increase in the popularity of digital currencies has led to an increase in cybercrime, because it gives hackers control of these virtual accounts. I would like to refer to one specific aspect: Bitcoin and OneCoin. Bitcoin is one of those alleged digital currencies, which actually does not exist, which is not registered with any competent authority, which is promoted by its founders as a digital currency that will enrich investors over time, but there is no evidence of the money coverage of this currency Virtual. Bitcoin can not be used, because no payments can be made and is just a speculation tool. A Ponzi scheme used by companies such as OneLife Network Ltd, headquartered in Belize offshore jurisdiction. If we look at the site, we see it's temporarily closed. Now OneCoin is the regional Bitcoin and is a currency, too, which does not exist. There are, for example, regional in Moldova, Bulgaria and Romania - investigations are being carried out. It is sold by a criminal network, which operates on a pyramidal system and which is called OneLife.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, the Internet offers us both beautiful and numerous opportunities in everyday life, but at the same time violent and new threats, and in particular the major threat of cybercrime. Cybercrime is multiplying — colleagues have recalled — and in very large numbers. This affects us all, in public services. I am thinking of the attack on WannaCry, which was an example that mobilized us and which is therefore to be followed when it comes to protection. There are no borders for cybercrime. What is our role? Firstly, in the face of the Member States, perhaps ask them to implement the European data protection framework very quickly. This will allow us to restore the confidence of citizens. Secondly, to raise awareness among citizens about small gestures, but also to the awareness of the importance of protecting themselves on the internet and protecting the Internet of Things through so-called cyber-resilience and, thirdly, to provide judicial and law enforcement authorities with sufficient economic and human resources and capacity to protect themselves on the Internet of Things. effectively combat this threat, notably through Europol's European Centre for Combating Cybercrime. In this respect, Commissioner, I welcome the Cybersecurity package presented by the Commission. It is also necessary to reform the ENISA agency, as you said, to establish a strong cyber defence agency in Europe and, finally, to protect our infrastructures, networks and content. In this regard, the role of enterprises is major. Alone, we cannot act solely at the public level. Companies need to build secure objects, assess, secure, understand vulnerabilities that threaten products or services, and also systematically report cyber attacks. It is also crucial to work on encryption — i know this is a sensitive theme — in building the tools to ensure the security and integrity of networks while respecting freedoms. Let's go louder and faster together!

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: Mr President, Commissioner King, President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen. This is not the first time we are discussing cybercrime and cybersecurity. The debate has been going on for some time, and we have adopted many resolutions in this House with a whole range of requirements. We have also put in place many laws that are important and which are making great progress. Nevertheless, in the recent past and all the time, even well-protected networks of government institutions and authorities are constantly being hacked, and it is quite obvious that we have a huge backlog. I would just like to briefly summarise ten demands, where I believe that we really have to do something at last. Firstly, as part of the ENISA reform, the common regulation on a cybersecurity act, we need mandatory minimum requirements for IT products. Every year on the European market, we get a whole load of products that do not meet the minimum level of safety standards at all. We do not have such mandatory standards. This has to change! We need liability. If gaps are not closed at all, it must be clear that there is also liability for the companies that put such gaps on the market. There must be no government-sponsored uncertainty. Our authorities cannot buy up vulnerabilities to exploit them, but it does not conceal gaps and thus prevent the infrastructure from being improved. A secure infrastructure comes first. We have to open up gaps rather than conceal it, and it does not always have to go to the Internet. I believe that when we evolve technology, we need to think very much about whether you really need to connect everything to the Internet at all times, or whether there are also opportunities to prefer separations. In addition we need to make products verifiable. We need recruitment professionals who are affordable. These are the points that we definitely need to address. We need a cyber strategy that also significantly revises the network competence of the police and the judiciary. We need open, auditable standards that our regulators can verify. It is scandalous that many authorities do not even know what is happening in the systems on their computers.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, terms such as hacker and cybernetics are used daily nowadays. States are soaring each other from invading different Internet servers or influencing elections. Some experts are talking about the so-called Cold Cyber War. That cyber attacks are steadily increasing, and most likely further will, is the reality. The question is whether they can be prepared effectively, or prevented. The international exchange of experience on this field is quite crucial. But the issue of cybersecurity is complex. The internet is a living organism that finds its way, and I fear it will always be a step ahead of us politicians. Rules need to be set balanced so as not to infringe on citizens' fundamental rights, such as freedom of speech. But we can't concede the liquidation of Internet freedom and the deliberate spying of citizens. Regulation is not the same thing as censorship. There is a huge task ahead, at the end of which must be increasing the security of our citizens.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, smart Internet criminals regularly hack equipment and such a hack often has major consequences.
