The Dutch House therefore asked the Dutch government last year to improve the security of the Internet of Things. I immediately asked the European Commission whether such a one-sided but sensible measure could be taken in this way. And: that doesn't surprise you, so you can't. It must be European. As a measure against hacking, the Commission wants more censorship on internet platforms and another European agency full of civil servants. This, Mr President, is at the feet of Brussels. It does not matter how costly or how bad a solution is, as long as it is European. Mr President, it is unfair that Member States cannot take independent measures. In this area too, Member States can act better, faster and more alerted than Brussels. Perhaps we can still maintain some internet freedom.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, at the beginning of the 21st century, another one was added to the threats that existed until then in the various states: cyber attacks. Although there is generally no universally accepted definition of cyberspace, it can be said that it consists of the set of computers, networks, the Internet, facilities and telecommunications capabilities of a state. Cyber threats are attacks aimed at destroying or causing problems in the operation of the aforementioned media. Because the potential on the Internet is very large, many countries regard cyber war as a threat to their own existence and therefore have it integrated into their strategic priorities. In order to be able to meet these requirements, states must ensure that cyber defence services cooperate with each other, exchange information and, above all, do exercises to gain the necessary experience to deal with problem.

name: Emil RADEV
text: — Mr President, information and communication technologies provide not only opportunities for the development of society and the economy, but also challenges to European and international security. According to a number of analyses, the next security crisis will be caused by the use of new technologies as a weapon against critical infrastructure or even for military purposes, and is supposed to result in huge economic and social damage. I am not only talking here about cyberattacks sponsored by certain countries, but about attacks even by individuals who have the skills to do harm. This requires strengthening international cooperation in order to overcome the effects of cybercrime, cyber attacks, electronic espionage and others. Regional initiatives and measures such as Europol's cyber centre, together with technology companies, should deepen the debate within the UN on establishing an international code of conduct for countries in cyberspace, as well as coordinate efforts in preventing and investigating cyberattacks, including through the exchange of information. In this context, it is extremely important that as many countries as possible, not just from Europe, join and ratify the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime. And why not even start work on a UN convention on the fight against cybercrime. It's time to understand that cybercrime is a reality! They also require real countermeasures.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the growing opportunities for connection and dissemination of information, the increasing use of digital products and services and the Internet of things have a positive impact on every aspect of our daily lives. On the other hand, they also expose new dangers and increase the vulnerability of public services, because they can cross borders and borders. The subtraction of sensitive data, increasing cases of payment fraud, the dissemination of material from illegal content and cyber attacks on a massive scale, which have filled newspaper chronicles, show that our societies are not yet sufficiently equipped to defend against these risks. The NIS Directive was the first measure on the issue of cybersecurity, with which we set the objective of ensuring the resilience of strategic infrastructures and increasing its coordination in the prevention and response to cyberthreats: a step forward of which we already appreciate the benefits, but which cannot rise to the challenges due to the reticences of the Member States. One year after the approval of the Network Security Directive, we have another opportunity in these months to strengthen the cybersecurity system, and to do so in a coordinated way through a new European act on which we are working, which will have to achieve two ambitious objectives. The first: the strengthening of the European Union's cybersecurity agency, ENISA, with more resources and operational powers. The second: the creation of a new pan-European certification system to ensure the safety of digital products and services, thus increasing confidence in consumers who every day use related goods and services. Only investing in resources and expertise in this field will ensure that the digital single market is able to deliver to citizens and enterprises a safer and more reliable system.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, digital systems penetrate all walks of life, including public services. We become addicted to them. The line between critical and non-critical infrastructure is becoming less distinct, fully autonomous systems and 5G networks will soon become a reality. Protecting against cyber crime is therefore a vital task and robust cooperation at European and international level must be the basis. Member States of the European Union have their professional systems and procedures. But we need to deepen the coordination and exchange of information within the European ecosystem. We will discuss the role of ENISA, there is also a dimension of cooperation between police and judicial authorities, including EUROPOL and EUROJUST. But one cannot create “Fortress Europe,” cyber crime does not respect borders. And all the more important is international cooperation with our Euro-Atlantic allies, but also with countries like Israel or South Korea.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, cyber security has become a part of global affairs and the threat is real, with possible lethal consequences. Imagine the consequences of a successful cyber attack on a nuclear plant, on an air-traffic control facility or on a hospital. There are more and more network disruptions for political purposes, and various state actors have been involved in malicious cyber activities in pursuit of political, economic or security objectives, including attacks on critical infrastructure, cyber espionage and disinformation campaigns. Because of this, we need to update European cyber defence capabilities, we need more cooperation among Member States, the EU, NATO and other like-minded countries. We need to build trust. We need to train more experts in cyber defence. We need more joint exercises and we also need to improve accountability, which requires further development of a common understanding of the international law applicable to cyberspace. The next attack might create far more damage than we have seen so far, and every future conflict can have a cyber dimension.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Mr President, let me fire my salvo. Currently intelligence agencies like the NSA have a habit of hoarding security vulnerabilities and exploits in order to gather intelligence. This means that they don’t disclose these vulnerabilities in a timely manner to the manufacturers of the affected products, who thus remain unaware and can’t immediately patch their products and services. Unfortunately, this modus operandi relies on the hope that these vulnerabilities are not discovered in parallel by anyone else, which is not very probable, especially if enough time goes by. This in turn makes everyone vulnerable, be it to attacks from a hostile nation-state or cyber criminals. Due to the nature of digital technologies themselves we are either all secure or none of us are.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: “Yesterday we had a debate on the multiannual financial framework. It enjoyed compatibility between Parliament and the Commission regarding the recognition of security as one of the most important elements of this financial perspective. Today we're talking about cybersecurity. It must be considered a key task, otherwise we will not succeed. We still lack time, consequence, determination and especially effectiveness in defining the problem itself. I will draw attention to the fact that cybersecurity involves attacks on programs, with tasks of obtaining information in an unauthorised manner, with various viruses, including impersonations of unauthorized persons or theft of information, and, above all, with security risks — security of citizens and economic entities. What do I want to pay most attention to now? If we do not settle, we will not succeed in protecting citizens and economic operators, the security of Europe will be seriously compromised. And it's already seriously compromised. And one more thing at the end: I believe that disregard for this issue, also from the technological side, unfortunately, is conducive to the opponents of Europe, European integration, as well as our security.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Mr President, we have been hearing today that digital technologies are an integral part of our daily life and the backbone of our economies. This makes it more crucial for the European Union to continue to equip itself with strong cybersecurity legislation, whilst investing in further research on how to protect citizens online. I believe that this is our opportunity to train young ICT experts who can combat this phenomenon and the crimes we are facing now and also the crimes of the future. Cybersecurity is not about infrastructure alone. It is also about educating users on the risks that they will be facing in cyberspace. The matter is more urgent since a number of public services across the EU are now available online. All it takes sometimes is just a click of a button or a password that is too easy to crack. My message today to the Commission and European governments is that it is not enough to arm yourselves with unhackable infrastructure. Educate citizens to think then click, not the other way round.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, the European Union has rightly prioritised the issue of cybersecurity, in my opinion, for some time. Cybercrime is costing the EU citizens and businesses throughout. The Barroso Commission in 2013 said one of the strategic priorities on cybersecurity was to drastically reduce cybercrime. This remains a noble aim. But sadly, the reality is that cybercrime has grown five times within the last four years, and this is expected to grow even further in the coming years. We need to ensure our intelligence agencies and police forces across Europe have all the necessary tools and comprehensive policy framework to take on these criminals. Equally, it is vital that we continue to raise the awareness among citizens of the importance of protecting their data against viruses and malware. While the United Kingdom will be leaving the European Union, we are not leaving Europe, and it is vital that we continue to work together, particularly on issues of security and cross-border crime. Hackers and other criminals seeking to attack us do not make a distinction between the EU and non-Member States.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. We have long known that moving further parts of our lives to the digital world is fortunately often making our lives easier, but at the same time more endangered by terrorists and cybercrime perpetrators. The Internet does not stop at national borders, so the top priority is Europe-wide cooperation between the European Commission, the EU Member States and us here in Parliament. We show determination here. The maximum protection of the critical infrastructure must prevent what happened a few weeks ago in Latvia, where the online healthcare system was paralleted by hackers. This maximum level of protection must be applied to businesses, public authorities and citizens, and we must all ensure that there is a targeted awareness of this issue. This starts with manufacturers, as well as citizens who do not have anti-virus protection or do not even update. The motto is to protect not only the data world that affects transport systems, rail, air and road transport, but also power plants, dams, industrial companies, hospitals, all authorities and so on. I believe we know very well that the European elections and all elections are also affected. Hence: Europe must act now!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the fight against cybercrime is an immediate necessity for the consolidation of democracy, the free movement of ideas, the protection of personal data and respect for personality. At the same time, however, the fight against cybercrime must respect the fundamental rights of citizens and their personal freedoms. A particular form of cybercrime is online intervention in the context of an election period in various Member States. Thus, among other things, false Facebook profiles are created, so that cyber attacks can be carried out with purely political purposes and targets. In this context, coordinated cyber attacks are taking place with the aim of politically and ethically obsolescence of all those who, through their political action, disturb the political and economic establishment. In addition to the criminal offences which are taking place, there is also a violation of every concept of open and democratic society, and all this, Mr President, in view of the forthcoming European elections.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Mr President, Commissioner. The true extent of cyberattacks is still underestimated, and the economic damage has already been named accordingly by colleagues. The number of issues is too large, and I still feel that we are still too dawful in dealing with the whole thing. That is to say, time plays an extreme role, and we just need to get to the edge here faster. This ultimately also illustrates two things, which has just been mentioned: we really need to be more educated so that this is also more anchored in the population. Secondly, we must recognise that this is a global problem and that we must therefore also strengthen cooperation with like-minded partners in the world in accordance with the way we do, because technology simply blurs the boundaries too much. We also need to try harder to create common standards here. The challenge is not just cyber crime, it's the Internet of Things, it's different legislation and it's human action. what do we need? We need concepts, a strategy on how to prevent cyberattacks, a strategy on how we can respond to them, and I believe that a hack back should also be included. We need a strategy on how to make our systems more robust. That is what colleagues have already said, we need standards, we need common rules, education, security by design, reporting obligations, balancing data protection issues, exercises and cooperation with other states.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, last week, Rob Wainwright, the outgoing director of Europol, was a guest of our Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. I asked him what was the greatest priority for European security policy in the coming period. He said, without hesitation, cybersecurity. Without hesitation. More than half of the people in this world today are connected to the Internet. Also, the number of devices connected to the Internet, which is connected, is increasing. Where you used to access the Internet only with your computer and an annoying dial-up modem, our coffee makers, our thermostats and our toothbrushes are connected. We don't go on the Internet anymore, but we're non—stop online. This is good for the ease of use that goes with it, but it is also vulnerable. We saw that too. DDoS—attacks, hacks to steal business data, sales of drugs and other prohibited resources on the dark web, cyber attacks on critical infrastructure. One thing is clear in any case: cybercriminals are not restricted by borders. An efficient approach cannot afford that either. The Directive on the security of network and information systems was an important step towards making the EU more resilient. Strengthening Enisa and developing the quality mark are important steps, but it is not enough yet. More than a hundred countries currently have the ability to spy digitally digitally and their professionalism is growing. My question to the Commission is: how are we going to arm ourselves against this in the coming years?

name: Carlos COELHO
text: — Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner King, cybercrime is no longer a risk to being a reality with an ever greater impact on our lives and on the functioning of our communities. From the scheduling of medical consultation to the control of the electricity distribution network, we live in an interconnected city that requires a determined action, both at European and national levels, both in the public and private sectors, both in prevention and combat. We advocate, and in some cases have already approved, strengthening the Network and Information Security Agency (ENISA), strengthening Europol's competences and resources, greater funding and close cooperation with private actors such as Facebook and Google. In this way, we have been equipping the Union and the Member States for this new reality. But we also need to adapt our evidence, that is to ensure that the Portuguese police have access to evidence that is on a server in Ireland, despite the fact that the crime investigated was against a Portuguese citizen. This example makes it clear that the absence of borders in the digital world urgently dictates the creation of a European approach to digital proof. That is why I am calling today for the European Commission to present a legislative proposal that regulates digital evidence, allowing for a more effective fight and certainly greater safeguards in the defence of European rights.

name: Michał BONI
text: – Mr President, digital is crucial for future competitive advantages and for everyday life. But the most essential things is trust. Trust based on guarantees to make all digital activities secure, and cybercrime as an offence clearly punishable, when we use the banking system, pay for digital services, use administrative services, watch movies at the tablet, send data to our doctor via telemedicine platform. This is the preventive function of cybersecurity policies fighting against cybercrime possibilities. Much more secure and protected devices, networks, platforms are the purpose of EU debate on cybersecurity package. Key for the prevention is cybersecurity hygiene; new attitude: to pay attention to the rules ensuring security in cyberspace. So what do we need for an effective fight against cybercrime? A proper legislative framework, similar globally; international standards and certification schemes; cooperation and shared responsibility of all stakeholders: public authorities, private sector, civic society and consumer organisations; law enforcement; real and virtual capacity and tools, to act effectively against the dark net internationally. And coordination of common actions, in Europe and globally, based on exchange of all information.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this debate, which I think has been very timely and has underlined again the importance of these issues. Last year we saw major attacks with WannaCry and NotPetya, but we also saw politically-motivated attacks. I think together, that has raised the awareness of the need to tackle these different cyber threats. I think we are responding. I am very grateful for the support that I hear and indeed the encouragement to keep working on these issues. From the Commission side we are committed to develop a cybersecurity agency with real competences and capacities and to develop a certification system that really delivers increased cybersecurity. We will work with the Member States to that end. We will work to promote a really effective public—private partnership. We will, as encouraged by you all, work to build the resilience of our infrastructures, our platforms, services and devices, but also to address the behavioural challenge: to build our behavioural and societal resilience too against some of these threats, because, as has been underlined by many of the speakers, in order to benefit to the full from the digital single market and all the social advantages we get from an ever-more interconnected society, we need to deal with the threats and the challenges that seek to undermine it.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I listened to your debates with great interest, and if we had to summarise the main aspects of the issue, I have to say that on the one hand, cyber security questions are clearly linked to the development of the digital single market, providing opportunities for citizens and European industry to make the most of the digital economy. On the other hand we are facing ever-increasing cyber security challenges, and one of them is the cyberattack WannaCry mentioned by many of you. These challenges ahead of us can be faced, and the ambition of making Europe the leader in cybersecurity by 2025 can be achieved, through multidimensional cooperation, a comprehensive approach and strengthening the legal framework. In order to increase the preparedness at national and EU level, the key word to overcome those challenges is cooperation and the multidimensional aspects: public-private cooperation, cooperation between Member States, economic cross-border and cross-sector collaboration, cooperation between the relevant services of the Member States, the EU institutions, the new agencies as well as third countries and organisations. As the Presidency, we are determined to advance the legislative work as much as possible. We consider the Cyber Security Act as a priority and hope to reach a general approach before the end of our term so that the trilogues can start under the Austrian Presidency. The aim is to give a stronger and permanent mandate to the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA), the new EU cyber security agency, and to avoid fragmentation of the cybersecurity market of services, goods and processes by establishing a framework for certification schemes at EU level. Discussions are still ongoing, notably the task and mandate of the ENISA as well as on certification. Let me assure you of the Council’s firm commitment to continuing the work that I have outlined and our readiness to adopt and effectively implement concrete measures in the field in order to ensure an open, free, safe and secure cyberspace while protecting with strong determination the fundamental rights and freedoms of our citizens.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. — There are many reasons for social alarm that can be fuelled by cybercrime. Some of these have emerged in the various speeches of the rapporteurs during this debate and all require specific attention and action, starting with the implementation of the directive on measures for a common high level of security of networks and information systems in the Union. On the other hand, as already highlighted in this Parliament's resolution on the fight against corruption and following the resolution of the CRIM Committee, cybercrime is often a means used in money laundering and counterfeiting. This form of crime, therefore, constitutes a significant source of income for many criminal groups and, also for these reasons, Union legislation and cooperation between Member States and with Union agencies in this area must be strengthened. We cannot ignore, in fact, that through fraudulent use of the Internet for illegal purposes, such as the promotion of drug trafficking or trafficking in human beings, criminal organizations have succeeded in greatly expand the volume of their illicit trades while also jeopardizing the safety of citizens.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. — Cybercrime, by its international nature and the increasing damage it causes, is becoming increasingly challenging for Member States, the European Union and the international community. Cyberattacks, or attacks using computers and networks, are estimated to bring losses of up to 400 billion euros a year to the world economy. There were more than 4,000 attempts to extort ransom a day last year, and 80 percent of European companies experienced at least one cybersecurity incident. Meanwhile, 51 per cent of EU citizens felt uninformed when it came to cyber threats and 69 per cent of companies had no basic knowledge of their vulnerability to digital threats. Therefore, the doubling of the European Commission's expenditure on the Network and Information Security Agency (ENISA), renamed last year as the EU Cybersecurity Agency (EU Cybersecurity Agency), should be supported. The agency is to hold cybersecurity exercises every year and, among others, defend against external attempts to influence elections. Based on the EU-NATO Joint Declaration signed at the NATO Summit in Warsaw on 8 July 2016, the EU is also working with NATO to counter hybrid and cybersecurity threats. Enhancing the cooperation of the relevant EU and NCA cybersecurity cells and the development of common standards is to serve the annual joint exercise on countering cybersecurity and hybrid threats, which will be led by the EU this year.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. — Online crime is undoubtedly a major threat in today's world and is going to concern our societies in the future. According to statistics, cybercrime is increasing in intensity, complexity and magnitude, as in some Member States reported cybercrime goes beyond traditional crime. Also, about 80% of businesses in Europe have experienced at least one cyber security breach incident. Characteristically, just last May, the global cyber attack “WannaCry” affected thousands of networks, computers, hospitals and railways across Europe. These recent incidents have clearly demonstrated the extremely high degree of vulnerability of the EU. So the question that arises is how can we effectively tackle cybercrime in cooperation at European level and how can we better protect European citizens? As the European Parliament's rapporteur on the report on combating crime on the Internet, I tried to answer these questions and deal with this complex legal and social issue effectively. Combating cybercrime is not a simple task, it requires highly skilled, continuing training and education, better coordination, cooperation with third countries and legal security.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on protection of investigative journalists in Europe: the case of Slovak journalist Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová (2018/2628(RSP)).

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, today’s debate has been triggered by the appalling assassination of Ján Kuciak and his partner Marina Kušnírová. First of all, I would like to offer my sincere condolences to their families, friends and colleagues. The Council strongly condemns this crime and expects the perpetrators to be brought to justice. Mr Kuciak was a journalist who was not afraid to investigate serious crime. He wanted to shed light on what needs to be eradicated in our societies and devoted his life to fighting corruption and the abuse of power. Mr Kuciak’s courageous behaviour deserves our respect and recognition. The work of journalists like him is a truly vital part of any healthy democracy. Media freedom is an indispensable pillar of any democratic society. Journalists are among the guardians of properly-functioning democracies. Where there is no freedom of speech and people fear for their lives every time they express a critical view, there is no democracy. It is for these very reasons that freedom of speech, media freedom and pluralism are guaranteed under the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. They are among the core democratic values on which the European Union is founded. These freedoms are an obligation on our governments, and all democracies must make it an absolute priority to protect journalists from financial or political pressure. Let me be clear: in our Union, attacks designed to silence media representatives are completely unacceptable. If they happen, we must act immediately: we must condemn the crime, find and punish the perpetrators and re-establish public trust in the ability of our democratic institutions to function. We are all conscious of the responsibility our governments have to protect journalists and defend media freedom. The Slovak law enforcement authorities, together with international experts, are investigating the crime. A delegation from the European Parliament was in Bratislava last week. I look forward to what they will have to say. The Council welcomes the timely initial response of the Slovak authorities, including their initiative to provide a detailed briefing during the February session of the General Affairs Council in Brussels, on 27 February. It signalled a clear commitment on the part of the Slovak Government to ensure a quick investigation. The Council stands ready to provide any assistance to the Slovak authorities in investigating this appalling crime. We owe this to Mr Kuciak and to all journalists working to make our societies better.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are all still deeply shocked by the assassination of Ján Kuciak, a 27-year-old investigative reporter, and his partner Martina Kušnírová two weeks ago in Slovakia. We strongly condemn it and express again our deepest condolences to their families and loved ones. Last week President Tajani made a strong call for a detailed, in-depth international investigation. All of the political groups requested an independent inquiry commission to investigate what happened. As President Juncker said, the killing or intimidation of journalists has no place in Europe, no place in any democracy. On behalf of President Juncker and all my colleagues in the Commission, can I say that we fully agree that the top priority for all of us must be to carry out an independent and thorough investigation of the facts and bring those responsible to justice? We call upon the Slovak authorities to do this quickly. We are aware that their investigation relies upon the cooperation of Europol and the Italian authorities. Europol is ready to support the investigations with all the instruments and expertise at its disposal. The EU also provides several additional tools to support police and judicial cooperation between Slovakia and Italy. We encourage the authorities to make full use of this extra support. This cooperation should be put in place as rapidly as possible in order for justice to be done. In order to find out whether this case involved misuse of EU funds and had a cross-border dimension, we invite the authorities to cooperate fully with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). If misuse of funds were proven this case would illustrate again why we need the European public prosecutor. The murders of Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová, as well as that of Daphne Caruana Galizia five months ago, show that investigative journalism remains a dangerous profession everywhere in the world, including here in Europe. We can’t accept this. As First Vice-President Timmermans stated, no democracy can survive without the free press, which is why journalists deserve respect and protection. We have to do our utmost to ensure journalists’ safety and to stop such crimes from happening again in any EU Member State. Media freedom and pluralism are essential pillars of our modern democracy. They are guarantees of an open and free democratic debate. They are fundamental rights, as enshrined in Article 11 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. They’re intrinsically linked to the values which we treasure and which we can never take for granted. Journalists have the right to investigate, to ask uncomfortable questions and to report effectively. This is what Ján Kuciak was doing. That, it appears, is why he was murdered. Every day we witness the challenges that political, technological and sociological changes pose to pluralism, to the status of facts and investigative journalism throughout the world. In 2016 the Commission dedicated its annual colloquium on fundamental rights precisely to these issues – media pluralism and democracy. Several Members of this House took part in those discussions actively. They explored the multiple links between a free pluralistic media and democracy and agreed to promote and protect that pluralism and freedom of the media in the EU. The assassinations in Slovakia show that we need to continue to be vigilant, including in Europe, and do more to protect these fundamental rights on a national as well as an EU level. Member States have a duty to make sure that press freedom and journalists are protected on their territory, in law but also in spirit. It is up to national governments, in this sad case Slovakia, to make sure that their citizens are protected and to bring those guilty of crimes to justice in accordance with their constitutional legal order and with international human rights obligations. Under the Treaties, the Commission has limited powers concerning media freedom. However, we can and do monitor, encourage and guide. For instance, we are acting to make sure that journalists can do their essential work in safety. Journalists are the watchdogs of our democratic societies. With their relentless work and investigations they enable a free and independent media to hold those in power to account. In this context, we are completing our work on an initiative that we announced in our work programme last October to strengthen the protection of whistleblowers. Whistleblowers who unveil illegal activities are an important source of information for journalists. Protecting them from retaliation is, therefore, a vital part of safeguarding investigative journalism. The best guarantee of media freedom and pluralism is to ensure the independence of media regulators. This is why the Commission has proposed strengthening the rules for the independence of national audiovisual regulators as part of the revision of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive. This includes requirements of independence that relate also to budgetary and structural provisions. But it is not only about laws. We also monitor risks to media pluralism across Europe and map violations of media freedom. We support journalists under threat as well as investigative journalism. We have recently begun funding a scheme dedicated cross-border investigative journalism. Many of these initiatives, and I salute this, are independent projects financed by this Parliament. One particularly useful instrument is the EU-financed media pluralism monitor, which aims to identify and highlight risks to media pluralism. Unfortunately, the results show that no Member State is immune from risks when it comes to media pluralism. I can assure you that we will continue to monitor the situation in all Member States, including in Slovakia. As this case demonstrates, both the EU and its Member States need to do more to protect investigative journalism across Europe. The murder of this young journalist and his partner is an attack on all that Europe stands for, our values, our right to freedom of speech, our right to ask difficult questions, our rights justice and our capacity to hold those in power properly to account. This is what distinguishes our democracies and keeps them healthy and vibrant. Mr President, if you’ll permit me, two words on another matter. We live in extraordinary times. Various forces seem intent on attacking the rule of law, the very values that lie at the heart of our open societies. We have seen recently the first offensive use of nerve agent on European territory since World War II, something that the Council of Europe called a ‘dangerous breach of the rule of law’. I want to join First Vice-President Timmermans in repeating again, on behalf of the Commission, our full solidarity with the people of Salisbury, indeed the people of Britain, as they tackle this attack.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you, Commissioner for both issues. On the latter issue Parliament has taken a very strong position and I can only reiterate and fully support what you have said.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: on behalf of the PPE Group — Mr President, two weeks ago we were all paralyzed by the horror of the act that happened in Slovakia. Two young people, investigative journalist Ján Kuciak and his girlfriend Martina Kušnírová, were brutally executed in their own home. If the target of the killers was to cause fear and apathy in people, then from this point I tell them they failed. Citizens of the Slovak Republic, who have been slowly accustomed to daily reports on millions of millions of casuals and to the miraculous phrase “deed did not happen”, took a huge number to the streets. These protests were not carried in a sign of hatred and violence. Were and are in favour of decent Slovakia. For Slovakia, where contacts and acquaintances do not decide, where the international mafia does not rule, but where everyone has the same chances and where honest work leads to a decent life. For such Slovakia as Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová wanted. What can we MEPs do to make Slovakia and Europe more decent? Very much, I think. First and foremost, we must continue where Ján Kuciak had to end up with the hands of the killer. We can uncover the schemes and ways in which European money gets into the hands of the mafia. We can improve legislation to protect journalists and send a clear signal that we will simply not allow such practices. The name of Jan Kuciak must not be forgotten. That is why, as the European People's Party, we propose that the internship for journalists in the European Parliament be named after Jan Kuciak. We honor his memory and bring Ján Kuciak's work to the end.

name: Claude MORAES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I speak for my group, but also with Ms Gräßle I co—chaired the delegation last week to Slovakia. This was a difficult delegation, and I think we both express our shock and sympathy to the family and friends of Ján Kuciak and his fiancée, Martina Kušnírová, for their loss, and we did so at their residence, which was a very moving moment. I think the entire delegation understood, in that moment, that this attack to silence journalists has shocked the entire country, and it is right that the European Union sends a delegation and tries to understand why this silencing of journalists anywhere in the EU is in fact an existential threat both to that country and to the European Union, as has been expressed. Together with my colleague Ms Gräßle, we had the task of trying to understand what was happening in the country. We spoke to journalists, to NGOs, to representatives of the protesters, right through to the Prime Minister, President and all of the Ministers and, as Ms Gräßle will say, to the highest audit and agricultural payment agencies’ authorities. We tried to understand what was happening. But this debate centres very much on the question of press freedom. What I would have to say is that from the journalists we understood that they regard themselves as free to express what they want to express. But also in our investigation we understood that there were also threats existing before Ján Kuciak was murdered, and this investigation is an urgent one. For this reason, as Commissioner King has mentioned, there is a lot of cooperation with outside agencies. But we would urge not just assistance from Europol, but we would request – and we did request in Slovakia – that there is a joint investigation team and that there is that level of urgency and an opening of the investigation so that there is maximum trust and people see that the investigation is as open and as trusted as it can be. The question of fundamental rights and press freedom is one for this whole House and indeed for the Commission and Council to consider. What happened to Ján Kuciak is something that we will investigate over the coming days: the connections between the allegations of corruption that we investigated without fear or favour. I would say that the entire delegation were not fearful of asking those difficult questions. In the final sentence, if I may, I would just say that we will make those observations clear in our report. Please read our report. But I would say that, if we have to protect journalists either in Slovakia or the rest of the EU, we will do it.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I am sure that I speak on behalf of the whole House when I say we are looking forward to the report and getting acquainted with the findings.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group — Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, in the Slovak national anthem, the words 'Slovakia has slept hard so far, but lightning thunder inspires him to wake up' are sung. And it is a great tragedy that thunder lightning were shots in the village of Veľká Maca, which killed innocent people, Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová. A journalist who dealt with anti-corruption investigations. They paid the biggest price, with their own lives. Ján Kuciak exposed corruption political cases and mafia crimes. But I will tell you that we also have other journalists: Pavol Rýpal and Miroslav Pejko have fearlessly revealed various scandals and are still missing today and hope is lost whether they are still alive. People were blunted by indifference, from which they were taken up by shots of the execution of Jan Kuciak and his fiancée. And Slovakia really came to life. Slovaks and Slovaks came to many of our cities to demonstrate to light candles and express clear opposition to the direction of our country. There are also various concerts and artists canceling performances to make it clear that this cannot remain that way. It is a disgrace to the government of Robert Fico and his ministers to where our society has caught up. Slovakia is getting out of lethargy, and until now the octopus of corruption has stretched its tentacles to the highest positions of governance of the state. I firmly believe this is the end. Dear colleagues from the Monitoring Committee, I thank you for the work you have done, because we also needed such intervention. I am grateful that you have mentioned the specific problems that Slovakia has to deal with. This is the time when Slovak politicians, honest police officers and investigators are waiting for work, as well as our entire civil public, great work to set up new paradigms for justice, enforceability of the law promised by our Prime Minister years ago, when he took office, and so far he seems to have failed to do so. Furthermore, trust must be restored in a state that defends the freedom and security of citizens, as well as journalists who fearlessly reveal corruption. It is necessary more thorough control of European money, as it is a source of corruption in Slovakia.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I must say that it is surely not just me who has the highest respect for the Slovaks and the message that they sent out in the streets of many Slovak towns and cities.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, last week the delegation stood at the house where Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová lived and, as Claude Moraes already said, it was an emotional moment and it also gave a very strong sense of purpose to the work of the delegation, because Ján wrote about corruption, fraud and organised crime and possible connections with government circles. Was he killed because of his work? Because exposing wrongdoing is likely to get some very powerful people really upset, maybe even upset to kill for. Just months earlier, Daphne Caruana Galizia was also killed. Two journalists killed in the European Union because they did their job: scrutinising those in power. Those killings are an attack on democracy, and it doesn’t just affect Maltese or Slovakian democracy but it affects the European Union as a whole. We saw a kind of double reality in Slovakia. On the one hand, the legislative framework is solid. The basic democratic institutional structures are in place, and media and civil society are vibrant and critical. On the other hand, there is a parallel reality of corruption, fraud, state capture and organised international crime. In this shady world it’s very difficult to distinguish between truth, half truths, lies and imagination. This uncertainty creates a climate of deep distrust and frustration of citizens with the public institutions. It’s therefore crucial that the murder investigation is independent. I strongly advocate the full involvement of Europol – and not just to provide technical expertise, but with full access to the files. Then, Commissioner, I hear what you’re saying, I’ve heard it before: the European Commission has very little powers to intervene. Well, I disagree with that. We have discussed it often. But this would finally be the opportunity to put forward a legislative proposal for a really strong mechanism for an annual health check for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, because I am convinced that in Slovakia that would have really been support for the ‘good’ people. Finally, we found a nation that is in shock, traumatised and angry – but also a nation that is resilient, and our visit was a message to the people of Slovakia. We stand shoulder to shoulder with you as Europeans to defend our shared values.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the tragic assassination of Ján Kuciak shocked everybody in Slovakia and in the European institutions alike. As a member of the EP delegation to Slovakia, I believe that now the most important thing is an impartial and in—depth investigation to unveil who and what were behind this brutal murder. But we also have lessons to learn at EU level. The first is that the media freedom situation of investigative journalism and journalists must be an issue for the EU as well. We cannot hide behind the mantra that media issues belong to the Member States and are Member State competences. We need better legal protection for journalists and journalistic sources, including whistle-blowers, now. We have to analyse the situation in the Member States regarding access to information regimes in the Member States and the possible protection of investigative journalists’ personal data in requests for data procedures. We must step up against practices to intimidate journalists by threatening them or by strategic law suits. We have to have European anti—SLAPP measures today and we should invest financial resources to support, strengthen and protect independent media in the Member States in the next post—2020 MFF at the latest. Second, there is the question of EU funds. How is it possible that major frauds regarding EU funds were happening for years and finally it was neither the Slovakian authorities nor the European institutions who uncovered them, but a 27—year—old investigative journalist who paid for this with his life? This must warn us that the control mechanisms to check the spending of EU funds are not strict and effective enough and so are not able to prevent EU funds enriching organised crime groups and politically well-positioned oligarchs in the Member States.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, death can never be justified, and not at all, if it is such young people who were merely trying to make truths. The deaths of Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová must be investigated as soon as possible so that we know the truth about this cowardly and vile act. Once again, let me offer my sincere condolences to the families of the bereaved. The case we are talking about today is absolutely damning, but I would like to ask everyone present not to make Slovakia a country occupied by mobsters here. We didn't do it in Malta and we shouldn't do it in Slovakia. We all believe here in democratic control and indivisibility of power, so let the Slovak authorities take place. Now really isn't the moment to collect cheap political dots. Events in Slovakia are not to be judged by the streets, the European Union and neither is the European Parliament, but by an independent Slovak court In this context, I find it sheer audacity that our colleague Manfred Weber is training Prime Minister Fico from whomever he is to throw out of government. So I would like to know if the countries of Central Europe can dictate who will be in the German government when it is finally looming. I hope so, because there's a double standard here otherwise. Please let us have this debate with respect to Slovakia and its democratic and independent institutions. Slovakia deserves a helping hand if asked for it, and not condemnation based on speculation. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: question asked by raising the blue card. — I would like to ask Mrs. Fini what she does not like about when Slovak citizens go free to express their opinion. They don't make decisions on the street, they meet there to express their disapproval of when the government isn't acting, when it doesn't want to take responsibility for the situation that's there. Street does not make decisions, but the street is calling for this murder to be properly investigated in Slovakia. So I ask: Why do you disagree with it when people take to the streets to express their opinion?

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: answer to the question asked by picking up a blue card. — Lady colleague, to the fact that I spoke Czech, I wonder that you do not understand me. I didn't say I didn't agree with the street stating its opinion. I just said that we should trust independent courts and trust Slovakia, and I refuse to let our colleagues, your colleagues, Your Manfred Weber, interfere with who is supposed to be a minister in Slovakia , or how the government is to be composed. We have no right to do that, and if we allow this, we are opening a Pandora's box, which may backfire for us.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was also part of Parliament's delegation which visited Slovakia last week, and what happened to Ján Kuciak and the Girlfriend Martina strongly affected everyone. As a first recommendation, we strongly need to make independent investigations and also through strong cooperation with international policies, especially the Italian one, given the possible implications of mob, organized crime. And on this point the Italian police have a lot of information and it would be appropriate to involve it throughout the arc and investigation. In addition, the Committee on Budgetary Control will deepen the issue of the use of the Structural Funds, especially in the field of agriculture and development, since there may also be there are connections linked, precisely, to possible fraud, or the need for further transparency. Finally, we use this moment to try to demand the implementation of a procedure that leads investigative journalism to be strongly protected, and the crime for mafia association a something not only transposed in Italy, but also in the rest of the countries of the European Union.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, in 2016, the Centre for Pluralism and Freedom of the Media assessed the risk to press independence in Slovakia at 53%. This was not to mention the endemic climate of corruption highlighted by several international indices, notably that of Transparency International. How many bloodshed, such as the assassination of Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová, so that the European Union finally takes its hands on the issue of creeping financial crime. His inaction in the case of the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia — indeed, we had the same speech and, since then, we have heard nothing more — is symptomatic of her waiting, as is the division by two, on January 23, of her already very lacunary list of tax havens. At a time when the Commission is waving red rags, like the imaginary threat of false information, its inertia in the face of the dramatic decline in press freedom is all the more scandalous given that the courage of real investigative journalists is paid at the cost of blood.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Madam President! I would like to thank the members of the delegation for their presence in Slovakia. I want to warn us against rash conclusions. We don't know — as it was now — why the journalist was shot. We must give the prosecution and the police every opportunity to investigate in all directions, and we must not point out pre-convictions and biased ways — it would be a serious mistake — if we want this story to be clarified. This includes, of course, tackling the systemic problems within Slovakia, and I did not like the fact that we have close government staff with mafia connections. That's not possible. I would also like the public's concern to be taken up here, and I would like us to ensure clear conditions here too. Commissioner King, we also have some requests to you: the Commission has stopped the annual anti-corruption report. We believe that it would be good and important to make this report again. We have seen from the point of view of budgetary control that we have problems in the agricultural fund. We in budgetary control will now address these problems, in every area — at the paying agency, the agricultural funds. We will deal with Slovakia very intensively and extensively, without any preliminary convictions. Until now, we have always been quite satisfied with the Slovak authorities. Slovakia was not the country where we saw the biggest problems, but admittedly we also have a helicopter view, we do not see everything. But we will do some things and work very hard to help Slovakia not to condemn it. Slovakia is an important member of our European family and that is why it deserves solidarity for all of us, but also for us to put an end to certain corruption conditions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: — Madam President, 26 February, when we learned of the brutal murder of journalist Ján Kuciak and his girlfriend, was a black day not only for Slovakia but also for the whole European Union. Two young people who wanted to live together were murdered. They planned to start a family and believed in the values of a common Europe. This brutal act needs to be investigated so that we do not take away young people hope that we live in democratic countries where laws apply. I live in Slovakia, where this heinous act happened. I am immediately experiencing the atmosphere that this act has created in humans. It's fear, uncertainty, perhaps up to the hopelessness that the perpetrators won't reveal themselves. I do not want to take this hope, and I firmly believe that this murder will also be punished because foreign experts also help our criminals. Last year we witnessed the murder of a journalist in Malta. Please, together, let us do our best so that we don't have similar sad cases anymore. This time it was Malta and Slovakia, but they could have happened anywhere else as well. Journalists have an irreplaceable place in our society. The protection of journalists must be clearly declared, they must have conditions created for their work that they are not intimidated, so that they do not have to work and live under police protection. However, this sad event raises many questions. The legitimate question is what we have done to ensure organised crime has no place in the European Union. What we have done to avoid the rampant movement of terrorists in the European Union. Have we taken sufficient measures to establish effective mechanisms for controlling the drawdown of Eurofunds with the possibility of prosecution if fraud is found? In tax evasion and tax avoidance, the EU loses EUR 1 trillion per year. Repeat, 1 trillion euros. These are the topics investigative journalists are devoted to. That is why I join the call that 17 journalistic organisations have written to the Commission so that the high-ranking representatives of the Union do not waste their time and follow up on their words with actions. Commission, according to this letter, must take the leading status and require civil servants and public figures to create an environment in which the fundamental role of journalism is respected. The first step towards this is the rapid functioning of the European Public Prosecutor, the establishment of a European Investigation Office of the European Intelligence Agency. And let us be honest that the elimination of tax havens within the European Union and the adoption of European legislation that will prevent tax evasion and fraud. We owe it to Jan Kuciak and his girlfriend, but also to EU citizens. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question asked by lifting a blue card. — Dear lady colleague, I know that you come from eastern Slovakia and this is actually the main topic or was the main topic of the last articles of Jan Kuciaka. Therefore, I want to ask you: How do you personally perceive what he wrote and what he described? How do you perceive these practices? You were here today calling for journalists to have protection. How do you personally perceive that he asked for that protection and didn't get it from the police? And how do you personally evaluate the work of Slovak authorities from a member of the government party SMER?

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: answer to the question asked by picking up the blue card — I will be happy to answer. I live in eastern Slovakia and I guarantee you that we have no mafia in eastern Slovakia. I invite Members, if they want to look, I have a real overview of how individual farmers manage, and I want to tell you that, in addition to Italian entrepreneurs, there are German, Dutch and various others who may have known in advance how to receive subsidies. Many of our farmers did not know about this yet, they were not ready, so I want to say that they are just taking advantage of how we set up subsidies in the European Union. It is time to look at the common agricultural policy and subsidies.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - Madam President! I am here in a dual role: as a member of our mission to Slovakia and as coordinator of its political faction in the Committee on Budgetary Control. I have to say that in this situation you have to speak very precisely. On the one hand, by adopting a large amount of measures from the European Union for agriculture, Slovakia can clearly expect that the chapter of these measures will be meticulously respected. On the other hand, what happens in Slovakia is an internal matter of the country. Slovaks decide whether they want an early election or not. This decision is up to the Slovak authorities, the president, the government, to the Slovak society and we will not interfere in this. We have the right to expect clear and transparent procedures. Finally, I will only propose that we do not talk about the general procedure, Madam Member, because this is an admission of the helplessness of the authorities of your country.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: — Madam President, the murder of Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová is terrible and the competent authorities must detect and punish the culprits. The media, especially print, these days face economic problems related to internet news coverage, social networks and other changes in the whole environment. Particularly time-consuming investigative journalism does not often have enough resources. The role of traditional novelty is irreplaceable in a democracy all the more that in today's world we are targeted by a multitude of fake news and misinformation. Its significance is also evidenced by the revelation of the type of Panama documents. Politicians must respect and, if necessary, defend free speech and create conditions for the free work of the media, not to mention the safety of journalists. In Malta, Daphne Caruanova Galizio was murdered and now there was murder in Slovakia. It is an absolute necessity to do everything to keep something like this from happening again.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Madam President! As before in Malta, we see the same pattern again: there are new elections or discussions on new elections, individual resignations, but what we actually need is to clarify the murders and clarify the acts that journalists have researched. This is just as lame in Malta as it is now in Slovakia. That is why we should be on the side of those who are currently demonstrating on the road in Slovakia — as has already happened in Malta — for compliance with European values. But we can also do things here, and that is why I call on you, Commissioner: at least now reinstate the European Commission's annual anti-corruption report and ensure an annual monitoring of fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law in all European Member States. That would also be sufficient for equal treatment. Finally, I think that the Socialist party family must also be asked whether Robert Fico did not contribute to the climate for this murder with his statements about journalists as prostitutes, snakes and hyenas. When did you distance yourself from Robert Fico? I'd like to know that from you.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: — Madam President, there is a question for these people we are discussing today: is it a coincidence that three months after the Maltese journalist's murder, we have had new murders? No, it's not a coincidence. It is a result of the fact that there is fertile ground for the development of crime. Economic oligarchy is becoming increasingly uncontrollable, tax havens still exist in Europe, and there is no adequate protection for journalists or public interest witnesses. In my country, Greece, there is a major scandal, the Novartis scandal, which is progressing and being investigated, thanks to the testimony of public interest witnesses (whistleblowers), who are not even protected pan-European. Mr King, I would like to ask you a question. A month ago, together with colleages from all the political Groups in the Parliament, we sent a letter to Mr Timmermans, First Vice-President of the Commission, asking him to protect journalists Against Lawsuits. Daphne was a victim of that. We have no answer. Any news? Another short question for the Commission: the current Prime Minister of Slovakia was calling the journalists 'prostitútka' like prostitutes. Any comment, Ms Panayotova, about that? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: — Qegdin illum hawn nitkellmu dwar assassinju ta' urnalist, Jan Kuciak. Athe f'Malta wkoll arrabna assassinju ta' urnalista — dak ta' Daphne Caruana Galizia. Kien hemm min trowel hawk interess li entainasad il-verajja taghom, biex iib fi tmiem dak li kienu qegdin jagmlu. L-investigazzjonijiet dwar ir-rabtiet u x-xibka ta' rünzzjon, u l-investigazzjonijiet dwar il-monasil ta' flus huma ta' xkiel gal min irid jostor il-verità. Ta' xkiel gal min ikun irid jabi l-fatti. Ta' xkiel gthe min irid isir sinjur b'mezzi illegali. Il-mexxejja u min gandu r-responsabbiltà li jinvestiga dawn l-assassinji gandhom piż kbir fuq spallejhom. L-g Nafu li l-istituzzjonijiet meta jkunu dgajfa u n-nuqqas ta' infurzar tal-lithe jiet huma velenu gthe as-so- jetà u vitamini gthe all-kriminali. Il-mekkaniżmu biex i-ittadini Ewropej ikollhom mom-mistriemid-demokrazija, il-versoarsien u l-applikazzjon tal-lito kif ukoll id-drittijiet tal-bniedem qed isir aktar ur-enti. Je家tieto li dan il-mekkaniżmu jkun applikabbli gmodal kull pajjiż u jidto ol fis-semalajr. Il-urnalisti qed i- allsu prezz g- oli. Qed ithe allsu b'theddid ta' azzjonijiet legali, b'kawżi fil-qrati, b'intimidazzjoni u sathe ansitra bi qtil kif rajna f'Malta u S-Slovakkja. Sadanittant u ana netieu azzjoni, ser inkomplu ni U hawnhekk nispi Kullimkien. We are all for Ján and we will never stop fighting for justice for Daphne.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President! The news of the violent death of journalist Ján Kuciak and his fiancée Martina Kušnírová has caused great horror everywhere, as has the murder of Daphne Galizia. We have to do everything we can to find the culprits and put them on trial. Above all, the background needs to be clarified and why the authorities failed or why individual officials may even have been involved in the incidents. This must be done relentlessly and without consideration, immediately. But we must also ask ourselves what impact such crimes have on the professional practice of journalists. We owe that to the victims. A vibrant democracy needs independent journalism; it's like the air to breathe. Journalists must be able to carry out their work without hindrance, without fear of repression, persecution or even death. That is why we must resolutely oppose any attempt to curtail the independence of the media and to restrict the freedom to practise the profession. Above all, however, a legislative initiative is urgently needed to protect whistleblowers. We can't undo what happened, but we may be able to prevent it in the future.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Madam President, Ján Kuciak was investigating how one of the most brutal trade unions of the Italian mafia infiltrated Slovakia. He had information that European money from agricultural subsidies had reached them and discovered links between Slovak officials and the Calabrese mafia. But why did he die? Ján requested information, on the basis of the Italian public information law, from the Italian finance, which, according to the law, notifies people about whom information is requested if they wish to appeal. Basically, in Italy, criminals are effectively notified when someone asks for information about them. We urgently need to make standards in Union law that protect the identity of investigative journalists. We can take an example from various undercover witness protection laws. Otherwise, basically, we force investigative journalists to disclose their personal data, pack their lives and give them to criminal organizations.

name: Eva JOLY
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Ján Kuciak has paid with his life and that of Martina Kušnírová for his taste for truth and her disgust at the corruption that is cranking Slovakia. Faced with the intolerable, I stand alongside their families and the thousands of Slovaks who express their craving and thirst for justice. First, by demanding a thorough and impartial investigation into these killings. Then, calling for greater protection of journalists and whistleblowers. Finally, by ensuring that all the light is shed on the organized crime denounced by Ján Kuciak. This case illustrates the full interest of the future European Public Prosecutor's Office when European funds are diverted and mafia groups and politicians seem to be linked. The European Public Prosecutor's Office will be able to put the necessary distance between justice and politics. It will ensure that sensitive investigations are conducted in a truly independent and coordinated manner. Europeans are tired of corruption, put an end to impunity.

name: József NAGY
text: — Madam President, violence and fear must not control our lives. I am therefore pleased that the European Parliament is also joining the media and political pressure to investigate the heinous murder of young journalist Kuciak and his girlfriend. In Slovakia, people are rightly protesting on the streets because they are anxious to see justice in many areas of life. Therefore, our higher goal must be for people to gain confidence in state institutions. So they don't just wave their hand over the possibility of asking for justice. A number of key findings have been made by the European Parliament's Commission of Inquiry. I am outraged that, for example, ignorance of some European standards prevents the investigation of criminal cases in Slovakia. But the biggest problem is that even where legislation is in line with EU standards, there is a huge deficit in application in practice. That is why there is a strong distrust of the institutions in Slovakia, and that is why criminals are increasingly allowing themselves. Yes, every murder is a heinous act, regardless of the person of the victim, and any uninvestigated crime weakens faith in justice and further encourages perpetrators. In addition to a thorough investigation of the case of journalist Kuciak and his partner, our resolution should demand clarification in cases of the mysterious disappearance of our two long-missing investigative journalists Pavel Rýpal and Miroslav Pejk.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Madam President! If journalists are killed in the middle of Europe who have researched corruption, possible links between crime and politics, then this must be on the European agenda. Because we must not tolerate corruption shaking confidence in public action. We must not allow journalists to be threatened or even killed on the basis of their research. Because independent, critical media are an indispensable pillar of democracy and the rule of law. That is why national and European actors must work together to provide information, continue research and clear conclusions must be drawn. This is not only a recognition of journalistic work, but it would be a clear signal that together together we are firmly opposed to corruption and abuse of power everywhere.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, hearing the radio news on 26 February also struck me with a feeling of disgust. For the second time in a short time, a journalist was murdered in one of our European Member States. I have worked as a journalist myself for years, which is why the news touches me very deeply. Ján Kuciak and his partner Martina Kušnírová were shot in cold blood. Did he get too close to the truth in his investigation into possible mob interference in the Slovak state system? We need to get it sorted out thoroughly. Journalists, the watchdogs of our democracy, must not only be left alone, they must also be actively protected. Our governments must guarantee journalists that they can do their job, that they can exercise their fundamental right to access information without risking their personal data being leaked, passed on to third parties, at worst to criminal organizations. It's too late for Kuciak and his wife. But let us learn lessons for the future — and I agree with the Commissioner — let us carry out an independent and impartial investigation by the Slovak Government, in cooperation with Europol, and pay due attention to possible complicity of officials. (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, the recent murders of the Slovakian journalist and his partner are terrible, but unfortunately this is not something new. Across the world we find too many cases to deplore and condemn, among others the murder of Anna Politkovskaya in Russia and the hundreds of journalists and crucial rights defenders murdered in Mexico. They were killed because they were investigating and denouncing corruption and the abuse of power. What can we do? Of course we should attack the causes of these tragedies. This means that we cannot leave those who fight for justice and freedom all alone. Corruption is destroying the kernel of our systems. Corruption is not just a private matter. That’s why we have to push governments and political and social bodies to fight, for themselves, against their internal, structural corruption. European insistence and monitoring in this direction is the best contribution you can make. If we do not fight corruption systematically, we are leaving critical citizens alone and unprotected.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Madam President, Slovak journalist Ján Kuciak and his partner Martina Kušnírová were murdered on 26 February. Ján was investigating alleged links between Slovak politicians and the Calabrian mafia. This murder, this act of cowardice, is an attack on one of the fundamental pillars of democratic Europe: freedom of expression and investigative journalism. My deepest and strongest condemnation. Unfortunately, this is not the first case and, unfortunately, it may not be the latest attack on journalists in a Member State of the Union. It is necessary to remember now and keep in mind Daphne Caruana Galizia, who paid with her life to report and investigate constant violations of the rule of law in Malta. Neither Slovakia nor Malta deserve what is happening, and it is the duty of this Parliament to ensure that all Member States comply with Article 11 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which guarantees freedom of information. I welcome and very positively appreciate the mission we sent to Slovakia a week ago. I hope that the meetings held with the various actors and institutions will help shed some light on this attack. It is essential that Europol, Commissioner, be much more involved in investigations on the ground in order to clarify these murders. Europol plays a decisive role under its own Regulation.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: — Madam President, several times I also wish to regret the death of a young journalist and his girlfriend. And I want to assure you that all people in Slovakia feel the same way. I say this not only as a politician, not just as a Member of the European Parliament, but also as a woman and a mother. My son will be 30 this year and I can imagine how hard it must be for his parents. I also want to assure you that all the competent authorities involved in this brutal murder are doing all the acts that lead to this murder being investigated. No one in Slovakia is now concerned about this murder being investigated. Of course, it is our duty to protect the rights and lives of journalists throughout the European Union, and we politicians should have proper relations with journalists and we should respect each other. If this has not been the case in Slovakia in the past, I want to express the conviction that this will be the case, and at the same time I want to ask all the competent authorities in the European Union that we also proceed to the spread of powers precisely because of the various suspicions in the European Union and in other countries, such as Slovakia, European Public Prosecutor's Office. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card question. – Ms Beňová, I think everybody agrees that we need to have an independent investigation. The problem is, of course, that the work of Ján Kuciak was investigating, in particular, people in power. So how can the investigation into his murder be independent if the very people he was targeting are in charge of that? Would you like to argue with your party in Slovakia that they should allow Europol in as a full member of the investigation?

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card — Sofia, we have known each other for many years, we have been together in the LIBE Committee for many years, and I can assure you that, as the President of the Slovak Republic said, all the authorities or all those involved in the investigation of Mr Kuciak's murder have enormous interest in getting this murder solved. And, as Mrs Gräßle said, I do not see the way in that we are now going to accuse individual members of the government or the government as a whole, of perhaps participating in murder in the plenary of the European Parliament. You can't even be serious about that.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Madam President! For me, these two appalling murders, both the one in Malta and now in Slovakia, committed on investigative journalists, like the plight of many whistleblowers, which we once, recently, also here debated, have a bit wider meaning. And it seems to me that these are drastic examples that show a much broader problem. What's the problem? Namely, the differences between facade and reality. A facade built from a declaration, sometimes also a facade built here in Parliament, with an adherence to the values and principles of transparency, the values of European democracy, and reality. And that reality, as we know it, is a bit more complicated. This reality is being explored by investigative journalists. And here I wanted to say that what investigative journalists reveal — and sometimes whistleblowers — is not just the disparity between facade and reality in Malta and Slovakia, it is also in other European countries. And I would advise colleagues to look more closely at the situation in their countries as well.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Madam President, no democracy can survive without a free press, said the Commissioner. We want to regret the drama of this murder for investigating the truth. Being a journalist is a high-risk profession in many places, for investigating cases of corruption, drug trafficking, tax fraud or capital evasion, but in some Member States there are also serious attacks on freedom of expression — as the Commissioner also said in relation to pluralism — as is the case in the Spanish State, where the freedom of expression of journalists is being repressed and gagged as well as that of artists and twitters. My full support for those people retaliated for the exercise of their right to freedom of the press and freedom of expression. Tell journalist Ana Pardo de Vera; to the vice president of the Spanish Television Information Council, Xabier Fortes; to Nacho Carretero for the seizure of the book “Fariña” on drug trafficking; Pablo Hasél; César Strawberry; tweet Cassandra; the artist from whom their ARCO work was withdrawn. Tell so many people repressed by the gag law.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: — Madam President, in a growing number of European countries, it would seem that if you are a journalist, if we investigate, if you risk getting too close to greedy, criminal interests, but above all deprived of some powerful, we live a dangerous life. We started last year, which is similar to a series with Daphne Caruana Galizia, who died because she was investigating. Ján Kuciak died, with his partner, because he was investigating. I am told that in Poland, a journalist is still fighting for his life. He has not yet died, but may well be dead as a result of a cowardly attack on him, because he was also investigating possible guilty, greedy and powerful interests. The privatization of the state we are facing, where powerful mafia interests are subjecting legitimate public authorities, is a scourge that we must fight. We are witnessing the capture of states in Europe, which has been proven to be more than once, and this is not a state of affairs that is tolerable in the 21st century, nor the eternal intimidation of journalists, the denigrations of people who do their jobs. Mr Orbán, Prime Minister of Hungary, told us a few days ago that he knows: Mr Soros is behind Mr Kuciak's death. Can we fall down?
