How far can we go into an unacceptable political rhetoric that creates atmospheres in which people die and where every death like this is one death too much? (He agreed to answer a question “blue card” (rule 162, paragraph 8, of the rules of procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: question 'blue card'. — Dear colleague, do you not believe — and I listened very carefully — that we need at this time to strengthen the common European security services? Do you not think we need to set up a European Intelligence Agency? Not only against terrorism, but also against crime in Europe, because we see abominable things happening in Europe, Slovakia, Great Britain, everywhere.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: answer 'blue card'. — (FR) Dear colleague, I do not have the impression that the problem we are dealing with here is primarily a problem of existence or non—existence of a European agency. I am in favour of a European criminal police, some kind of European FBI. We will need it much earlier, I believe, than intelligence services or agencies, but here we have another problem, namely that the Slovak State is structurally — most likely — complicit in mafia interests. There is no European or national police agency that can change this state of affairs, and states must be re-independent in the sense of “not subject to mafia interests”.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, journalists and bloggers are being persecuted, both in the European Union and around the world, because they deal with the laundry of the economic oligarchy. They're putting out what's going on in tax havens. They display exploratory cases around money laundering and are therefore targeted. Daphne Caruana Galizia was murdered, as we know, in Malta, and now we have in Slovakia the assassination of Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová, and all this is because they investigated harsh economic interests. Indeed, in the case of Slovakia, they investigated how European money has been wasted, the funds relating to the common agricultural policy, where even the mafia is involved. It is obvious that all these cases need to be investigated and, at the same time, OLAF and the Committee on Budgetary Control check what is happening with European funds in Slovakia. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question under the 'blue card' procedure. — Madam President, dear colleague, you are right: the crime is horrible, not only against a journalist, against any man, but journalists, even more so, are exposed, as has been said here, due to investigations. Do you think that everything related to European funds, to spending public money in any Member State should be more transparent and subject to a public information system so that it can prevent crimes against journalists who expose the cover?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: answer to a blue-card question. — I agree with your remarks that the European Union must seriously control the waste of European Union money and Community fraud, and this concerns both the common agricultural policy and other funds. In this Chamber I have repeatedly said that the funds received by the various NGOs, which are supposed to be intended for refugees but which do not go there, must also be checked. There is a big party and I had asked for OLAF to intervene on all these issues, including the Committee on Budgetary Control. I think it is up to us to control the fraud that exists at European Union level around EU funds.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: — Madam President, the murder of a journalist is the highest attack on freedom of speech, an attack on democracy. This is what Slovak citizens understood and took to the streets to demonstrate against the power responsible for the murder of Ján Kuciak. Spark skipped from the East. Ukrainians in Majdan understood that they were ruled by the same who ruled under communism, that in their country the most flaming communists became the greatest and richest capitalists, the most powerful oligarchs. This was understood by Slovaks as well. Murder of a journalist was a sign. Tens of thousands of Slovaks in the streets begin to understand that the famous Czechoslovak Velvet Revolution of 1989 is not over. That it needed to be completed by all the democratic means it provided us. Majdan appears to have become migratory. Hungarians and Georgians, who have their oligarchs, also took to the streets. Czechs also took to the streets earlier in the year protesting that they were ruled by a former Czechoslovak KGB agent, a State Security agent, a former member of the Communist Party, now a wealthy oligarch and prime minister of the country and owner of influential media. Ladies and gentlemen, Central and Eastern Europe is bypassed by the shadow of popular resistance. Murdered Ján Kuciak fell in this fight. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by lifting the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the blue card. You describe a series of nations and scenarios in those nations that appear to be talking about something riddled with corruption and whole systems that don’t seem to work. Would you agree with me then that, if we are talking about huge sums of taxpayers’ money going through the EU to be distributed into these kind of systems, there is a basic flaw in the system, whereby you are actually slushing money into a system which is then being stolen, effectively, by criminal organisations, be they state sponsored or oligarchs?

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: answer to the question posed by lifting the blue card. — I was not looking for financial flows, I wanted to draw attention to the fact that our countries are still spiked by communists who control in our countries of the Eastern Bloc all essential political and economic posts. That's all I wanted to say.

name: David CASA
text: — Sinjura President, illum ana ningaqdu mal-poplu Slovakk u nikkundannaw bla ebda riżervi l-assassinju tal-urnalist Jan Kuciak. L-istat he' hawk democrazija timkejla fuq il-libertà u s-sigurtà tal-家urnalisti ta' dak il-pajjiż u fl-ewropa balissa dan l-istat mhuwiex wiedyed tajjeb. Sa ftit taż-żmien beauties frog qegdin niddiskutu l-assassinju tal-urnalista Maltija Daphne Caruana Galizia u ż-żewkażijiet huma simili, orzzjoni, abbuż ta' poter u kultura ta' impunità. Dak li entaara lil Jan u Daphne sfortunatament ma jistax jinbidel però dak li jista' jinbidel huwa l-protezzjon li noffru lill-urnalisti. L-abbuż minn sistemi legali biex titpo家a sarima ma' attenualq il-urnalisti m'gandu ebda post FL-unjon Ewropea u galhekk aohuna qed nitolbu lill-kummissjoni biex tipproponi liarijiet kontra l-użu ta' SLAP. Jiena nilqa' b'sodisfazzjon il-kliem tal-vito President Timmermens fejn qal li L-rubber sjon ser tadem biex tikkumbatti dan l-abbuż. Ejjew nonoraw il-memorja ta' Daphne u ta' Jan billi nkunu ana li nkomplu l-idma taghom u nipproteto u dak li huma kienu jissimbolizzaw.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Madam President! There is nothing clearer in this European Parliament than the fact that independent European investigations must be carried out together with the authorities in Slovakia. The issues on which journalist Kuciak has researched must be pursued consistently until the court hearing. It is about murder and mafia entanglement in Slovak politics and about corruption in connection with European funds. Full interference by the European Parliament is, of course, necessary here. Hence my respect for Manfred Weber, who demands this. Not only the demonstrations of the last few days, but also the Eurobarometer show that the Slovak people have more confidence in the EU than in their own authorities. Stop this game in Europe! Europol is well placed to do the work here. All of us in Europe have a responsibility to protect journalists as a superpower of democracy.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: — Madam President, the heinous murder of Jan Kuciak and his fiancee, Miss Kusnírová, has left a deep mark in Slovakia. I must say that a government that has in the past at least ten cauz — economic and political casualties — rejected under the carpet, declared these cases irrelevant, or that the deed did not happen, lost the trust of citizens. I must say that the citizens in Slovakia have taken to the streets because they no longer have confidence in this government. One hundred thousand citizens in thirty cities in Slovakia came out to demonstrate to express their will to turn Slovakia into a country of decent people. And this, I think, is necessary, and this is only possible if there are fundamental political changes in Slovakia and probably the collapse of the government and the election is being held. I am also in favour of both Europol and OLAF intervening in this matter and investigating together with the Slovak authorities.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Madam President, Commissioner, we agree that the murder of a journalist and his partner in Slovakia is a criminal attack on freedom of expression, which is the freedom to say what someone does not want to hear, and free communication, which is the freedom to publish what someone does not want to know. Especially when it comes to investigative journalists committed to fraud, tax evasion and corruption, which requires threats free journalists and jurists and lawyers free of threats. But it is also a mobster attack, which tells us about trans-European, pan-European mafia crime, which requires a European community — yes — of judicial cooperation, information and intelligence, against cross-border crime. And what we see is that the principle of mutual trust and mutual recognition, which makes possible judicial cooperation against cross-border mafia crime, is deteriorating. That is why I say quite clearly that, in the face of the pan-European mafia, there is a need for a pan-European response that protects, against organised crime, essential and foundational values of European construction.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: — I will admit that I am not in favor of external elements of demonstrating my own views in the form of shirts, placards, inscriptions. This time, however, I made an exception. I have made an exception precisely on this issue and for two reasons: firstly because we do not face inflation of such demonstrating views, and on the contrary, we show a definite attitude of the European Parliament to murder and to the attack on European Imselderabilia. Secondly, freedom, justice, democracy, respect for the law are the foundations, pillars of Europe, and if the European Parliament does not defend these values, it will be weaker or cease to function. I therefore call for special protection of the work of investigative journalists and war correspondents and to respond adequately to the situations we face.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, I led the mission to Malta following the assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia. I must say that I see very worrying parallels, and it’s not just because they were investigative journalists working to expose the corrupt and the captured, but it’s also because the investigations point out two mafiosi having done the professional job of assassinating both Daphne and Ján Kuciak and his partner. This is extremely worrying, and it is a reason why we absolutely must have Europol and OLAF not only associated with the investigation: they must co-lead the investigation. That’s exactly what we see, for instance, in Malta. The former Commissioner who was dismissed with a scathing report never faced charges and was actually made an adviser to the Prime Minister. What does the Commission have to say about that? The question of capture by the corrupt of our political establishments is the crucial question that must be addressed.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: — Madam President, young people should not die, and not like this at all. It is important for the Slovak Government that the deed is investigated and clarified as soon as possible. That's why an international investigative team will also be involved this week. Although we don't know the perpetrator, part of the opposition abuses the murder for political purposes. In an era of cyberattacks and fake news, such tendencies can be exploited to subvert democracy anywhere in Europe. Several false information has also been heard here today, for example, that the murdered journalist asked for protection and did not receive it. He didn't ask. On the contrary, a few days before his death, he said he did not believe anyone could attack a journalist in Slovakia. Fellow Members, in these difficult moments, we are relying on your support, solidarity and togetherness.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: — Madam President, the murder of young journalists is, of course, a heinous act. Equally heinous was the act when Oles Buzyna, an investigative journalist in Kiev, was murdered and we were silent. He was a person who had only a different opinion than our protégé Petro Poroshenko has. I trust the Slovak authorities. Several years ago, the constitutional judge of the Slovak Republic Ernest Valko, a friend of mine, was assassinated. His case was investigated, the perpetrators were found. I believe in this case, too, that will happen. In the context of the murder of young journalists, I ask myself the question: Have we together done enough to prevent such things from happening? Isn't the problem European, common? We should probably be more intent on how to work more together against money laundering, organised crime, how to protect journalists.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the murder of Slovak journalist Ján Kuciak and his partner has brought to light many pathogenesis which exist in the political systems of certain countries of the European Union. The most important of these is the corruption that exists at the highest levels of political leadership. In order to maintain its privileges, she does not hesitate to corrupt, manipulate and blackmail journalists who can expose her illegal activities. Those of the journalists who do not want to submit face various dangerous situations, sometimes their lives are threatened. What matters is that journalists should be left undistracted to do their work, because blackmail and attacks on them violate the principles of freedom of the press, which is a fundamental pillar of democracy. On the other hand, journalists must also respect their work and not persecute opponents on suggestion and on submission. I wish the blood of Ján Kuciak will be the last to be poured on the altar of independence of the press.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I would like to express my grief and solidarity both to the families of the victims and, of course, to all Slovak citizens. We don't really know who is the perpetrator of this heinous act, and we must insist on proper examination, I would like to underline that. However, doubts about the proper examination were expressed, for example, by the mother of one of the victims. I think it is the job of the Slovak authorities to dispel these doubts. I think that journalists must not be murdered in the European Union, it is a great disgrace to our community. I would like to remind the dictionary of Prime Minister Fico in those last decades. He actually remains, in my opinion, in this dictionary somewhere in the Far East and I think he indirectly could have legitimized the attacks that were on journalists. I think it is important to say that these attacks could have legitimised even Prime Minister Fico's expression. For me, it is important that the examination is actually guaranteed by the European authority as well, that is, Europol. It's our shared responsibility.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the brutal killing of Ján Kuciak and his companion, which took place six months after another execution, that of Daphne Caruana Galizia, journalists both of whom they had reported cases of corruption and fraud in their countries, they are not only efferate crimes, but real attacks on freedom of the press, the right of citizens to know the truth and therefore to democracy itself. For these reasons, in the face of such dramatic episodes, thorough investigations are necessary, with the utmost impartiality to clarify the responsibilities and causes of such murders. But more generally, and precisely to prevent threats, retaliation and efferate attacks, that is why freedom, independence and pluralism of the media must be protected, finally establishing a regulatory framework European to protect whistleblowers and journalists who are too often, even today, forced to report abuse and corruption, to expose themselves and their family members to serious risks.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: — Madam President, the situation in Slovakia is tense. The political crisis that came after the murder of journalist Jan Kuciak and his partner points to the dark side of democracy. This tragedy pointed out that the current Slovak government is unable to solve problems that traumatise Slovak society. Unfortunately, these are the same problems that the young murdered journalist pointed out. Corruption, clientelism, and even suspicions of linking government power to organized crime. The Slovak public is rightly concerned and outraged. But she's also determined to show her civic stance on this critical situation. Whatever has been said in this debate, the truth is that Robert Fico's government has so far failed to restore confidence and gain the confidence of either the Slovak or European public, even in matters of justice and independence of the investigation into this unprecedented premeditated murder. The European Parliament must respond clearly at this point. The murder of a journalist is an attack on freedom of expression and the foundations of democracy not only in Slovakia but throughout the Union. In this situation, we should stand together, say no and contribute to making such heinous acts never happen again.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Madam President, I think we have heard a lot of words of criticism here, and I think maybe we should take some lessons from this case of Ján Kuciak and some optimism to work. We should say to ourselves one thing that still stands, that truth will someday triumph over lies and hatred. And if this death reminds us of this message and if we take away from it that we wake up, we will stop as politicians criticizing journalists for their work and stop being latent to when a politician criticizes and threatens journalists, I think it's a thing that can serve for all states within the European Union. It's not the first death, before that was the death of a female journalist in Malta. It is necessary for freedom of speech, for democracy and for journalists to work, to fight constantly. Because he who sleeps in a democracy wakes up once in totalitarianism.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: — Il-Qtil tal-urnalist Ján Kuciak ftit xhur biss wara l-qtil ta' Daphne Caruana Galizia jqajjem il-kwistjoni serja ta' kemm il-midja hija prothe fl-ewropa. Iqajjem il-kwistjoni li ssemmiet minn diversi kelliema dwar kemm qed inShoarsu lill-urnalisti investigattivi. Naturalment lili jolqotni wkoll il-fatt tal-iżviluppi politio differenti FIS-Slovakkja u f'Malta gЂaliex, FIS-Slovavakkja kellek ir-riżenja l-ewwel tal-ministru tal-kultura, issa wkoll ir-riżenja tal-vithe Prim Ministru responsai bbli mill-intern u l-fatt li Maltese baqa' gaddej “business as usual” qisu s'issa minkejja li gshort ad ma nafux min ordna l-qtil ta' Daphne Caruana Galizia qisu kollox irridu nqisuh bthe ala xi envelava normali. Kontra dawk kollha li riedu jaglqu entalq il-alq il-enurnalisti rridu nwasslu l-messashort short er li dan il-parlament qieged hawn biex jiddefendi d-dritt tal-libertà tal-espressjoni, mhux biss tal-urnalisti kolma tal-popli lha; tal-poplu Malti li tilef l-informazzjon kollha li kienet tagtih Daphne, tal-poplu Slovak li tilef l-informazzjon kollha li kien jagtih Ján Kuciak.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, the murder of Ján and Martina was understood by citizens in Slovakia as an attack on freedom of speech and understood it correctly. And if their death is to make any sense, then it must not happen so that this murder is not investigated. Citizens in the Czech Republic also understood the need to defend themselves and freedom of speech should be defended, therefore today in Prague and other places of the Czech Republic people will manifest and to express condolences for the death of the Slovak journalist and his girlfriend. It is also because even in the Czech Republic President Miloš Zeman attacks the media and freedom of speech. The Czech president also brushed about the media, including public television, in his recent inaugural address. Populists in our country entice citizens to nationalise public media in exchange for forgiveness of concessionary fees. Ladies and gentlemen, it is up to us, politicians, Members of the European Parliament, to stand for freedom of speech.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this is an important debate. I very much welcome Parliament’s support – the support that all of you have expressed – for getting to the bottom of this case as rapidly as possible. I recall that Europol deployed its support team to Slovakia on 28 February. They are there to provide on the spot support and assistance to the Slovak investigation and to share their specialist knowledge of investigative, technical and forensic methods. I reiterate that we call upon the Slovak authorities to engage fully with OLAF in order to find out whether this case does indeed involve misuse of EU funds with a cross—border dimension. These are very important matters and we will not rest until we get to the bottom of them. I have heard the calls from several of you to look again at the arrangements for scrutiny on rule of law matters and indeed, in some cases, to look at potential legislation. I will pursue that with colleagues, but the Commission does remain completely committed to the fight against corruption through a series of targeted initiatives, through the scrutiny that we carry out in the European Semester, and through our practical and financial support for a wide range of projects in the field of anti-corruption. I repeat again that we will be coming forward with a legislative initiative to strengthen the protection of whistle—blowers at the EU level. We agree that whistle—blowers who unveil illegal activities play an important role, including as sources of information for journalists, and we agree that protecting whistle—blowers from retaliation is crucial for safeguarding investigative journalism. So we will return to that.  This horrible crime is, as a number of you have said, unfortunately not an isolated case. There have been other attacks against journalists, in particular investigative journalists, and that clearly calls for a collective response from all of us, because freedom of expression and a free media are anchors of our democracies. So to all those who seek to undermine our democratic values and to those who want to silence independent voices, in particular in the media, we need to send a strong signal. We will not be intimidated or silenced. We will speak up and protect the values that we hold so dear.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me assure you that the Council attaches great importance to the protection of journalists and the defence of media freedom. We are all shocked by the appalling circumstances surrounding the death of Mr Ján Kuciak and Ms Martina Kušnírová. Our words of condemnation must now be followed by a strong response from the law-enforcement authorities. We are confident that the Slovakian law enforcement authorities, assisted by Europol as well as teams from several countries, will be capable of upholding the rule of law in the face of this brutal murder. I can assure the House that the Council has taken careful note of the views the honourable Members have expressed here today, and this is a very important issue for us.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place in the next part-session. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Eugen FREUND
text: in writing. — Media and freedom of the press are the cornerstones of democracy. As a former journalist, I am therefore particularly struck by the murder of Ján Kuciak and his partner Martina Kušnírová. Kuciak had information about a network of Calabrian 'Ndrangheta, which is supposed to reach the highest Slovak government. The murder is in all likelihood due to his research. Unfortunately, this is not an isolated case, because in the recent past there have been some such cases. This fact once again reflects the importance of protecting journalists. Until the double homicide, Slovakia was also considered a flagship country from a political point of view with regard to the neighbouring countries of Poland and Hungary. The fact that the Slovak Minister of the Interior Kaliňák resigned a few days ago raises some questions that need to be answered, precisely because Kuciak is also said to have investigated Kaliňák. Slovakia is now in a deep government crisis and needs to restore stability. This can only be achieved if the murder of Ján Kuciak and his partner is fully investigated.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the joint discussion on፦ the report by Alain Lamassoure, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a Council directive on a common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB) (COM (2016) 0683 - C8-0471/2016 - 2016/0336 (CNS)) (A8-0051/2018), and - the report by Paul Tang, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a Council Directive on a common corporate tax base (COM (2016) 0685 - C8-0472/2016 - 2016/0337 (CNS)) (A8-0050/2018).

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, the CCCTB project has two major political objectives. For businesses, it offers a single tax space for the most important tax. This means simplicity, justice, equal conditions of competition. For the Member States, this is the only way to put an end to the temptation to see some reinvent national laws which amount to stealing tax matters from neighbouring countries. Tax competition is legitimate. It must also apply the rules and principles that we apply in all the other areas of the single market: transparency, loyalty and fairness. Regarding taxation, the European Parliament, unfortunately, does not have the right of amendment. That is why the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal of Paul Tang and myself, wanted to focus on three major policy recommendations. First, the project needs its two legs: harmonization, consolidation. All the companies we consulted are categorical about this: the single common basis would bring more complications without the advantage of the common tax space. Secondly, if there is a common European system, it must apply to all companies, regardless of the sector, regardless of size. Finally, thirdly, this project is an ideal opportunity to address the problem of taxation of digital activities and, in particular, the particular economic model of service platforms. These platforms have been around for ten years now. The time has come for tax law to take into account their existence and peculiarities. For example, Google and Facebook have tens of millions of subscribers in my country and pay no taxes. Our European Parliament will be the first political institution in the world to put concrete proposals on the table. We look forward to what the Commission — Commissioner, next week — and the OECD will then propose. I would like to make a political clarification. At the initiative of France, another digital taxation project currently occupies specialized media and services. This is another, simpler and faster approach, a tax on sales or some of the commercial revenues of digital companies. Careful! This project, presented as having the flexibility and speed of a feline, will still have the duration of gestation of a pachyderm and it will give birth, at best, a mouse, bringing a handful of billions of euros a year. In addition, like any indirect tax, the actual burden will be borne not by the taxpayer company, but by its customers, with a risk of double taxation. Let no one be mistaken! The real tax revolution will not be a short-lived pocket recipe, but the harmonization of the whole of corporate taxation. Our great predecessors dreamed it, it is up to us to achieve it.

name: Paul TANG
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, it is good to be here. This week, the Financial Times reported that corporate tax rates have been falling ever further since the crisis, and it raises the question of sovereignty. The only sovereignty the Member States currently have is to lower the tax rate, whereas I would think that if countries had a choice, they could not just decrease, but also increase the tax rates. The proposal that the European Parliament discusses today is a real game-changer. It changes the nature of tax competition. Let’s start with consolidation. Consolidation is the principle that firms no longer decide where to make profits and pay taxes, but it is up to the countries to decide where they make profits and where they pay taxes. It puts an end to profit-shifting. This reduces the pressure towards lower tax rates within the EU. But we also need a profit border control, and that has been included in a proposal by the European Parliament as well. Controlled Foreign Corporation (CFC) rules and switch—over rules – it sounds a bit technical but what it amounts to is very simple: if a tax rate in a country outside EU is lower than 50% the Member States have the right to tax extra, according to the statutory rights. This is a border control that we need to have in place. Reducing the pressure on marginal tax rates and making sure that we let multinationals pay their fair share. That’s what people ask from us. The second important element in the proposal is taxing the digital economy, which has long been overdue and should have been done much earlier. We have made calculations that Google and Facebook didn’t pay 5 billion in taxes over a three-year period, because we are working with an outdated corporate tax system. That is a problem. The current corporate tax systems are outdated. They come from a time with chimneys and blue-collar workers. But globalisation and digitalisation has changed things. And location has become a choice, something that is particularly true for the tech giants, which have no physical presence but are very present in our lives. And in this way, they avoid paying taxes in large, high-tariff countries and reduce their tax bill. Third, and I think this is a very clear statement from the European Parliament, we think that the current proposal amounts to a simple and robust corporate tax system. It should not just apply to the large corporates, but should be extended to include all firms. So we need a lower threshold to give benefits and bring a level playing field to all the firms within Europe. I hope very much that the European Parliament will tomorrow give a very clear signal that, despite all the political differences we have, we can agree that we want a fair, efficient and modern corporate tax system for the 21st century. That could be the signal for the countries to start debating this. I very much hope that especially the large countries, Germany and France, will put pressure on the smaller countries, countries like the Netherlands, Ireland, Malta, Luxembourg that are the pirates within the European Union. They come to another country and try to appropriate these countries’ tax base. These are not the actions of a European partner. A fair and efficient tax system in the 21st century is what we need. I call on the support of the European Parliament but I also call on the countries to restore their sovereignty and back up these proposals in this year.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. — (FR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to take part in this debate today, your debate on the common consolidated corporate tax base. A debate that is the culmination of Parliament's truly remarkable work on this subject. I would particularly like to stress the unwavering commitment of rapporteurs Paul Tang and Alain Lamassoure to explain, to promote the benefits of the CCCTB throughout Europe. They did not just do it here in this chamber, they have, as they say in French, “wet the shirt”. CCCTB's proposal is much more than just a technical adjustment. It raises the question of the taxation we want to build in Europe for the years to come and, as Paul Tang has just said, in truth, corporate taxation in the 21st century that we are now going to debate, namely fairer taxation, more effective taxation, more attractive, rather than maintaining divides national and administrative burdens, and in the end a race to the least tax, of which no one ever emerges as a winner. There is an urgent need because other economies, we know them, are developing their own tax strategy — to put it frankly, we have seen it with the US tax reform. What will Europe's reaction be? Are we just going to rely on the Member States, in the name of the principle of fiscal sovereignty? If we do, we may lead to contradictory national reactions without a long-term vision, and again everyone loses it. Rather, I think that we have everything to gain and all to gain from defining a collective strategy at the level of the European Union with a real impact on the international scene. This is what the readjusted CCCTB project I presented in October 2016, a fundamental project that breaks down, as you know, into two proposals: the establishment of a common corporate tax base and its consolidation. In saying this, I immediately reply to Alain Lamassoure that I agree with him, that doing things in two stages does not mean that we split them but that one precedes the other and that one cannot go without the other. These are the three “C” of CCCTB (CCCTB, in French) that the Commission proposes. If this breakdown has been done for pragmatic reasons, I would like to point out that it is crucial to move forward on both fronts at the same time and that is very clearly what companies want this modern tax system expect from us. The CCCTB will, above all, promote the growth and competitiveness of the European Union, which is what it is about. It will support and attract businesses and investors into a genuine single tax market by removing national barriers and simplifying administrative procedures. It will also offer fairer taxation, in which taxes will finally be paid where the profit is generated, and we know that this demand for fairness is absolutely major and massive for our fellow citizens. Finally, it responds to the legitimate concerns of all those who, for years, have been revolted by scandals created by repeated tax evasion and also by condemnable tax optimization practices. The CCCTB will remove asymmetries between national systems, which are currently being exploited by those engaged in aggressive tax planning. It will also eliminate — Paul Tang pointed out — transfer pricing and preferential regimes, which are today the main drivers of tax evasion. Of course — and Alain Lamassoure made this link — I cannot introduce this debate without mentioning the taxation of digital companies, a subject that is in all minds. We will indeed talk about it at the end of week in Buenos Aires at the G20 Finance. We will look at the OECD's work in this area. What is it about? Companies offer more and more online services, while our tax system is always based on the principles of a national, industrial economy, where we know the centres of decision making, where we locate physical presence. This is a pre-Internet era that is now largely bygone and let us be aware that more and more the information economy, the technological economy and the economy are going to be confused, as our companies are incorporating more and more data into their business. That is why I very strongly welcome the European Parliament's proposal to define the digital permanent establishment, which is a necessary move towards modern and fairer taxation. I also welcome your willingness to introduce a numerical factor in the tax allocation key. We will naturally have to analyze its definition carefully, but the direction seems to me good. As I have already said before this House several times, I remain convinced that with the CCCTB we have the powerful tool and even the optimal tool to introduce, in a structural way, this taxation of digital businesses into the corporate tax rules of the 21st century. At the same time, other more targeted measures are also being studied, although — I tell Alain Lamassoure and I echo what he said — I still believe that the real reform is structural reform, it is the introduction of the digital presence in the consolidated common corporate tax base. But on 21 March, I will also make more specific or more targeted proposals on digital taxation by presenting two texts simultaneously. On the one hand, a proposal to revise the corporate tax rules, to take into account the new forms with the objective of incorporating this new text into the CCCTB — i mentioned it — but also a more specific proposal, which will apply until a revision of the corporate tax rules allows profits to be taxed where value is actually created. I will nevertheless have at heart — I tell Alain Lamassoure — to avoid the risks of double taxation and also this pachydermal approach that gives birth to a mouse of which he spoke nicely. We have to find and there are ways to find a smart third way, and that is what the Commission will try to propose next week with enough ambition to, indeed, reach digital companies and also enough finesse to reach consensus, because a good tax proposal is the one that makes it possible to to create a consensus so that it can be adopted under the conditions we know, that is, at 28. In conclusion, I call on the Member States to remain ambitious in this rostrum because the challenge is considerable: it is nothing less than the definition of a true European tax model. I am glad that the Bulgarian Presidency is treating this subject with priority, not in this Chamber but in general. A good advance in the discussions could lead to an agreement before the end of our joint mandate, the mandate of this European Parliament and the mandate of the European Commission. I hope that after solid work under the Bulgarian presidency, we can reach an agreement under the Austrian Presidency, so before the end of this year. That seems to me a reasonable and desirable objective. You can count on my determination to do everything possible to ensure that this goal is met. I hear here or there the Cassanders announce that this project will never succeed, that it is a sea snake that has already been blocked for seven years. To these pessimists, the optimist I am would like to give an example taken in the latest news to restore hope. Yesterday, at the Ecofin Council, the finance ministers agreed — yes, at 28! — to impose new transparency rules on intermediaries, such as banks, lawyers, other advisers on the tax arrangements they create, and the European Parliament voted on this subject by an overwhelming majority a few weeks ago. This is a major step forward for the transparency revolution that I have called for since taking office and for which I am fighting alongside you. This is one more step, it is another victory that reinforces my determination to reach an agreement on the CCCTB, but if I mention that it is not to highlight a success, it is simply to say that we did it in nine months, not nine years, but nine months. It means that when you want and when you put some political energy on a subject, you can. Dear friends, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced, listening to your rapporteurs, that you want it and, whenever you want, we can. Now, let's go to the debate!

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici. We have enough mice already. Some big, beautiful, successful animals, that would be it. As bulky as it sounds, the common consolidated corporate tax base is at the heart of tax fairness in Europe. This is the only way we can make taxes really paid where profits are generated. However, as the European Parliament we are going one step further. With the digital establishment, we also want to get Internet multinationals to pay their taxes in the future. I would also like to take responsibility for the Austrian Government here. I expect consolidated corporate income tax to be top priority in the coming presidency of the Council, because anyone who says yes to Google tax must also say yes to the common corporate tax base, the basis for tax fairness. Congrats Paul Tang and Alain Lamassoure: You have done a great job!

name: Markus FERBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. One of the key points that makes it easier for companies to operate aggressive tax planning within the European Union is simply the fact that we still have 28 tax systems. That is why it is right to start with the authorities with a uniform tax base in order to help ensure that the tax is actually paid and that trickery is made more difficult. Taxation of digital companies has already been mentioned. I think this is very, very important, because our corporate tax law still comes from a physical establishment where something is produced in real terms. In the digital age, however, this is not always the case. The plant is somewhere, where a server is located, but not necessarily where the value is added. And I think it is very worth mentioning that we are going ahead here and not waiting for the OECD to make proposals. However, I would also like to point out for tomorrow's vote that we will keep what we worked out together in committee — for which I am also really grateful to the rapporteurs — so too. I don't think we can move forward with ideology here. The fact that research costs can be deducted, but not from financial institutions, is very driven by ideology. I believe that we cannot agree to a lowering of the thresholds. And it is also clear that we should restrain ourselves on the issue of tax rates, which is the competence of the Member States. My appeal would be: let us agree with each other what we worked out in committee! Then we have a serious proposal for the Council.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Paul and Alain for this important report, which was expected by civil society, because, of course, all our citizens have suffered the various tax scandals — LuxLeaks, Panama Papers, and so on. All these scandals have one thing in common, that is the fact that large multinationals do not pay taxes by playing on the 28 tax systems in the Union. However, whether we are a citizen, an SME or a multinational company, it is normal, fair and ethical for everyone to contribute, according to their income, to life in society, because it is tax that finances social security, health care, schools, public transport, infrastructure or, even, the development of our economy. This was evidently and outrageously forgotten by many multinationals. The result is that, every year, European states lose 1 trillion in tax revenues. It is, of course, unbearable! The aim of the two directives we are discussing today is to achieve an identical definition of taxable profit in European countries, in order to put an end to the play of multinationals who seek to take advantage of the differences between our tax systems in the Union. Specifically, this CCCTB project proposes that there should be only one place of taxation, one contact with a tax authority for all multinationals operating in the Union. Initially, only large companies with more than 500 million turnover will be affected, but Parliament strengthened the directive proposed by the Commission, extending the scope of this directive to all companies within seven years. I think it's a good thing. With this text, companies engaged in cross-border activities will have to comply with a single European system to determine taxable income, rather than different national regimes in which the activity is carried out. We have also introduced measures to tax digital businesses, which, too, must contribute to their fair share, given the enormous profits made. These two directives should therefore, in part, address current concerns about corporate taxation. One downside, unfortunately, is the fact that we are not able to agree on a minimum tax rate. However, this tax rate would allow for real tax harmonisation at European level and should reduce intra-European competition, which is too strong at present. Commissioner, we are counting on you for this important issue. (He agreed to answer a question “blue card” (rule 162, paragraph 8, of the rules of procedure)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I listened with interest. You talk about tax harmonisation and, obviously, less competition on tax, which will mean that tax rates inevitably will go up, I would suggest. Are you not concerned that, if tax rates across the EU are higher, that would inevitably lead to large companies upping sticks and moving their operations into more competitive tax environments outside of the EU, and therefore we all lose out because we lose the jobs, the business and the wealth?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: answer 'blue card'. — (FR) Madam President, this is going to be very short, because I think my colleague has not yet understood much about tax evasion. We have been given the same element for years. No, it is impossible for a multinational company to deprive itself of one of the largest markets in the world — 500 million consumers. When we all agree to impose higher tax rates, they will stay with us because they cannot do without our European market. And I am not available to multinationals.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Just for the avoidance of doubt, I will only accept one blue card per speaker, because otherwise the time delays will be too large. That's why we're going to the next speaker now.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, I want every European country to be able to attract businesses and create jobs. I want the small Member States to have a chance too and not everything goes to the big Member States. I want countries to remain competent for taxation and we therefore stress that the European Union is a platform for cooperation and not a country, and therefore it is not up to the European Union to introduce taxes. For all these reasons, I am against these proposals for the CCTB and for a CCCTB. I know that these terms, CCTB and so on, sound rather dry and technical and like an accounting language, but they are not. This goes much further. This is going much more fundamental. This is about our fiscal policy and the end of it. This is about a transfer from small to large Member States, because that is what companies will do. They will shift their business, their profits and their jobs from smaller, innovative economies to the larger economies in the European Union. To France and Germany, because there are more factories there, because there is a larger market there. We oppose it. Fortunately, we're not alone. There are also a number of other delegations that do so. I am surprised that the Socialiste Parti supports this proposal, which apparently prefers jobs in Germany and France to jobs with us in Flanders, Wallonia and Brussels. I know where our priorities are. That's with our people and our economy.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, for years we have been advocating a level playing field and fair taxation. The CCCTB is a very important step in this direction. So today I would like to ask you to support this report. Finally, the taxable base will be the same throughout the European Union, with one aim in mind: taxing value where it is created. However, it is not our intention to eliminate competition between Member States. On the contrary, creating a level playing field will lead to competition in mainly three areas: workers, infrastructure and tax rates. This will strengthen the competitiveness of our Member States and, ultimately, that of the whole European Union. As an icing on the cake, our companies will have to take into account only one system, rather than 27 different ones, which will significantly reduce the administrative burden. This single system is also a strong basis for taxing digital giants such as Facebook, Google and Amazon. Moreover, it creates a framework to arm ourselves against attacks on our European tax revenues by third countries. To sum up, the CCCTB represents more revenue that will be borne by a broader base and a stronger Union in the world. It's a historic opportunity. I therefore hope that the Council will take our advice to heart and deliver results quickly. (The speaker answered a blue card question (Rule 162 (8)).)

name: Sander LOONES
text: 'blue card' question. — Mrs Wierinck, interesting to hear your speech. We all know that as a party you are traditionally in favour of proposals for more and more Europe. I just want to ask you a question. You saw the vote in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. There was a minority vote among a number of interesting parties, such as the CDA, but also small parties from small Member States: Denmark, Finland, etc. Their argument is very clear: what is on the table is not good for small Member States, but it will shift jobs to large countries. You're not afraid of that? You either conduct yourselves, or we have a policy together to create jobs in Belgium. But these jobs will be shifted to Germany, for example.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: 'blue card' answer. — No, I am not afraid of that. We are indeed going to create funds where value is created. It is important that all Member States should be allowed to receive the fair taxes that will be created by the CCTB. I'm not afraid of it at all. This is a fair tax and will ensure that large multinationals and other companies start paying their taxes as the little man has to pay them.

name: Eva JOLY
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, the solution to corporate tax evasion has one name: the CCCTB, the common consolidated corporate tax base. Behind this obscure acronym is a tax revolution. No more profit transfers from one subsidiary and country to another to avoid tax! This reform adapts our tax system to the realities of our time. Multinationals will finally be taxed as a single entity in Europe and tax will be paid where their business actually takes place, including for digital companies such as Google or Amazon, which will be taxed based on where they offer their services, not just in the country where they set up their headquarters. But tax evasion has its accomplices, it is the national governments, which have been blocking this reform for seven years now. I tell them: that's enough! Let them stop their hypocrisy, who pretend indignation with every new tax scandal. Place to action! That is what citizens are asking for. If our governments are unable to agree on this essential reform, I call on the European Commission to use the powers at its disposal by proposing that this text be passed by qualified majority rather than unanimity. The use of Article 116 of the Treaty falls under its responsibility. Let her take it to advance tax justice, as President Juncker promised us. Who refuses to act against tax evasion destroys Europe!

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. The obligation of ownership is not only a proverb, but also in the German Basic Law. Article 14 (2) states, and I quote: 'Ownership is obliged to use it for the public at the same time'. But far too often this duty has become a false voluntary. The tax scandals from LuxLeaks to the Panama Papers and the Paradise Papers, which the European Parliament will, as we know, will be debating in a special committee, are still on everyone's lips and have caused legitimate outrage. Because they have shown that Google, Apple, McDonald's, Facebook, Starbucks and whatever their name may bounce the states by hundreds of billions of euros a year. That is why, as the Left, we welcome the fact that we are working here at European level on overall corporate taxation, which should no longer allow groups to shift their profits from A to B in order to avoid tax payments at the expense of the general good. We see this as a right step away from a non-functioning tax system. As always, the devil is in the details here too. Indeed, the lax rules contained in the text still allow companies to shift their profits to non-European subsidiaries. This opens the door to further tax avoidance practices. In addition, no minimum tax rate is foreseen and we believe that this will exacerbate tax dumping competition. No one has anything of this except those companies that continue to refuse to fulfil their obligations as a whole. Well meant is not well done by a long time!

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, tax harmonisation: an attack on the principles of competition and national sovereignty. Of course, if you can eradicate competition you can raise taxes all across the EU, which is actually what you want to do. You seek to rush in this new, fiendishly complex scheme so it may even affect the UK during the dreaded transitional period. The committee even wants to reduce the threshold for this, from EUR 750 million a year down to zero, over a seven-year period. We need simpler taxes that can be set at a national level and encourage competition, not an effort to stifle competition. By removing the chance for nation states to compete on tax, you inevitably increase tax levels and make us all less competitive.  What is the impact of this? Companies fleeing the high-tax, regulation-filled EU could move elsewhere. Smaller EU countries which currently manage to actually prop up their economies by being competitive on tax, such as Ireland, will be penalised. Of course, when tax is increased, the whole economy of all of the EU will be suppressed and held down by this wet blanket of desire to control and to tax all the time. I hope that the UK adopts a very competitive position on corporation tax policy post—Brexit. I would like to see us competing as an island off the coast of the EU that gives a real competitive advantage to business, that says: we want you here; we want wealth creators here; we are a friendly nation to people who want to make money and we are not like the EU, which is addicted to endless taxation so that they can spend on huge schemes. We, in the UK, should favour business, growth and employment.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, combating the leakage of the tax revenues of multinationals, particularly US multinationals in the digital economy, is the top priority of the National Front. Evasion, optimization and tax evasion cost the French state almost 100 billion euros in revenue per year. Mr Moscovici, without these revenue losses, France would have budgetary surpluses. The functioning of the European Union is the direct cause of this destructive tax dumping. Thanks to the active complicity of several Member States, such as Ireland and Luxembourg, companies like Apple manage to pay an effective tax on their profits in the European Union, which is close to zero — a direct consequence of globalism. We support many aspects of the Tang and Lamassoure reports, especially on the concept of digital permanent establishment. This solution solves the difficulty that arises from the intangible aspect of the cross-border digital economy. We also support the formula for the allocation of the taxable base presented in the Lamassoure report. This would allow the effective redistribution of the taxable tax base to those States where economic activity is actually carried out. On the other hand, we are not in favour of removing the 750 million turnover threshold, which would concern too many companies and not just large multinationals. Just as we are opposed to the federalization of these new tax revenues, which naturally belong to the States. It is for these last two reasons that we will vote for abstention. But the National Front supports the struggle of the big European states against tax vampirisation carried out by US digital multinationals with the complicity of a few small states in the European Union!

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, I wonder if I might just remind the Chamber that the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base was first attempted and shelved in 2011, and it is hard to understand, or even identify, what has fundamentally changed since then. A little bit of risk analysis here: we do have two Member States, Ireland and the Netherlands, who currently shelter the big internet giants and who do give them a certain amount of tax advantage. But the risk analysis for them is: are they actually going to support this, and are there other countries that are as yet unidentified that might react in a similar way?  I am just going to return for a moment to this aspect of tackling American companies. We talked this morning about Trump and what he is doing in terms of protectionism. Has anyone done the risk analysis of what might happen if we implement this? Equally, remember that the big entrants in the market are now China and India. Are we actually sending a message to them that they are not wanted in the European Union?

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: - Madam President! In this House, we have repeatedly called for taxes to be paid where value is created. And I therefore welcome the draft directive for a common tax base for corporations. I believe that there cannot be an effective, efficient and single market when individual Member States apply different tax bases, different rules for deducting various cost elements from tax and thus introduce very significant distortions into the mechanism competition. On this, we should really speak with one voice. A single tax base across the European Union market should not be an element of tax competition between countries, but should instead be an element of facilitating the activity of the single market. On the other hand, I want to stress very clearly that I am against the harmonisation of tax rates. We often hear, especially from the left of the hall, calling for tax rates to be unified. I want to say to all colleagues who make these types of proposals that, as long as we do not have a unified or level-level of development of individual Member States, we cannot have uniform tax rates. Taxes are a burden on the enterprise. In exchange for these burdens, companies receive certain services from the state. In some countries, the level of services provided to businesses is obviously lower and we should take that into account. Therefore, on the harmonisation of rates — no, while in terms of harmonising the tax base — yes.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: — Madam President, the new technologies and the development of aggressive tax optimization practices of large companies make the system for calculating and collecting corporate profits tax lapses and make it necessary to set up a common consolidated base in Europe. Our corporate tax systems were designed for an economy in which businesses had a physical place in a local or national market, which does not take into account the development of the single market or the growth of the digital economy. The principles of common sense, according to which a company must pay taxes where it generates profit is crumbling. That is why we look forward to seeing this project on the table today. It comes from afar, it could be revived thanks to the erosion of corporate tax bases or the multiplication of scandals, whether it was the case of Apple who paid only 0.005% tax on profit in a country where tax was already very low, to the tune of 12.5%, or the LuxLeaks scandal that revealed how much of the agreements concluded between Luxembourg and Luxembourg and multinationals such as Amazon severely limited the possibility of taxation. However, we are also pleased that, under the leadership of your rapporteur and our Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, we now have the definition of a permanent digital institution. This is a great step forward for those who actually want to tax digital. On the basis of this proposal for a tax... (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: – Madam President, one of the areas the EU is not meant to interfere in is that of national tax sovereignty, yet here we have not one but two reports, Tang and Lamassoure, that propose EU tax harmonisation by harmonising the corporate tax base. Indeed, they set a floor – a base level below which corporation taxes cannot be set. Will that floor be 33% as in France? President Macron has called for a binding, harmonised range of tax rates, backed by a penalty of lost cohesion funding if it is not followed. This is simply tax trespass. Pity poor Ireland with its 12.5% corporation tax. Mr Varadkar, stop exaggerating border issues for your EU paymasters and wake up to EU proposals that threaten your entire economy! For the EU proposes to abolish unanimous votes – so bye-bye to the Irish veto. Will plans to consolidate taxes, to share them round the whole EU, end all national budget control? That fits with the proposed eurozone Common Finance Minister. A common corporate tax base is simply an … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: – Madam President, if there is a strong political will in this House to achieve fairer taxation, it makes sense to deal with both CCTB and the consolidation file together. It is high time to deliver. According to a Financial Times analysis, big multinational companies are paying significantly less tax than before the 2008 financial crisis, with companies’ effective tax rates falling by 9% since then.  These proposals are the remaining missing pieces for the EU to fight tax avoidance. They will further strengthen our internal market and improve our tax system, which the TAXE and PANA committees have proved is necessary to counter aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance.  Taxation should take place where the value is created. Too often this natural principle is not respected. Parliament’s position also addresses a specific loophole in our taxation system: the digital dimension. Again, we used a very simple principle. Digital businesses in the EU without a physical establishment have to be treated in the same way as businesses having one in the EU. It is up to the Member States to find an agreement which responds to the need to keep up with rapid globalisation development. I therefore call on the Member States to join us in this renewed initiative to create a fairer tax environment for the benefit of fairer competition and, above all, the citizens.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Madam President, it is often pointed out that tax dumping in the European Union is based on the nominal corporation tax rate, which is indeed a problem, and therefore we must move towards harmonisation of that nominal rate. But there is not so much talk about the problem of dumping from the calculation of the tax base, which also functions as a central element of tax dumping in the European Union. And that is why this proposal — the BICCIS — to harmonise and consolidate corporation tax is so important: that there are common rules on the calculation of that taxable amount, a tax levying all the activities of multinationals throughout the European Union, and also that the question of digital companies and how they pay taxes, because, in the end, what we are talking about with these measures is to regain fiscal sovereignty. The fiscal sovereignty that Member States have at the moment is simply the sovereignty of lowering taxes. To recover fiscal sovereignty, to make multinationals pay at once — not as is happening now, as we have seen in the recent Financial Times report — is to harmonise taxation at European Union level, and this proposal is very, very important.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, it is clear that the current system of taxing multinational corporations isn’t working. The so-called ‘arm’s length’ principle is out of date and ineffective. But for unity in taxation to work effectively as a means to end profit shifting, it needs to be global. My main concern is that Member States are being asked to transfer further powers to the Commission in exchange for the promise that this new system will end the ability of multinationals to shift profits, but shortcomings in the proposal mean that this goal is unlikely to be achieved. Profit shifting outside of the EU is not addressed at all and it will actually increase the incentive for multinationals to shift profits outside the EU. By creating a common tax base across the EU, the proposal will, in fact, promote a race to the bottom on tax rates because the headline rate itself will be the only measure left for Member States to compete on. The Irish Government has signalled its concerns over this proposal and, no doubt, will continue to do so. But, at the same time, the Irish Government needs to act now to end the dangerous and unsustainable situation in which it actively markets the Irish state as a tax avoidance hub and in which our public finances are severely over-reliant on the corporation tax receipts of a handful of multinationals. We need tax justice, we need tax fairness and we need national tax sovereignty. There is no reason why we cannot achieve all of these things.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Commissioner. The European Union's public budgets lose around €70 billion of tax revenues each year due to aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance. This is primarily a reduction in corporate income tax. These two reports under discussion today, which seek to harmonise the corporate tax base, are intended to close this gap in terms of revenue. In addition to VAT and income tax, corporation tax is one of the most important tax areas. The aim of CCTB and CCTTB is to create simpler tax rules for the calculation of cross-border tax profit and better comparability, eliminate differences and discrepancies in the tax base, and to create fair conditions of competition, in particular between multinationals and SMEs. without jeopardising the Member States' tax sovereignty. In order to achieve the highest possible multinational effectiveness of these two reports, these two areas, these two areas should be in line with the requirements of the OECD PEPS actions and the international accounting directives under IFRSs — at least as the Commission proposal envisaged. The European Parliament has made some changes here, namely to zero the threshold for the mandatory application of the EUR 750 million directive over a period of seven years, eliminating the possibility of unlimited loss carryovers, massively reducing the charge of R & D expenditure, and new new tax costs. criteria have been established, for example, for the qualification of a parent company, by way of derogation from IFRSs. This is not helpful for a multinational approach to combating tax avoidance, and this is also at the expense of competition for Europe as a business location.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Madam President! Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Mr Tang and Mr Lamassoure, and also encourage Commissioner Moscovici to continue his work to prevent unhealthy tax competition. We have already tackled a lot, but there is still a lot of work to be done because Member States are still in a blockade on many issues. The results of the two TAXE committees in particular, but also of the PANA Committee of Inquiry have shown the gaps where we need to improve where we need to move the tax system into the 21st century, in particular, when it comes to ensuring that international companies, especially in the digital economy, have their fair share of contribute to the financing of public infrastructure, the administration and also the welfare of the welfare states, and not only benefit from their ability to do business. That is a common objective here in Parliament, and I can say that we support all this. Another question is the minimum tax rates. Since we have no influence on tax arrangements in this sense anyway, it would be wrong if we were to demand minimum tax rates. Nor would it be in the interests of joint efforts to make small progress. I therefore hope that these issues, such as those of a common tax base, will be able to be included in the codecision procedure in future. If tax rates remain within national competence, we would also have more influence in terms of content.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, it is high time to ensure that taxes are paid where profits are made, and the sad truth is that, a long time ago, we, as Member States and nations, lost sovereignty around corporate taxation in the age of globalisation. What this proposal on a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base is doing is actually taking a first big step to ensure that we can regain sovereignty around corporate taxation – ensure that big multinational corporations again start paying their fair share of taxes – and it is also creating much better and more equal competition between small and medium-sized enterprises and big corporations, thus ensuring growth and jobs in Europe. It is important to note that what we have been seeing now and over the past decades is a race to the bottom on corporate taxation, raising inequalities between our societies and in our societies. With this Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base we are taking a step to eliminate that race to the bottom. So this is an important step we are taking in Parliament and in the European Union, and we should go global with it. This is the first step. We need to create a corporate tax system that fits the 21st century, and what we are doing in Europe is actually not impeding nation-state sovereignty. It is a step to enhance sovereignty and also to ensure that everybody contributes with fair taxes – and that we should applaud!

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Madam President, the Revolution of Information Technologies and Modernization of Distribution Chains have ensured companies a great presence in markets far from their headquarters. Individual states have used this to attract big businesses with stimulating tax rates and additional benefits. A good part of the Member States cannot and do not want to compete in that tax match because it would require cuts in public spending so now we have this initiative that aims to cement the existing situation. We must not forget that European nations led the world in research and innovation when they competed most with each other. This internal competition for Europe can only be good because it will motivate all members to constantly work to increase competitiveness and efficiency and force them to eliminate unnecessary costs that politicians often buy voters' favor.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, taxing multinationals in a fair way and where they receive their revenues is certainly a fair and shareable principle, but let us pay attention to certain points of this measure. We must tax and control multinationals, not small and micro enterprises that already today struggle to be compliant with all the administrative burdens they already have in carrying out their own activities. Thus, implementing this measure for all companies is dangerous and counterproductive. And the second point must be very clear: with this measure, we must not drain resources from the Member States. Taxation is a competence that remains in the hands of the Member States and these measures must not be linked to any own resources to be brought together within the European budget.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: — Madam President, according to a survey, the results of which were published the day before yesterday by the Financial Times, since 2008, when the international financial crisis broke out, taxes on larger multinational companies have been dramatically reduced and income taxes and taxes are constantly increasing. consumption in the name of the consolidation of public finances. The consequences of this policy are the reduction of the middle class, the impasse of many small and medium-sized enterprises and the economic marginalisation of wider grassroots strata. This is the case for the economy and society, because there are also obvious political implications, that is, the credibility of the political system is reduced, and in many cases the world is turning against us. The reports we are discussing, by Mr Lamassoure and Mr. Tang, it's in the right direction. We thank them and they deserve our support. I believe that they are realistic, that is to say things that are reasonable and can move forward, provided that the political will exists, and I think that the European Commission's attitude is constructive. What we have to do is ask the governments of our countries to adapt to the thinking that we are analysing here, because we are often well told, but in our countries of origin, completely different things happen.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici, ladies and gentlemen. This week we have spoken in various contexts about the UK's exit from the EU, the so-called Brexit, which poses a particular problem for me as a member of the European Committee on Budgets, namely a hole in the European Union's budget, which is about 10% hole in the European Union budget and thus the mandatory Need to allocate expenses. We are faced with the balancing act between the right of European citizens and the governments of the Member States to a powerful EU and a revenue situation that is collapsing. Today we have adopted the European Parliament's own resources report and our proposal for the multiannual financial framework. I believe that there can hardly be a better new own resource for the European Union budget than the common corporate tax base. We should apply for this. This is a means of European regulation and important in the common market — a European instrument for a European budget.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, the idea of taxing where value creation takes place is a real idea. It is also true because it eliminates a massive imbalance that currently exists between internationally active groups and medium-sized companies. However, the previous speaker has just confirmed this once again in an impressive way, there are considerable doubts as to whether all parties are actually pursuing such noble objectives here, or whether they are pursuing completely different objectives. Today we heard the call for common tax rates. We have even heard that the large states should put pressure on the smaller countries to tax them as much as the large states would like. And we have just heard that we need funding for the European budget through this way. Ladies and gentlemen, this is a mistake. This is exactly what we need to prevent!

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: — Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the two rapporteurs, Paul Tang and Alain Lamassoure. I do not want to repeat everything that has rightly been said, but I would like to focus on four points. Firstly, in my view, this is not a law that now wants to punish a certain type of company, but it is a law that seeks to establish equality — equality between small and medium-sized enterprises that are based in Europe or anywhere else in the world, and the large companies that have the chance to learn about tax arrangements to take advantage of the freedom that Member States have given them. Secondly, that is why it is also important to make it clear that this law does not restrict the freedom of the Member States — and no matter whether they are large or small Member States — but that we regain sovereignty so that we can actually achieve a consistent balance in Europe in tax law, in which the Member States are large or small. the individual Member States will then be able to once again allow fair competition with different tax rates. This, too, seems very important to me. If we get this common corporate tax base, there will be competition between Member States, but it will be competition that will be fair. That is why I believe that this proposal will help us to increase tax fairness, and I am grateful that we will be able to follow this path. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – I know you are a specialist on this matter, Mr Schwab. Since the very beginning I have supported the merger of both directives on corporate tax, including by aligning the entry into force of the base and the consolidation on 1 January 2020. Taking into consideration your experience, don’t you think that it is too early? Do you think 1 January 2020 is feasible, when we are almost in the middle of 2018?

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Answer to a question about the procedure of the “blue card”. — Dear Mr Frunzulică! I think this is the right time, because we can't wait forever either. We've been a long time now. This Parliament discussed this proposal for the first time in 2008. It has been mentioned that the Member States were very slow to participate in this. And it was only when the European Commission courageously singled out individual cases that it became clear how much damage is. I believe that the EU states cannot afford to invest 70 billion a year in the long run. We need to take a step, which is why I believe this is the right time. I was also able to mention the fourth point that was important to me.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: Madam President, harmonising the corporate tax base and consolidating the distribution between States is absolutely essential in a single market. The opposite is unfair competition. This is an essential step in combating tax avoidance and, above all and especially, for loyalty among the States of the same single market. I think this is essential and this step seems to me that the Commission did it well, the rapporteurs who have carried out this report have improved it in the European Parliament, and I am glad that. But I also have to warn honourable Members that, unfortunately, the Council is ignoring Parliament's recommendations. Unfortunately, the Council does not listen to us. And since these reports are for consultation, unfortunately, the Council is legislating without taking us into account. And I would like to make this complaint, because the contributions that have been made in this Parliament are very important in order to improve the initiative that the directive represented at the time.

name: Luigi MORGANO
