text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we know how some recent fiscal scandals have brought to light the downward fiscal race in many states, unfortunately also in the European Union, quantified among the fifty billion euros a year of non-revenue for public finances. Those who earn it are mainly the large multinational digital companies — but not only — which exploit differences, asymmetries and complications existing in the tax systems of the Member States, as well as ad hoc agreements. Those who lose it are the citizens of Europe. Parliament is making a bold proposal in its simplicity. With the harmonisation of the taxable base which provides for the texts under discussion, two things are basically asked: to restore the link between the place of taxation and the place of profit making, Restoring a level playing field for large multinationals and small and medium-sized industries, which are the framework of the European economic system. With satisfaction, also staff, I note that the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs wanted to maintain a focus on the deductibility of undistributed profits transferred to reserves by companies cooperative cooperatives and consortia, and the possibility of allocating some of the resources arising from an EU tax on the common tax basis to the European budget to reduce direct national contributions.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I believe that taxation of products and services should really remain in the European Union. This, of course, does not prevent uniform procedural rules from being adopted. We should therefore look for a strategy for how that tax remains on the territory of the European Union. Tax must be paid where profit was generated. I think that is a rule that also complies with the proposal of the European Commission. I'm glad the rapporteurs upmodded him. However, I would like to distinguish this situation from unfair tax competition, that is, if Member States have legitimately established their tax policy and it is not unfair tax competition, it is indeed within their purview. But at the moment when we are seeing that there is also a kind of unfair tax competition between Member States, I must confess that I am not quite happy to see it — and that is very subtly put it — and it would be good, so that the European Commission will also be able to respond to this issue.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the current international economic environment, the challenge of ensuring that income from economic activities is taxed in the place where it comes created the value. The reference is particularly to large multinational companies able to easily transfer profits to Member States with lower tax rates. Existing systems of corporate taxation reflect the economic realities of the last century, in which companies had a clear link to the local market. The directives we have today aim to create a common basis for taxation in the Union of certain companies, so that taxable profits will have to be divided between the Member States in which the undertaking operates. This may prove to be a powerful tool in combating aggressive tax planning, but in order to enable new legislation to express its full potential, there is a need for greater cooperation between the National tax administrations, also crucial for the Capital Markets Union, the Digital Single Market and the Investment Plan for Europe.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, this proposal is very important in combating tax avoidance and optimization. The Anti-Tax Evasion Directive does not prevent multinationals from using financial techniques to avoid paying taxes. Our group — Greens/EFA — published the “Tax Shopping” study on the Galician textile company Inditex Zara, which avoided paying taxes in Spain between 2011 and 2014. I contacted you at the time and you told me via Twitter that you were following the reports. This is an example of what we are fighting against today with the proposal we are debating in this Parliament.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this Parliament's proposal is still far more ambitious than what I expected at the beginning of the debate. I must say that what is contained is definitely something very progressive, which goes within the framework of combating inequality in the field of taxation. Multinationals must pay taxes where they carry out economic activity. There remain small problems, from my point of view, that can become even big, for example on the threshold of 750 million turnover which will affect only 10% of multinationals, if eliminated after 7 years, it's going to hit all the companies. A technical study has to be done on this, and the Commission should apply, to apply with a threshold of around EUR 50 million, because it would affect multinationals, and then exclude the small companies that may have difficulty in applying and transposing this matter. And we may agree on own resources, but we must not apply an increase in the resources that the States must convey to the Union budget. So I absolutely agree, only as long as this doesn't put additional burdens on the states.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Madam President, the principle of taxation policy in trying to encourage investment and industrial policy – particularly in peripheral parts of the European Union or less developed parts of the Union – is an essential point that we should never lose. I recognise that there is a significant majority in this House for both of these reports, as has been the case for many, many years, but there is not a significant majority, or anywhere close to that, in the Council. That is because there is a real concern among smaller Member States that this proposal could lead to a hollowing out of the public tax position in those Member States, and could lead to a real reduction in terms of their total tax take in favour of larger Member States with big domestic populations. There has been no serious impact assessment on this proposal and we are very concerned about the way in which it could impact radically on smaller Member States. We have to do more to address aggressive tax planning, and the best way of doing that is at OECD level.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President! It is surprising that there are still numerous barriers, obstacles or even chicanes to business operators in the European market. So many years have gone by, and all the time we face barriers that seemed straightforward. I understand that harmonizing 28 tax systems is not easy and not possible today. However, I am unable to understand why there are still so many obstacles preventing normal accounting of taxes. I am very happy about the two stages that are being proposed at the moment. I also accept the transition period in which the proposed compensation mechanism would function. By contrast, it is crucial now to define the main business address well and indeed move to implementation quickly.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: — Madam President, I congratulate the rapporteurs, colleagues Lamassoure and Tang and consider that two important steps in preventing tax evasion and profit shifting are made through the proposals of these two directives. So, the first step — establishing a common corporate tax base — is important because the tax practices of providing hidden grants and attracting companies are stopped in such a way that allows them to reduce the tax base as much as possible, and also, thanks to this proposal, they reduce administrative costs and significantly simplify procedures for companies across the single market. The second step — the joint consolidated corporate tax base — is important because it prevents the transfer of company profits to lower taxes and introduce the practice of, of course, consolidating results and distribution in line with income, assets, number of employees, but also data in the case of digital business.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. — (FR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen in the European Parliament, first of all, thank you all for this quality debate, I do not know the vote, by definition it will take place tomorrow. I do not want to prejudge this, but I am glad that we are moving together in a largely transpartisan way to call on the Member States to act quickly, as they have done on intermediaries, because our fellow citizens are asking for it, and it is true that this debate gives rise to the very broad ambition of the proposal. I would like once again to welcome the work of the rapporteurs who have been able to mobilize, convince and promote the CCCTB project across Europe. I hear the questions that arise, and it is normal for such an ambitious reform to give rise to questions and debates of ideas, but we are at the time of political choices. It is time for Europe to be ambitious in its tax reform to attract businesses, remain globally competitive, fight against tax evasion and evasion, and with CCCTB we have a unique response to the concerns of both businesses and citizens, and that is why this reform is so important. For businesses, we offer a genuine single market, with simplified, uniform rules and fair and fair conditions of competition, and to citizens, we show our determination to fight tax evasion, which feeds precisely on asymmetries between national tax systems. Thanks to the proposals I will make next week with your support in the future, digital business taxation will also — if the Member States decide — will be an integral part of the CCCTB project and therefore we will really have this corporate tax architecture for the 21st century which will affect the whole economy, whatever be its strata, its sectors or its forms. Facing cleavages in view of the current administrative burden, i think we have the cornerstone of the modern, competitive, transparent tax system that we want. I am counting on the two coming Presidencies, the Bulgarian Presidency at the present time and the Austrian Presidency to complete the work. I would also like to respond to a few points raised by Members of Parliament. First, no, this project is not an attack on the sovereignty of the Member States. This is never the case in the projects we are formulating because the European Commission, as you know, has no form of competence, for example, over rates. It is just a question of harmonising the operating conditions in the single market for the benefit of companies and this is not only a national level but also, of course, the national level retains most of its prerogatives. Obviously, it is also a question of combating tax evasion, which is fostered by the complexities linked to fiscal borders, but again the answer is European. Mrs Joly referred to the use of Article 116 to deal with distortions of competition in the domestic market. I do not think it can be used as a legal basis for a legislative proposal such as the CCCTB, but you know that the European Commission is thinking about reverting this issue of unanimity in tax matters, which we find is at least a source of complexity, especially when we have plans as ambitious. Finally, on the question of whether there is a basis for a own resource in the future or on the question of tax rates or tax harmonisation, I repeat: by creating a common basis, we are undoubtedly moving towards fiscal convergence. Fiscal harmonization, which I share, also depends on the will of the States members, because there is no return on tax sovereignty. I do not think there is any additional tax weight — at least that is not included in the proposal — and therefore I think that with all the sensitivities that are expressed here, you can move confidently towards the consolidated common corporate tax base which is consistent with much of the visions I have heard here. . Moreover, the rapporteurs do not seem to me necessarily come from the same political families, and yet they have done an extremely close job, since we have a proposal here which can really bring together because it is a question of modernising, making our tax systems transparent and combating aggressive tax optimization. This extremely powerful tool is in your hands and, as usual, I believe that Parliament and the Commission have worked well and that, by your vote tomorrow, you will mark that you are asking the Member States to move forward with the same strength and ambition.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your answers, and I thank all those of our colleagues who took part in this very interesting and enriching debate, which foreshadows tomorrow a fairly clear majority in favour of the proposals adopted by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. I would like to appeal to the Council, because the ball will now be in its side and it is time for the Council, at the appropriate level, that is, at the political level of ministers, to take up this issue. However, we know — we have seen other examples and, on this subject, an example a few years ago — that the Council knows perfectly well how to get rid of texts that embarrass it, without having to vote formally against it. The first way is to say “There are other emergencies” and, in 2011, it is true, we were in the middle of the eurozone crisis, there was fire at home, maybe it wasn't the time to take care of changing the furniture. Another method is to let the file get bogged down by postponing it from meeting to meeting, and this is where the priority over time, which the Council could give to a limited solution to digital taxation by indirect tax, could be harmful. Finally, there is another method of emptying the draft of its substance, and what we can know about the work of the working group, which operates under the authority of ECOFIN, is very worrying, since they have completed a first reading of the first draft directive, simply deleting most of the provisions proposed by the European Commission, making the original proposal meaningless. I therefore appeal that, on the basis of the Commission's proposals with the amendments suggested — I hope tomorrow — by the European Parliament, the Council should finally take up this essential subject in order to achieve this progress that the European Union needs.

name: Paul TANG
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would first of all like to thank my colleagues for their contributions in this debate. Special thanks also go to the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs for working together on these files, as well as to Alain Lamassoure and also to Pierre Moscovici. I think we worked together very productively. I very much appreciate it. We have the vote tomorrow, but it doesn’t mean our work ends after tomorrow. We can’t just have a vote in the European Parliament. We still have to reach out to national parliaments, national governments and the public to put pressure on for this reform. I also expect that from Members of the European Parliament, and I am sure that Alain Lamassoure and I will continue to work outside this House to press for this reform, because this year will be the moment of truth. I am very pleased when Pierre Moscovici says that this year we should have the discussion in the Council and this year we should put the pressure on. This is the year when the Member States have to show their true colours. In the end, I think that, even if we don’t have the 27 on board, we should push this, because it puts pressure on the countries that remain outside an agreement. Currently, the situation is that Google and Facebook are in Dublin, but the tax reasons for being there become much less if other countries already start to tax Google and Facebook. This will change the dynamics. Hearing this debate, another point came to my mind: first of all that reform is very difficult, especially for countries on their own. They fear losing competition, so the best option for reform is to do it together. So we need to restore sovereignty for Member States as well, by trying to reform together. I hope, again, that Parliament will give the starting signal and vote in favour with broad support for a fair and efficient corporate tax system in the 21st century.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 15 March 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. — Tax dumping and aggressive tax planning are a daily occurrence in the European Union. The Netherlands of Dijsselbloem, the Luxembourg of Juncker and Malta are countries which provide tax avoidance incentives to the various multinationals. Therefore, aggressive tax planning is essentially the second nature of the European Union, because the EU itself wants grey areas to exist through unfair tax competition between Member States. The time has come at a pan-European level to create a fair tax system with a common corporate tax base, without grey areas, to stop the tax dumping of multinational companies and to tax their profits in the countries where they are reaped. In addition, all legislative “windows” that legitimize the practice of intra-group transactions and lead to tax avoidance that deprives state budgets of huge tax revenues. But in the end there is a lot of hypocrisy, since Ecofin unanimously removed even Panama from the black list of tax havens. Therefore, the key to hitting tax evasion and avoidance in the EU lies in the Council, where serious decisions need to be taken. But there are Member States which not only do not want concrete measures to be taken but are totally blocking the necessary decisions.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: in writing. — The work of the LuxLeaks and Panama Papers Committees has shown that aggressive tax avoidance practices are not a problem of an individual country or a single company, but a structural problem of tax policy in Europe and worldwide. as a result, gaps between national systems, double taxation and high administrative burdens are hampering growth and investment, and large firms can usually legally choose the “tax-sparing” country for each part of their activities. On the other hand, the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base is the most effective medicine. We want companies to pay their taxes where value creation takes place. We want to harmonise what is taxed and where across the EU. We want to jointly introduce uniform rules for calculating taxable profits and consolidating them. We want to reduce bureaucracy, generating 3.4% more investment and 1.2% more growth in the EU. And we want to incorporate digital activities of online groups and define a “digital permanent establishment” for Internet-based businesses. The idea is not new, but was born in 2011. Today, as then, the European Parliament has delivered. The Member States must finally stop betting each other and adopt this important initiative during this parliamentary term.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. — The core idea and objective we must achieve is for firms to divert taxes where they make profit. I am completely against tax havens and tax fraud. But I think we lack the definition of what a tax haven actually is. We must distinguish the limits by so-called tax optimization and purpose fraud. At the same time, I remain convinced that fiscal policy should remain fully within the competence of the Member States. As the KSČM, for example, we propose two tax rates, lower for small and medium-sized enterprises and higher for large firms. But the proposed directive envisages a minimum single tax rate across the EU for all legal entities within seven years. I strongly support unanimous decision in the Council on these steps.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the oral question to the Commission by Czesław Adam Siekierski, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Relations, on the US attack on EU support payments for farms under the CAP (related to Spanish olives) Development and Bernd Lange, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O-000006/2018 - B8-0007/2018) (2018/2566 (RSP)).

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: author. — Madam President! Dear ladies! Processes occurring outside the borders of the European Union have an increasing impact on the situation of the EU agri-food sector. Another example of external conditions affecting the situation in our agriculture is American trade restrictions on Spanish olives, although in the future it can be expected that various products from other countries may also be affected. Growing protectionist trends in the world could pose a serious threat to our producers. I would like to present the letter now. On 13 July 2017, an anti-dumping and countervailing duty proceeding concerning mature olives from Spain was initiated after it was concluded that the aid maintained by olive producers in the Union resulted in olive products being imported into the United States at prices lower than market ones. Given that the increase in exports from Spain has very little impact on the situation of the two US olive producers, the most worrying aspect of the case is that some of the support measures applied under the common agricultural policy are examined in the countervailing proceeding, even though they fully meet the criteria for payment of the green category applicable to the WTO. The measures under consideration for countervailing duties are the basic payment scheme, aid for young farmers, etc., which have no connection to production. They do not affect the level of prices in particular agricultural markets. They don't disrupt international trade. On 19 January 2018, the Department of Commerce imposed an unreasonable countervailing duty on Spanish olives in excess of 17%. What action has the Commission already taken on this? How does the Commission support Spanish companies? What actions are planned in response to the threat in which the Common Agricultural Policy has been found? Is the Commission considering the possibility of bringing a complaint against the US to the World Trade Organization? It is end of the question. Finally, I would also like to stress that, in addition to fighting protectionism, we must also strive to ensure a level playing field for competition on the global market. This is about matters of environmental, climate and social standards.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: author. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. We are, of course, the subject of two subjects on the issue of olives from the United States, others would say under attack. One is anti-dumping investigations against individual producers of olives. Here too, one can indeed be very critical of whether this is a justified subject of investigation, because we undoubtedly do not allow dumping proceedings in the EU. We will probably see a result of these anti-dumping investigations by the United States in June. I can also, in some ways, sympathy for launching this anti-dumping investigation. But the second line, anti-subsidy measures: the accusation of subsidy fraud being carried out in the European Union — I have no sympathy at all. This is not against individual companies, but, as the previous speaker said, it is against European agricultural policy. This is a mockery because, with the last reform of the European agricultural policy, we are clearly fulfilling the criteria of the green box within the WTO. In this respect, this is an attack on the structures of the WTO, and of course we know this from other contexts. We discussed this this morning as far as steel is concerned. Structures accepted by 164 countries are deliberately questioned here. That is why we must also make it very clear that we cannot accept these anti-subsidy investigations and the impose of duties. This is ultimately pure protectionism! We have already asked the Commission three times what is the state of play on the olive issue, that is, what action the Commission has taken so far. Right now, following the impose of tariffs in January, the Commission is going to sue the US to the WTO. Are there any considerations to create security measures and countermeasures?

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, yes the Commission is fully aware of the importance of this case, not only in terms of the economic impact on the Spanish exporters but also because of its systemic importance, relating to the targeting of the EU common agricultural policy: the ‘green box’ support available to Spanish farmers, which you have raised. So we have been actively involved in those investigations from the very beginning, and have provided all the necessary assistance to the Spanish Government and the exporters concerned. We have made several technical and political interventions to legally rebut the US allegations and politically dissuade the US authorities from taking countervailing measures against EU CAP ‘green box’ subsidies. Despite all these efforts, as you know, the US authority nevertheless decided to take preliminary countervailing measures. We are very concerned about this decision, because these subsidies are not trade distortive and they do comply with the rules of the World Trade Organization (WTO). We will continue to exert pressure on the USA. I have personally raised the issue with the relevant ministers and secretaries; and some of my colleagues in the Commission, notably Commissioner Hogan, have also raised this personally several times with relevant ministers and secretaries; and we will continue to talk with and assist the Spanish Government. There are talks on this regularly, including with the Spanish companies concerned, with the aim of avoiding the imposition of any unjustified measures by the USA. If this is not successful, we will carefully analyse the factual and legal aspects of the final decision due at the beginning of June, and will weigh all possible options on how to challenge these measures, including through WTO action.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Trump Administration's harassing European exports is unacceptable. Among the many similar procedures initiated by the United States, the action against Spanish table olives is of particular concern. If it thrives, the aid model of the common agricultural policy, which is perfectly in line with the rules of the World Trade Organisation, as the Commissioner said, would be put into question in a capricious way. I think that the European Union should not turn the other cheek, but rather respond to the United States with its own weapons. In Andalusia, a community heavily punished by the economic crisis, US action can cause serious damage, damage to many families living from olive groves and olive processing. The success of this sector has been due to its work and its ability to introduce technological improvements. European aid is not the reason for increasing the competitiveness of Spanish producers. I sincerely believe that the European Commission is doing its job well together with the Government of Spain and that it should continue to do so by giving a strong response to these investigations. From the European People's Group, we have tabled an amendment calling for an investigation into subsidies received by US production such as almonds and maize, as there are compelling reasons to think that this is truly trade-distorting aid.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, as other Members have said, Trump's protectionist measures are an attack on the European CAP aid system, and that is what is worrying about this situation. And they announce a trade war on our export sectors. Research has been opened — as they have already referred — since last June, in one case, and in July, in another case, to several Spanish, Andalusian, and Seville companies, specifically, three companies that have a high competitiveness in this field of table olives, namely black table olives. One of them is a cooperative. These are the olives that are so critical and apparently so much affecting Californian companies in the marketing of their products. This has already meant that, on a provisional basis, an increase in tariffs of an average of 22% has been imposed on the companies concerned. The final decision will be determined next June. If the result is negative, important tariffs would be imposed on imports of black table olives from Spain, for a duration of up to 10 years. We are clear what is the goal of Americans: to weaken the export capacity of these companies, which are already heavy-implanted in the US market, to clearly benefit two Californian companies. The Commission is doing well, it is supporting the sector and the Government of Spain. I encourage her to stay like this. Ladies and gentlemen, in conclusion, the problem is that the excuse is the aid they receive from the common agricultural policy. Now it's olives, tomorrow can be other products or other sectors. Therefore, we cannot let ourselves be overly. We support the Commission in its actions, and I therefore call on all Members and all groups to support the joint motion for a resolution that we have tabled. It will undoubtedly be good news for this sector.

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President Free trade is important to all of us, for prosperity and for freedom. Now we see the US starting a spiral of tax reductions. Today it's olives from Spain, tomorrow it could be scam meat from Denmark and it is a threat to our growth and welfare. That is why it is extremely important that we speak with great words and reason to each other. No one is served by trade war, especially not the working people who are taken hostage. Imposing trade restrictions is a socialist mindset which has never worked. It's not American, it's selfish. Now we need to send a clear signal that we want free trade and dialogue with the United States as well. The US also needs to know that we don't always buy products from the US that aren't environmentally friendly.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. — Madam Commissioner, I must say that I understand your rhetoric from this morning when we talked about steel and aluminum and now your rhetoric when we talk about Spanish olives, but I want to warn you: The war has begun! The war has begun! I support moderate rhetoric, but I expect firm decisions. We must understand that war follows, and every day more and more. There is no dilemma that everything you do is benevolent, but we have to be prepared for countermoves in a way that maybe this US administration today wants only one thing: it wants to redouble the European Union. Spanish olives will get their customs duties, but the Croatian won't, the Greek won't, and we have a common agricultural policy. And we need to get on with that common agricultural policy. And I argue that we in our Common Agricultural Policy have to play to top quality and in doing so we will be the most competitive in the world market, but that is a question of ourselves. In this case it is very clear that the rules of the World Trade Organization (...), so I think Trump will be pursuing policy, that he will just shake. They'll say, “No matter what a World Trade Organization!”. We see what he does when he talks about doing business in the Pacific, when he talks about doing business with other states and I think we're off guard here. There is no dilemma that if someone says, “America first!”, I invite you to say the same: “Europe first!”. I'm completely open to the world economy, I'm completely open to a completely liberal economy, but someone says, “America first!” Here you come from the Commission to say, “Europe first!”

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President, Trump's trade war against Spanish olives is unfair, arbitrary and contrary to the rules of world trade. The aid received by the sector does not distort the market and comply with the so-called 'green box' at international level. At the same time, the future of the sector is not to reinforce the mass export of large industry, based on monoculture, through another agricultural model that primes the environment, good working conditions, public health and animal welfare. So in Andalusia, in Extremadura, in the Valencian Country we diversify our field, encourage local consumption, organic farming, small farms and food sovereignty. This is the best response to Trump: a just transition to a living and sustainable field. I hope that you will support the Verts/ALE Group's amendments in that regard so that we can support this resolution as a whole. To save the olive and its people, neither Trump, nor monoculture.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, thank you very much, Commissioner, in November the US Department of Commerce issued a resolution proposing to impose tariffs on Spanish olives. This measure can have dramatic costs in the sector and thousands of families depend on olives. The measure shows that Trump rules in the service of lobbies, even if it makes him fall, as in this case, inconsistently, because they accuse us of unfair competition for subsidizing our agriculture, when US agriculture is heavily subsidized. In addition, our subsidies are WTO approved. It is worrying that a precedent can be set against other agricultural products, but our response should not be more war. We demand Trump to withdraw this unjust and arbitrary measure, which will be suffered primarily by small- and medium-sized farmers and workers in the sector. We call on the European Commission to redouble its efforts to address this threat and to focus its response on workers, SMEs and cooperatives. We also underline the need for the future CAP to develop resistance to these types of external threats, and to that end we must focus on our internal market and overcome the risks posed by the continued commitment to export. We must prioritize small and medium-sized farmers and the sustainability of our rural world over the great benefits of agro-industrial enterprises, and encourage short cycles and agroecology. The challenge is a major one. We play the present and future of our rural world and hundreds of thousands of jobs.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, as you know, the United States wants to block imports of Spanish black olives. Already during negotiations with Australia, the agricultural sector had been excluded from the negotiations, a position completely opposed to that of the European Union, which is ready to sacrifice its farmers. The Americans consider that Spanish olives are sold at a low price thanks to CAP subsidies, and have a serious impact on their industry. The Spaniards, for their part, consider that their efforts to reduce costs and investments are the only reasons why they produce olives at a competitive price. Therefore, how to help Spanish producers? The solution is certainly the renegotiation of treaties and trade agreements. The primary objective of our agricultural policy must be to nurture, not to impose unlimited competitiveness with the aim of speculative agriculture. This breathless system makes no sense anymore, especially when we know that Spain also imports olives. Faced with this situation with the United States, we must absolutely revolutionize our trade rules.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, for many months the Commission has remained silent. Whereas for a few days the steel case has been on the chronicle, this case does not concern only Spain, it concerns all of Europe through Spanish olives. Yes, as has been said, it is an attack on the common agricultural policy, it is an attack on the efforts we have demanded for several decades from European farmers to comply with international constraints. The legitimacy of our common policy is being questioned today by the United States. However, should we recall that the United States is helping farmers twice as much as Europe for each of their hectares? Europe seems ready to deliver this or that part of its agriculture into international agreements and we are silent to defend it when we are attacked in one of our essential tools. Commissioner, our fellow citizens are asking us for a Europe that protects them. A Europe that protects them is a Europe that expresses itself in time and time, it is a Europe that acts immediately and not a year later, it is a Europe that is able to show tactics against the opponent. That is what we ask of you, that is what we expect from you, not in June, but immediately it is a signal to send to our farmers.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, after steel and aluminium, Spanish table olives could only be the first in a series of European agri-food excellence, victims of scellerated trade war initiated by the US administration. A decision, that of the American authorities, which takes surreal traits if it is thought that Spanish producers are accused of exporting below the market price because of direct aid from the common agricultural policy. A policy that, unlike the US Farm Bill, has long decided to eliminate any distorting aid, making the European Union one of the few trading blocs in the world capable of boasting the almost totality complies with agricultural policies to the green box of the WTO. Our farmers, after the crisis due to the Russian embargo, now risk seeing a market that, with a total volume of exports exceeding 20 billion euros last year, represents the most important trading partner of the European Union. It is therefore necessary, Commissioner, to immediately reopen a discussion table with the US authorities in order to avoid further heavy repercussions on the agri-food sector European.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Madam President! This move by the US administration to portray Europe's agricultural subsidies as a distortion of competition is, in my view, only the beginning. We must firmly oppose this, otherwise we will soon have the same problems in other areas. I would also like to suggest that in future we will bind the first pillar of the common agricultural policy much more to public services, such as climate protection, clean water, biodiversity, healthy food, animal welfare or landscape protection, in order to dispel any suspicion that market support measures are involved here. , and to make it clear that this is about public services that are legal under the green box.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the situation caused by the United States with table olives clearly shows the vulnerability to which farmers in this sector are subjected as a result of an export agricultural policy. Before we had the example of the Russian embargo. The European Union and the United States promote neoliberal and devastating agricultural policies, with prices at source below production costs, which, while providing cheap raw material to agribusiness, make farmers fully dependent on aid. I want to denounce the hypocrisy and falsehood behind free trade, because in this battle neither the United States nor the European Union defends farmers: they defend only the agro-export business. That is why I ask the Commission: what concrete measures will it take to protect small and medium-sized agriculture in the production areas concerned? What steps will you take to defend direct and indirect jobs? What measures are you going to take to defend fair prices and living wages and also to keep profits in the territories? And finally, what concrete measures are you going to take to put an end to the vulnerability of olive growers?

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I will not repeat what has already been said here, and I agree with my pre-speakers. It is only among them that Spanish olive producers receive only the financial aid they pay to other agricultural producers in the European Union and therefore receive no special production subsidies. So, in my opinion, it's not about breaking any rules, let alone WTO rules. Commissioner, in my view, the European Commission should, first and foremost, provide expert support to Spanish olive producers in the situation, this has not yet been sounded here. For these producers, the investigation by US authorities undoubtedly poses a significant burden. Second, we should consider the possibility of challenging the US decision with the WTO's dispute resolution bodies. It is also appropriate to use the diplomatic service, that is to intensify diplomatic efforts to support and defend the European Union's Common Agricultural Policy, which, I reiterate, is consistent with by WTO rules. Given the intransigence of the US side to date, we should also evaluate the risk of extending US anti-dumping measures to other European agricultural products, because this risk actually threatens, and I think we should be prepared for that. At the same time, we should strongly warn the American side that a policy of protectionism can create instability and uncertainty in world markets that will harm world trade and ultimately turns just primarily against the US.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the Commission and the Commissioner and her team for their efforts to work with the Government of Spain, the Government of the Junta de Andalucía and the sector to deal with this absolutely unjust situation, and which I share with everyone that it poses a systemic risk, for the it poses a threat to the CAP. I know that every effort is being made, but what I wonder is: if it is not possible to prevent the final situation from reaching the final situation and becomes firm, what can be the next product? What is the chain? Where to Trump? Because it is clear that here you have no reason to open this investigation. I believe that it is acting to defend the particular interests of certain American companies, which are not the general interests of Americans, and certainly skipping all the rules of the World Trade Organization. But the key question is: can something be done to avoid it? How can we go together Parliament, Council Commission, sector, farmers, everyone, to try to stop Trump if possible?

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the boycott of table olives is not a Spanish, Andalusian or Sevillian problem, it is a European problem: it attacks the heart of the European Union, it attacks our CAP, our identity. I am going to ask the Commission to give this sector the same treatment it has been applying this week in the face of the Trump administration's arbitrary and unfair attack on other sectors also in Europe. I ask you that same forcefulness and the same treatment. And I will also ask you to advise, help and accompany companies, which are making a tremendous effort to defend themselves before US institutions: to accompany them, advise them — as I say — and help them to cope with this extremely difficult situation. In short, security and forcefulness. But I cannot fail to recognize the enormous effort that the Commission is making, and I encourage it to continue on that path.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: — Mr President, I welcome the committee for accompanying the investigation that the US is carrying out to establish possible unfair competition practices in the export of Spanish olives to the US market. I believe that it is important to ensure the transparency of this process so that it does not constitute a factor of distortion of the market and WTO rules. We cannot accept the predominant application of new punitive tariffs to Spanish exports of olive oil, in addition to the national taxes already in force for the sector, since it affects not only Spanish producers but also Portuguese, since, in order to meet the needs of the internal market and to meet the export commitments, the olive and olive oil produced in Portugal end up going to Spain in bulk. Although I am a supporter of the single market and, of course, I welcome foreign investment in my country, I cannot but regret that in the Alentejo region the super-intensive olive grove planting on thousands of hectares is ravaging real archaeological treasures and irreversibly changing the morphology of the landscape and the orography. I would therefore like to point out that this intensive cultivation of olive groves is also responsible for a real environmental crime due to pressures on water use, soil depletion and contamination of groundwater.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the most worrying aspect of this affair is that the United States investigation into the countervailing duty targets the support measures envisaged by the CAP. I would remind you that the CAP has undergone a transformation as a result of numerous reforms aimed at adapting most of the support measures to the WTO green box, and is still designed to ensure the full compliance with the agreements of the WTO itself. The decision of the United States therefore calls into question in an unfair and arbitrary way the entirety of the European Union's support programmes for agriculture, with possible consequences for all beneficiaries of the CAP. The Commission must cooperate with the Spanish authorities to protect the undertakings concerned by this aggressive protectionist measure, which, if it becomes permanent, would have an economic impact on Spanish olive producers estimated from 350 to 700 million euros in the next 5-10 years. The Commission should also take all necessary measures, both bilaterally and in the WTO, to defend the support system provided for by the CAP.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Mr President, after President Trump's recent attack on steel and aluminum, it is now the turn of the Spanish olive. Table olives is a strategic sector for Spain, especially for Andalusia and Extremadura. We are the world's largest producer and the largest exporter: more than 332 000 tonnes sold to 180 countries, with 450 industries that transform olive into table olives. But above all, it is important to note that this sector generates more than 8 000 direct jobs and countless indirect jobs, in harvesting, cultivation, ancillary enterprises, transport and a long list. The sector also contributes around EUR 1 billion to Spain to gross domestic product. If no action is taken, this attack will not be the last. Possibly, in the near future, the same will happen with any other product that the United States considers to be a threat. The Commission therefore needs to provide a strong and strong response that protects the activity of the agri-food industry and, above all, families and small producers, agricultural cooperatives and workers.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, Commissioner. It is important that we also use incentives to counter these tariffs. It is important that we look at the entire value chain and look at which areas of the value chain we can support our exporters, for example in food exports, so that they can also grow stronger in exports. We just talked about the corporate tax base before. Mr Moscovici could have prepared a nice activity here, namely a 50% reduction, so that we could become more competitive on the international markets. We will only be able to win if we become more competitive. With additional punitive measures, only consumers are punished. The European Union is an exemplary role here. Thank you personally.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Mr President, as Sevillian, as Andalusian, as a Spanish and as a European, I am deeply concerned about this attack on table olives, which gives work to so many families in Andalusia. These companies are being the scapegoat for Mr. Trump's aggressive, unjust and protectionist policy. We cannot leave alone the olive sector, which is defending itself with a lot of money, millions: five million euros has been in lawyers. Today is the table olive, as my companions say; tomorrow, steel; and after, what will it be? Mrs Malmström, I tell you that Europe can defend itself, and we will do it by your hand, as you are doing so far.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for bringing this up and for continuing to support the Commission in our efforts in this matter. We share your concerns and I do not accept the accusation that the Commission has been silent on this. Since the very first day, we have raised it with our American partners in different ways. There have been letters and personal meetings where we have raised it with the relevant ministers. We have raised it over the telephone. We continue to raise it, and some of my colleagues are doing the same because we share the view not only that this is a disaster for Andalucía, and the producers there, but also that the anti-subsidy part of those investigations raises serious systemic issues, which might affect not only Spanish farmers but also the entire EU support granted to farmers across the EU under the common agricultural policy. We have made that point, very clear. So we will continue to defend EU agricultural policy until the end of this investigation, at both the technical and the political level. We have worked very closely with the Spanish Government on this. Only this morning I had contact with the Spanish Minister. We have also worked with the authorities from Andalucía. We offered support for the written and oral intervention that Spain made on this. We also offered assistance during the US verification. That was declined, as it was not needed, but we continue to work very closely with Spain and with Andalucía. We will continue to exert pressure on the US authorities until the end of this because we firmly believe – as you too have said, honourable Members – that these subsidies are totally in compliance with the rules of the World Trade Organization (WTO). As you know, we also had a discussion this morning on steel. This discussion is not easy, given the US administration’s protectionist attitude towards international trade. If our efforts should fail we will carefully analyse the situation. We expect a final decision in June and we will weigh all possible options to challenge a measure, including in the WTO. We will, of course, do so in close cooperation with the Spanish Government. I would like to thank the House for continuing to exert pressure in this matter. We will to continue to follow it very closely.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. Discussion is over. The vote will take place on Thursday 15 March 2018. See Minutes

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on corporate social responsibility.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I’m happy to talk tonight about corporate social responsibility. It’s an issue that is dear to my heart personally and to this Commission especially, and I know that many European citizens that you represent also attach great importance to this. I’m happy to update you where we stand on this. The European Union, including the Member States, have a great track record on corporate social responsibility. I would say that it’s one of the best track records in the world. We have led, our Member States have led and a very large number of our businesses have led, including our small and medium-sized enterprises. And this is not only about ethics and respect for others and the environment, it is about long-term sustainable growth and profits for business: shareholder value. The Commission has recognised from the start that the EU has a valuable role to play here. We can facilitate the implementation of CSR principles, bringing together companies from across different industries and individual sectors to find common solutions. We can incentivise it, including by setting benchmarks and other requirements, and we can also, if necessary, legislate. In 2011 we issued a communication setting out a range of actions. Among others, these actions have aimed to enhance the visibility of CSR and disseminate good practices; improve company disclosure of social and environmental information; further integrate CSR into education, training and research; emphasise the importance of national and sub-national CSR policies; and better align European and global approaches to corporate social responsibilities. We have adopted policies right across our work, from development to agriculture, to labour rights, to justice. A major step forward was the 2015 Directive on non-financial disclosure. This allows shareholders to have proper disclosure and put pressure on companies to change practices if necessary, and I would say that our work has delivered results. In 2014 we carried out a major consultation on CSR. It showed that over two thirds of the respondents were happy with what we have delivered, and that is not just only public sector engagement. Of course there’s always more to be done, and that’s why during this mandate the work has continued. We have continued to mainstream CSR across our policies. In the last year we adopted a revised shareholders’ right directive. We have been giving effect to our new public procurement legislation, paying attention to social and environmental elements, and we are working to finalise guidelines on socially-responsible public procurement. And of course, we adopted here the conflict minerals regulation – we will discuss that tomorrow; I’ll be happy to give you an update then – to ensure responsible trade in four minerals: tin tantalum, tungsten and gold. And only last week we adopt an action plan on sustainable finance. On the basis of the recommendations set out by the high-level expert group on the subject, the Commission is setting out a roadmap to boost the role of finance in achieving well-performing economy that delivers on environmental and social goals. That is just the tip of the iceberg of what we have been doing. We are continuing to engage with business and stakeholders. Whilst public authorities, of course, have a role to play, the final responsibility must always be with the businesses themselves. CSR must be in their DNA. And we are continuing to engage internationally, both through multilateral fora such as the UN and OECD, and of course bilaterally. We have been developing a good dialogue with Japan, for instance, on these issues, and I expect us to develop more such dialogues, because we want other countries to come up to our levels. It has been increasingly clear that there is no dividing line between CSR and our wider work on implementing the United Nations sustainable development goals. If you act against companies using timber that has been illegally logged, that is an issue both of the CSR and the SDGs. If you act against the import of materials produced in sweatshop conditions in a third country, that is an issue of corporate social responsibility and sustainable development goals, and it’s true of our work on business and human rights as well. So under this Commission, we are taking a holistic and integrated approach. We are putting our work at the heart of our implementation of the SDGs. Whether you label them CSR or SDG doesn’t really matter; the matter is of course that you take the most effective and proportionate action to address a situation. That can be through legislation, but it can also be through promoting industry-led standards. Under our 2016 communication on SDGs we have set up a multi-stakeholder platform, made up of stakeholders from business, trade unions, NGOs and others, and I expect that within this platform there will be a working group on CSR. That started its work in January only, and it continues to meet. It will give us valuable input and ideas how to take this work further. We have encouraged it to look at the progress we have already achieved and give us advice on what more needs to be done. So we are looking very much forward to receive the input, carrying on also our own stocktaking exercise of what has been done and what more can be done, and the result of this work will feed into the autumn communication of the SDGs. So with this, I hope I updated you on an issue I know is very important to you as well, and I’m looking forward to the discussion.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Commissioner for the report. I just wish, Commissioner, that you had very clear that today's argument on corporate social responsibility was prompted by a specific case, which was the subject of an oral question co-signed by 69 Italian MEPs, on a specific case called the Embraco case. I also say this by thanking the delegation of Embraco workers, who joined us after fifteen hours by coach from Italy this morning, who are following our work. Why, Commissioner, the situation is this: Embraco is a company that is in Italy, which is in Piedmont, is a company that is part of the Whirlpool group, and it is a company that, despite the fact that it is not going through a moment of crisis, but has the favorable economic situation, decides to move and decides to relocate. The problem is that it decides to move not outside the EU, but within the EU, and precisely Slovakia, where labour costs are lower. Then we must understand, Commissioner, what the Commission's position is. One, if it's acceptable that a company that is well can move around and put the 500 workers who are laid off to move elsewhere in crisis. Two, if this elsewhere can be in Europe. Europe was born to create wealth, not to move it from one country to another. And three — and I will close, Commissioner — we must understand whether these European countries have used European funds to create situations of facilitating these companies to move, because this would really be very serious, because this is money from European citizens, even those citizens, of those 500 workers, who are now in danger of losing their place. Like them, the Italia Online group, also in Piedmont, is putting 500 more jobs at risk. I believe that if Europe is to be credible, it must have a clear word in this regard.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too want to bring my solidarity to the workers and workers of the Embraco, who are here and who are in Turin fighting for the their jobs, and also to the workers and workers of Italia Online who in the same hours, in the same days, are suffering the same suffering that these workers are suffering. However, we must also be very clear, because this oral question which we had tabled today and this debate was to be closed with a resolution, a Parliament resolution in which it is they asked the Commission for very precise measures. Unfortunately tomorrow we will not have the vote in this Parliament because of the European People's Party and the fault of the right, who have not wanted to assume, together with us, a responsibility in the face of the citizens and to citizens, women workers and workers. Because we wanted to make a resolution asking the Commission first of all to give precise answers on what happens with the European Structural Funds, if these structural funds come used by some countries to allow relocation, we wanted to ask the Commission to take account of how companies work and how companies respect social responsibility, and we wanted to Of course also ask the Commission to respond on what is going on in these specific cases. Unfortunately this will not be allowed to happen tomorrow. I am convinced that Europe has done a lot of things over the last three or four years, has done them for business and has also done them to create jobs, but it is time that Europe, The European Commission and the Council also begin to take an interest in the interests of workers and workers.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, corporate social responsibility (CSR) has been defined as the responsibility of companies for their impact upon society. It refers to companies voluntarily going beyond what the law requires to achieve social and environmental objectives during the course of its business activities. The Commissioner has told us how well companies of all sizes across the EU are leading the way in the development of CSR policies. Many companies are progressively integrating CSR into their company strategies on a voluntary basis, and businesses which acknowledge that they are a part of the community where they employ people are to be welcomed and encouraged. In my own region of the West Midlands we have a brilliant example of CSR: Cadbury’s, the well-known chocolate company developed Bourneville, a model village on the south side of Birmingham for its factory workers to live. It was described as one of the nicest places to live in Britain. They put social responsibility at the heart of their company’s ethos. CSR is not just a benefit to society, it benefits the company too, often helping them to compete in the labour market and to become an employer of choice. I would like to see the Commission and Member States continue to promote the voluntary take-up of CSR initiatives. But let’s ensure that companies always retain the flexibility and the freedom to shape their own CSR policy according to their specific circumstances and the needs of their employees.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Mr President, thank you very much, Commissioner, not only am I speaking on behalf of the ALDE Group, but it just happens that I am the coordinator responsible for drawing up a joint motion for a resolution on the subject of corporate social responsibility. The reality that no agreement has been reached to vote tomorrow is that all the groups, which have had 72 hours to work on this issue, have seen that there was a possibility of reaching agreements if they let us work a little longer. Obviously, the ALDE Group's position is that Parliament is not here to deal with a particular problem of a company — imagine how many companies there are — but to talk about strengthening, improving that win-win situation, which is corporate social responsibility. This is an excellent tool for enterprises which creates a win-win situation because it allows for improved social dialogue, allows companies to undoubtedly improve their productivity, competitiveness and image, and, at the same time, obviously, has very favourable social repercussions. We are therefore going to develop, adapt, to improve what the Commission said, for example, in 2013 on corporate social responsibility. I must say that it is not appropriate to transform the concept, and that is where we are going to debate how far it can go. It is an instrument in the hands of companies and is an instrument for socially reacting to the strategic decisions of enterprises, but it is not an instrument that has to set business strategy, but is it going to be adapted in the most socially way; nor is it an instrument that can never be used to prevent mobility or free installation of companies or their long-term strategies and less when it comes to going from Europe to Europe. That's true, too. Let us strengthen corporate social responsibility, but do not transform it into an obstacle to the creation of a very mobile, very diverse and very competent Europe.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE group. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the problem of placing companies is a broad problem, because of a system we have built, the system of globalization of an open market and free and that is sovereign over everything. The problem, however, is also how the European Union responds to these kinds of problems and how it responds to the workers in Whirlpool and the Embraco who are here to listen to this debate today. And we as Parliament may not have a responsibility for having to give concrete answers, but at least we could have a resolution that said how we want to respond to these kinds of issues. Resolution that tomorrow we will not have, because we have taken a month to think about it, a resolution which should have some firm points to say what are the answers to these problems, for example, a tax common minimum that is shared between all countries to prevent countries from competing with each other by stealing companies, and for example clear, clean and correct use of European funds to prevent the companies that take these funds then run away to another country, which is happening all the time. These are the answers that today perhaps the Embraco workers wanted to be told and that tomorrow instead will not have.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, in order to operate, a company benefits from many public resources available by the community: schools and training, health and social protection services, public transport, roads and various infrastructure, and sometimes even European appropriations. contribute. These companies therefore have a social, territorial and ecological responsibility towards society and their employees. However, they are obviously more concerned about their rate of return to the detriment of the general interest. We must therefore define a binding framework setting social responsibilities. CSR cannot be a hollow and unefficient concept as I hear about it here. Relocations or downsizing should be blocked when it comes to increasing stock market profits. When it comes to technological or digital modernization that increases productivity, the reduction of working time and training should be encouraged. Social responsibility is also a new sharing of value, thus improving wages and respecting subcontractors. This must lead us to create a minimum wage. It also means paying its contributions to the common good, while a study has just shown that multinationals' taxes have fallen by 9% since 2008. Yes, there is an urgent need to establish an effective, not hollow framework in the interests of society as a whole.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, rather than the social responsibility of companies, we should discuss the social responsibility of the Europe. Because, as my colleagues have already explained, the fact that the Embraco has tried to move to Slovakia and send 500 workers home is a problem, not so much because this company needs to move to for some reason, because it is already active, the problem is that it is the very structure of Europe that allows and incentivizes these behaviors. And it is useless to find palliative solutions, you have to solve the problem at the root. Perhaps Bratislava used European funds to favour tax relief, but that wouldn't be, and that's not the point. Slovakia is more competitive than Italy because, while part of the euro, it has lower taxation and lower labour costs. If Europe incentivizes the movement of capital between such different states, it should at least assess its impacts on employment and the economy, and of course implement concrete countervailing measures for people who they lose their jobs. However, Europe's response is too weak, and that does not surprise me, given that not even here, within the European Parliament, can we find a compromise and vote tomorrow on a resolution on the Embraco case. And I would like the workers here to know that they have to thank the obstructionism of the People's Party, the ECR, the ALDE, who try to erase any reference to the Embraco case. In nine months the truce negotiated in favour of Embraco workers will end, and these 500 people who are here this evening, 500 families, will again face the spectre of unemployment. So, by then, Commissioner, a solution will have to be found. Europe must end fiscal and social competition between its countries, otherwise it will start a race to the bottom where we will be lost.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a lot of bad faith in this debate, the bad faith of those who have forgotten that they voted lightly for the extension of Europe to these countries of the East, which have a very different and competitive social legislation and productive economic situation. A war between peoples was triggered, rather than making peoples Europe, for the interests of those who wanted to exploit this enlargement to the East for financial reasons. And then, Commissioner Malmström, you must not come here and tell us, as you have for years, the usual bales about answers when there are these crises. You must acknowledge the very serious mistakes that this Europe of bankers has made. You have elected President of this European Government the multinational tax evasion theorist, who clearly wants to continue with you to carry out these policies of overpowering the real economy of those works and produces, small entrepreneurs and the workers who have it in that place, it is a disgrace, you should be ashamed in front of these people, rather than continue to play your games, with your parties accomplices who do not even dare to write in the resolutions the name of this factory, the name, because in my Turin the word worker is written with the capital “O”, shame! (The speaker beats on the table during his surgery. Mr Šojdrová asks to ask a “blue card” question, but the speaker leaves the House as soon as he finished his speech).

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr President, before I start my speech, I would like to ask that the gallery be reassured. Please, you are only listeners here and should not interfere with the discussion. I will be very grateful to you. Mr President! Creating incentives for business to be socially responsible is extremely important. Especially these days, when the pursuit of profit messages other equally important aspects. Businesses, and particularly larger ones, are often an integral part of a particular geographical area and become one of the relevant sources of employment and income. Fortunately, businesses are creating various programs within the social responsibility of business. I have examples of this in my region as well. However, I am convinced that the creation of a programme within the social responsibility of business should be due to the will of the enterprise concerned. No such obligation should be made by European legislation. Rather, we should focus on incentives for entrepreneurs that can take different forms — tax incentives, for example, as well as image incentives. It is necessary to increase awareness of consumers and convince them that it is worth buying products or using the services of businesses that promote good employment conditions, protect the environment or support the local community. I was surprised by the proposal that, as part of corporate social responsibility, introduce a ban on relocation of companies from one country to another. The decision on the business model and the place of business is a matter for companies. This is a fundamental, treaty-guaranteed freedom within the framework of the European Union. I believe that we should pay more attention to the instruments in which we are able to erode the effects of relocation and provide workers with retraining or other attractive employment. Europe has instruments to use for this purpose. One is a community fund. Its effective use can provide a balance between employee protection and the freedom to manage the company. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Question “blue card”. — Colleague, I would like to ask you — I hope it was a mistranslation — I would like to ask you to apologize to the people you appealed as “only viewers”. I wish you would realize that those are first and foremost people who are losing their jobs over these rules, who actually are on treaties: You talked about freedom of establishment. I would like to understand what wealth it creates, in a European Union, to take away the work and livelihood of five hundred families in order to move them somewhere else, from your point of view.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: answer to the question posed by picking up the blue card. — Speaking of listeners, I referred to the noise that listeners caused on the gallery. As far as your question is concerned, I think it is very important that we play open cards. If, in a given market, a company has problems with retaining employees, dismisses them gradually of five, ten people and cannot use any other instrument, the instruments provided by the European Union should be used — for example, a social fund that will allow for retraining laid off workers. Very many examples in Europe show that these people are even more satisfied with the work they are doing.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – Mr President, I want to talk about two things tonight. First, I want the Commission to investigate cases where companies decide to relocate their production within the EU. We need to make sure that EU funds have not been used in such a way that they are actually creating competition between Member States. Secondly, it is unacceptable that large companies can pretend to be socially responsible by developing social initiatives, or through charity, when, on the other hand, they are not paying the taxes they owe to society. I heard the Commissioner mention a roadmap, but can I please ask for an ambitious new action plan on corporate social responsibility (CSR) with legal requirements, with stronger reporting obligations and with more effective control mechanisms? To come back to the question of taxes, this action plan should also include the disclosure of tax payments in CSR reporting. It is time to expose this hypocrisy, and for that I am counting on the Commission and its proposal before the end of the year.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would also like to use this opportunity, a little bit like Ms Jongerius, to raise the concern that the Commission is not acting, even if the Council and Parliament have both called for such a comprehensive action plan on responsible business conduct. And I think most of us don’t understand why the Commission is not going to do this, because now, in the absence of actions at EU level, the Member States are acting. For instance, we see that France already has put in place a law on duty of vigilance; the Netherlands is fighting against child labour; and others are following: the UK, Switzerland and so on. We need a level playing field so that all companies would have to follow the same rules on corporate social responsibility. And by the way, I think this notion of corporate social responsibility is already a bit outdated. We should talk about corporate accountability, which is a broader subject, and we need European-level actions.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: Mr President, promote sustainable development, combat waste generation, protect biodiversity, and so on. These are Carrefour's social responsibility values, but they could be Mercadona's, Embraco, Inditex or many others. The reality is very different. Many continue to transfer activities to countries with cheaper labour, such as the example of Embraco, which will close its subsidiary in Italy to go to Slovakia. Marketing campaigns are totally legitimate, but don't confuse advertising with regulation, because if we do, we take a step further towards disaster. There are companies that look the other way when their subcontractors use slave labor. It's unfortunate, but “it's the world, it's the rules of the game,” many of you will tell me. That is precisely what you need to do: change the rules of the game, or, rather, set rules to the game, because they don't exist now. We're like in the jungle. We cannot leave people's lives and life on earth in the hands of the goodwill of businesses. We need laws, binding laws, that hold companies accountable for the consequences of their activity on society and on the world, and so that, if there are violations, of course there will be sanctions.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, it is not unreasonable to expect major companies to pay a fair share of tax and be aware of their effect on the societies in which they operate. After all, individuals with far less power and wealth are expected to meet these basic benchmarks. The EU’s approach to corporate social responsibility is, in fact, not all that well developed. For many years the EU served effectively as a facilitator for tax-dodging by corporations, enabling smaller Member States, such as Luxembourg or Ireland, to strike sweetheart deals that eroded the tax bases of larger members. It is now attempting to construct a new system that will make profit-shifting and other aggressive avoidance more difficult within the EU, but this would be better done globally by the OECD. Other measures to improve corporate responsibility can be implemented at a national level, so long as governments are not shorn of powers to do so. For example, rules limiting the salary of the highest-paid employee of a corporation to a fixed multiple of the lowest-paid employee could be put to national electorates in elections. Too often in recent years, the corporate sector has taken refuge behind high-profile, politically-correct sponsorship schemes which provide a sheen of good publicity, which is then used to camouflage a generally ruthless approach on such issues as importing cheap labour rather than training local labour. A survey published on Monday by the Financial Times showed that, over the past decade, the effective tax rate paid by multinational corporations has plummeted, even as the tax ramp on workers has got worse. All of us on the right of centre in politics would do well, I think, to recognise that nothing has done more to undermine the standing of free-enterprise economics than the excesses of multinational corporations. Unless there is big improvement in their behaviour, it is likely to give radical leftists a way into power, bringing with them all kinds of prosperity-destroying ideas.

name: Romana TOMC
text: — I am pleased that the awareness of the importance of socially responsible behaviour has reached many companies operating in the European Union. Not all of them, but certainly all those that show good results of the business. They recognise that long-term business success cannot be achieved without taking into account environmental and human impacts in their operations. But social responsibility is not something that could be enforced overnight. It's about a philosophy that requires time. Therefore, it is important to talk about it and emphasize the positive effects, which, of course, are not few. In principle, companies that are socially responsible are more successful in the market, offer better jobs and behave more responsibly towards protecting the environment. As a member of the Employment Committee, I am primarily interested in the employee-related aspect. In this area, positive results are shown in greater employee affiliation, greater motivation, less sick absences and this all of course again leads to an overall better result. We should also be aware that in some places social responsibility is greatly promoted by the actions of the state, through tax breaks.
