And we as policy guideline makers need to support good practices in the field of social responsibility, but I warn, in doing so, we must be careful not to burden businesses with new requirements and new obligations. So we will acquire everyone: businesses, employees, the environment and society as a whole.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, Mrs Malmström. Corporate social responsibility must not stop on transparency and voluntary codes of conduct. What has happened in Italy is once again clear: we need a Europe-wide framework for the involvement of the workforce in business decisions. The existence of almost 500 workers and their families was destroyed in one fell swoop. How can the Commission justify that there is still no directive on information and consultation for the whole of Europe? In the context of the debate on the future of the European Union, the Commission must also consider how we intend to improve the European legal framework for multinational companies. The decades in which the European Union alone has strengthened shareholder access must be over! The social responsibility of the large corporations still lived today follows the understanding of a Milton Friedman of the seventies of the last century. He said that the CSR consists solely of the provision of jobs and taxes. As we see, not even this is alive today. So we need this Europe-wide framework. Dear Mrs. Malmström, stand up for this!

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: — Mr President, corporate social responsibility is obviously not a PR charity. The social responsibility of companies can understand, in addition to financing public benefit projects, corporate, environmental or social policies, how they affect their activities atmosphere in society. So let's talk about double standards as well. On working conditions in parent and subsidiary firms, on relations between labour productivity and wages, on payment or non-payment of taxes. Let us entertain whether companies do not create employees and consumers of the first and second category, not only from the perspective of third countries, but also here, in the European Union. Even that can have an effect on people's relationship to the society we live in. Czech has one fitting recommendation: “To sweep before your own threshold.”

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you heard there is a drama about 497 Italian workers and workers. They could be from any other European country. What matters is that this danger run it because European rules are not enough rules. Jacques Delors spoke for the first time about social responsibility in the 1993 White Paper, asking companies responsible behaviour and asking Parliament, already at that time, to define rules that were effective. We don't have these norms today. It is true that those involving social responsibility have been rewritten several times, and we have done so recently as well. But there is a vulnus: they are not obligatory. And when those rules are simply optional and only question the reputations of businesses that don't comply with them, what we're commenting happens. Because Whirlpool and Embraco have beautiful volumes, which they publish every year, about their social responsibility, they say that their activities are sustainable, that they are socially and environmentally responsible. That's not the case! They say they have a very good relationship with the territories and the associations that organize and represent them. That's not the case! The rules on social responsibility need to be changed. Then I think it would be very useful one thing, a political act. The Commission will take action on Whirlpool. The facts, even small or seemingly small ones, than so many statements of principle matter much more. If you summon the company and ask the company to change direction of travel, putting things back in place, you will have made an exception to the rule, but a political act of which many will give you notice people.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: Mr President, it has been almost 20 years since the Green Paper was published, the first major document that the European Union produced for the promotion of corporate social responsibility. For the first ten years, Commissioner, the European Union did many things and did them well; in the last seven or eight years, it has done almost nothing, almost nothing. The European Union is no longer the instrument for promoting social responsibility, and experience shows us that, unfortunately, voluntariness has become a kind of policy in favour of social marketing rather than social responsibility. There is a serious problem here, because the citizens, the workers who accompany us today do not believe in the responsibility of companies if there is no real coherence between what is social responsibility and what is their work behaviour. This is the demand I want to make: we need a European policy to promote social responsibility; there is a need for a comprehensive policy in favour of corporate social responsibility in all areas of their work, tax, social, etc.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Embraco-Whirlpool workers have not only the spectre of dismissal next December, they have seen cuts in their salaries of 300 euros, they have not been able to do so. plus the canteen, they have to eat cold, no longer have the means to go to work, they go by their means to pay for themselves. This is a very serious thing. So we ask, in addition to the unity on the resolution that we must do, very strongly, that any negative initiative against workers be discontinued, suspended, erased any negative initiative against workers. Because we have to stop with tax shopping in Europe, wage shopping, we can't talk about this: it's very serious! What is social responsibility in front of people who are 55-58 years old? It is difficult to find work at this age. There is a very easy outgoing flexibility, but it is very difficult to have a chance to enter and relocate. Then this is social ruberia, one takes and carries, perhaps even with regional public funds or even the European Union. You have to stop any negative action against these workers who were sent away just for a round of applause. It's very serious, President!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what is happening to the Embraco company is called social dumping for lower wages, tax dumping for lower rates, and it is deprecable behaviour and irresponsible because it doesn't aim to value human resources, but to fire. Embraco, which has benefited from public support and funding in the past, declares that it adheres to a code of ethics and the principles of the United Nations global compact, unless it proves a business practice anything but based on the principles of social responsibility. Corporate social responsibility must become a fundamental element of European policies and be an indispensable requirement for access to public funds and to participate in procurement. European funds cannot be used to transfer jobs. I therefore expect the European Commission to take exemplary measures, should it be confirmed that the incentives put in place by the Slovak Government constitute a violation of the rules on the State aid. Government subsidies cannot in any way benefit some member countries to the detriment of others within the single market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Mr President, corporate social responsibility means that businesses should be taxed where they make profits. And of course that is not the case, because the multinationals exploit tax havens and thus evade tax and evade tax. Billions no longer go to the budgets of the Member States. But, of course, ECOFIN is also in this, which, in its recent decision on 23 January, took Panama off the list of tax havens, with the agreement of the Greek Government, Mr Tsakalotos, and indeed yesterday continued the same thing: Again with the agreement of the Greek Government, Mr Tsakalotos, Mr. Tsakalotos and Greece, ECOFIN removed three other countries from the black list of tax havens, including the Marshall Islands. Is it possible to continue this situation?! From then on, the monument of social irresponsibility of businesses is, of course, relocations. After having taken the European Union's money, they are now relocating to other regions and leaving thousands of people unemployed. A classic example was Embraco, who left Italy for Slovakia.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: — Mr President, I believe that the subject of corporate social responsibility is one of the most fundamental ever that we should solve in the twenty-first century. I find it completely undeniable the fact that just like every individual and state, so do companies and corporations have a huge responsibility for the state of this world. If companies degrade the environment and abuse cheap labor, we'll find it hard to talk about human rights and climate protection here. If companies and corporations don't pay taxes and prefer to “lump” them into tax havens, then here we will have another and more investigative panels. Taxes will be paid by those who do not “lump” money, and we will address the lack of funds for pensions. This is not a sustainable state, this is at the centre of future crises, this points to the unfairness of the current system. And we have to do now.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr President! I don't think the Commission's statement is understood. My impression is that the interpretation of this document is too often expanding, and in some given exmplifications not very precise. The responsibility, which we refer to as social responsibility for the activity of European companies and subcontractors outside, outside Europe, and because of the effects obtained here in Europe, must be heavily overhauled. My feeling is that this document should be more adequate, more timely, and at the same time better suited to the principle that is widely accepted — that the responsibility of companies is no grace, that possible social effects do not mean dealing in favor of their employees some extraordinary effort. It is simply predicting specific effects that have very broad, very global significance and such activity effects. Whereas at the end I'll only add one thing. It cannot be that this is required from Europe, from European actors, and not applied to external actors.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the EU’s policy on corporate social responsibility should include a gender aspect. Here are some specific measures the Commission can take. Firstly, encourage corporations to increase the representation of women and LGBTIAQ+ in management positions and at all levels. Secondly, support lifelong learning for women at work, including trade union learning, particularly in male dominated sectors. Thirdly, ensure adequate work conditions and rights for women and LGBTIAQ+ people throughout the supply chains. Fourthly, avoid sourcing material from conflict areas where there is widespread gender-based violence. With regard to ethics and CSR, can I applaud the tireless work of the ‘Art Not Oil’ coalition whose powerful culture and sustained campaign depicting oil soaked birds was successful in persuading the Tate Art Gallery to dump the multinational BP.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, corporate social responsibility is an increasingly popular issue. It emphasizes that businesses voluntarily take into account the protection of human rights, the environment and other societal criteria in their activities. I just want to be reminded that this is nothing new. Ninety years ago, the firm of Tomáš and Jan Bata knew that it had to take care of its employees if it was to be sustainable in the long term. They weren't just about their own profit. Corporate social responsibility should remain largely voluntary. We can't command companies that they have to do business only in a specific place. But I understand my colleagues from Italy, I also understand the staff who came here to present themselves, I understand their concerns and their movements, but I think that is primarily in this case the Italian government and national state governments, which must engage with their incentives and conditions for advantageous business of companies.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are discussing many different, very important issues today. The subject of this debate, as communicated to the Commission, was corporate social responsibility. Now we are on a much wider agenda. As I said, the European Union does a lot on corporate social responsibility, inside and outside Europe. We can always do more, of course, and that is why we have set up this multi-stakeholder platform to give us input and ideas, and we are also carrying out an internal assessment to see whether there are loopholes or things we can do better. And I have taken good note of things you said. The granting of regional investment aid, however, that involves the relocation of jobs from elsewhere in the EU is subject to strict Commission control. The state aid rules provide safeguards to prevent Member States from using public money to incentivise the relocation of jobs from one country in the EU to another. That is at the heart of fair competition in the internal market, and it is why, as long ago as 2014, we introduced specific conditions to ensure that regional investment aid cannot be granted to incentivise the relocation of jobs and business activities from one country to another. Arrangements were strengthened in 2017 to ensure that these rules work well in practice. The company the honourable Members are referring to today has not received any support under regional development funds in Italy. We have contacted Slovakia to investigate whether any investment aid was given to Embraco from them, and we are still awaiting a response. We, as the Commission, can act under state aid rules only if companies or sectors get a selective advantage that is not available for everyone, and we work to ensure that the general labour and taxation rules in Europe work for everybody. Should you have any indication that state aid might have led to relocation, my colleague Commissioner Vestager and her staff are ready to have a look at the relevant information. And, as I said, we are working constantly in a dialogue, not only with big, small and medium-sized companies but also with NGOs, with stakeholders and with trade unions and labour organisations, to see how we can endeavour to improve corporate social responsibility. Then on the tax issue, that is a totally different issue – related, I agree, to a certain extent, but subject to other types of activity and legislation – which was discussed in this Chamber earlier today, I think.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Discussion is over. The vote will take place on Thursday.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item is the report by Thomas Mann and Svetoslav Hristov Malinov, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Culture and Education, on the proposal for a European Parliament and Council decision on a a common framework for the provision of better services for skills and professional qualifications (Europass) and for the repeal of Decision No. 2241/2004/EC (COM (2016) 0625 - C8-0404/2016 - 2016/0304 (COD)) (A8-0244/2017)

name: Thomas MANN
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. With more than 100 million CVs since 2005, Europass is a successful, cost-effective initiative at European level. It helps young and old to document skills, competences, qualifications, but also professional and personal aptitudes. Standardised forms are used to provide transparency and facilitate the evaluation process. Students and jobseekers are assured that qualified data will become an important cross-border decision-making tool, both for employers, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as for public authorities and institutions. Our aim was to simplify the Europass, make it more user-friendly and make it an even more efficient tool. In the European Parliament, we agreed that the transformation of the Europass into a completely new form would have been too radical. In the Council, too, 14 Member States had significant concerns. The European Commission reacted constructively so that a proposal initially heavily criticized gradually became a substantial portfolio for more European mobility. After ten months of work with many technical meetings, we agreed in the fourth trilogue in mid-December 2017. The use of the Europass will not be compulsory, it will remain voluntary. I thank the shadow rapporteurs and the members of the two Committees, Employment and Social Affairs and Culture and Education, for the climate of openness and fairness. Dear Mr Svetoslav Malinov, we as co-rapporteurs have worked together excellently, no doubt which, I believe, is a good basis for this report. The Council and the Commission have pursued consensus in the same way and achieved it with us. The result: the Europass is not overburdened, the administrative and financial expenses for the Europass will not be overburdened. Member States are absolutely manageable and the cost-benefit ratio is balanced. The continued existence of the national Europass Centres remains assured. This group of experts has existed since 2004. There is competence, there is know-how, everything is proved, it was never a prevention machine. We have succeeded in preventing the introduction of ESCO into the Europass. While we agree on the objective — better education, better qualifications and much more — a uniform terminology for determining professional aptitudes and key skills does not yet have the necessary maturity. We are looking at ESCO; at the moment it is a project that needs to be tested before it can really be used. The results of the fourth trialogue were agreed at a joint meeting of both Employment and Culture Committees. 64 voted in favour, four voted no, and none abstained. I think this is a good joint success. So we have a chance. A revised Europass — perhaps it can start early next year. European mobility would then have a new and very attractive face.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, the Europass initiative was born nearly twelve years ago and aimed to meet a strong need for European citizens, namely to ensure easy access to the opportunities and means of assessing their skills and qualifications. Every citizen needs this and especially when he is looking for a job and decides what and where to study. Differences in languages, definitions, document formats and evaluation and validation methods make it difficult for everyone: from students and jobseekers to employers and government institutions. Not to mention the additional problems posed by the growing mobility of Europeans by newly-joined countries and third-country nationals. The need for a clear common framework, common principles, common terminology covering all parties is unquestionable. Thus began Europass, primarily as a dossier of documents ensuring maximum transparency of citizens' qualifications and competences, used on a voluntary basis. From the outset, Europass has clearly stated objectives, valid until now: to help citizens present their skills and qualifications effectively to find jobs and training opportunities; to help employers understand and assess the skills and qualifications of the workforce; to help employers understand and assess the skills and qualifications of the workforce; to help of education and training organisations in the most reasonable way to define and present the content of curricula. No one can dispute the fact that Europass is one of the European Union's most successful and most popular initiatives. But although successful, the Europass initiative is no exception to the general rule that technology advances constantly require changes. Not only that, the Europass revision should reflect both changes in the labour market and new forms and practices in education and training. It should give people better and more user-friendly tools to represent their skills, as well as to obtain useful and up-to-date information on learning opportunities and the labour market. We are changing Europass to provide online services to European citizens, such as the creation of an e-portfolio and skill assessment, the so-called Skills' intelligence. We are changing Europass so that citizens easily provide information about their skills and qualifications acquired outside formal education and training, such as voluntary participation, in-work learning, traineeships, self-learning. Since the Europass changes are necessarily binding for all Member States, from the outset we searched and finally reached a consensus to defend the competences of nation states on standards for the different qualification systems. We were looking for changes to ensure easier access to Europass for people with disabilities and even better protection of personal data. We were looking for changes that would be bold and useful without, however, causing an excessive administrative burden on Member States, as well as excessive new organisational costs. I am confident that we have achieved these changes. I am convinced that, in the future, European citizens will use Europass more easily, more often and even with greater pleasure.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, in the fast—changing world of work, new digital technology is opening up new challenges but also new opportunities. The skills that people have when they leave school should be a solid basis, but now more than ever before, people need to grow and upskill during their lives and professional careers. Working patterns more and more often mean a change of job or profession, working in new ways or taking on new tasks, some of which we cannot predict today.  People need to be able to easily show and present their skills, identify their skills gaps and easily find the right learning opportunities to fill them. For over a decade, Europe has helped people to showcase their skills and qualifications across Europe. Many of you might know the Europass CV, which has had over 100 million downloads since it was created. It has already been successful, but the time has come – as the two rapporteurs said – to modernise it. In doing so, we want to make the most of the new technologies to ensure that Europass continues to support the needs of those looking for upskilling, mobility and career opportunities. I would like to warmly thank the two rapporteurs, Mr Mann and Mr Malinov, for your very constructive approach to this during the interinstitutional discussions. The amendments from you strengthen the Commission’s proposal, for instance by highlighting the need for Europass to be fully accessible to people with disabilities or elderly persons. I want to thank the entire team in Parliament and the Council for the excellent cooperation, allowing us to reach a timely agreement on this Europass decision.  We have made progress on the implementation of the New Skills Agenda for Europe. The Commission has delivered on all its ten priority actions. Our aim, which is well reflected in the text that we have now agreed, is to provide an ambitious, forward—looking framework that offers modern tools for describing skills. The new Europass will include the electronic skills portfolio, which will allow users to create, store and share documents and information on their skills and qualifications. It will include a self—assessment tool that will allow users to identify new skills they may need, share the results, add them to their CV, store the results in Europass and map their progress over time by comparing with previous self—assessment results. It would also include skills intelligence, which is up—to—date information on trends and demands in different sectors, countries and professions across Europe. This information can help individuals in their career management. All these tools to support people’s careers and upskilling choices bring an added value to Europeans. The new Europass text lays the basis for the next step towards closer cooperation and easier communication of skills and qualifications across the labour market, education and training sectors. Let me underline the important role of Europass in helping to deliver on the European Pillar of Social Rights. The right to education, training and lifelong learning and the right to active support for employment is enshrined in the Pillar. The modernised Europass can now play its full part in actively supporting these rights.  Together, we can deliver on our commitment to making the most of people’s skills. This is good news for individuals, as better matched skills improve their work and life opportunities. However, it is also good news for employers – they can easily find workers with the skills that they need – and it is good news for Europe. Unlocking people’s talent is the key to competing and succeeding in the global economy. So thank you again for the work you have done.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE group. — Thomas Mann and our colleague Hristov Malinov have created an excellent duo. Not only did they prepare the document itself well, but they also created an excellent pattern of temporal discipline, which is rare in the European Parliament. I thank them so much for this because it is a sign of respect for all other fellow MEPs. I will only address two matters: what features Europass has been listed first and these are the reasons: openness, voluntary, flexibility and adjustment to the needs of the market. If we add to this new challenges of digitisation, simplification, greater accessibility and the best response to changing conditions, they should be applauded, congratulated on the solutions and save us the time for further discussion.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, I’m glad that the Council and Parliament have agreed to the creation of an online platform managed by the Commission with the aim to make easily available information to end users through a single portal. There will be services offering guidance for transnational learning, mobility and information on skills and qualifications that could be relevant to the particular needs for third country nationals and that will be especially useful when it comes to integration. The aim to make Europe as more user friendly is an important one as it’s making potential users more aware of it. The Member States will work together with different stakeholders to achieve this according to the agreement, perhaps the Commission’s new proposal for a European Labour Authority can also be helpful in that regard. We have nonetheless reached a compromise on skills intelligence, which was controversial from the start. Now users of the online platform will be able to find an analysis of supply and demand of skills in the labour market and of corresponding learning opportunities. Our labour markets are, as has been said earlier here, changing very quickly, and the most important skill moving forward will be flexibility. Member States who do not already have education and training systems that allow and support lifelong learning will need to get on that quickly, and I’m glad also that the Commissioner mentioned the social pillar, since this is one of the points on that agenda.

name: Czesław HOC
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! We welcome the new European programme for skills, competence and qualifications. Favorable changes have been made to the transparency of the Europass portfolio, importantly, on a voluntary basis. Changes are being made incrementally, without increasing administrative costs. Recall, Europass is a set of documents to present skills and qualifications clearly and comprehensively throughout Europe, so curriculum vitae, language passport, Europass mobility — i.e. knowledge and qualifications acquired in another European country, and diploma supplements confirming vocational qualifications and completion of tertiary studies. The current favourable changes are the practical alignment of Europass services to the needs and expectations of users and service providers, respecting the diversity of responsibilities, including people with disabilities, simplifying the system and improving efficiency, including the capabilities of future digital systems. Europass will improve understanding of learning outcomes in formal and non-formal settings, as well as through practical experiences, including mobility. Great congratulations to both rapporteurs.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: for the ALDE Group. — Dear Thomas, dear Svetoslav, thank you for your cooperation. I have greatly appreciated our positive cooperation since the beginning, from the committee negotiations to the conclusion of the trialogue. They say the best way to predict the future is to create it. If we are interested in the future needs of the labour market, I think it is doubly true. Europe's prosperity depends on its greatest wealth, and it's not mineral resources or state-of-the-art technology, but it's us, the Europeans, who live and work here. In a rapidly changing global world, our skills will be the driver of our competitiveness. Therefore, it depends on the readiness of graduates, because thanks to their application in the labour market, they will be able to perform interesting and skilled work and lead a better life. The new version of Europass tailored to new technologies and specific needs is the answer to how to boost and make people's skills even more visible. With the new Europass, they will be able to show their skills and qualifications more easily and choose from offers of work across Europe. Europass is an important tool to promote labour mobility. Travel for work is an important solution to reducing unemployment, especially among young people, which is alarming in some countries and some regions. I believe that the potential for labour mobility remains untapped in Europe. So we should encourage young Europeans more to gain not only study, but also work experience abroad. Driving beyond the comfort and security of home and staying in foreign competition will give them confidence and insight. And it is Europeans that we need.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (EL) Mr President, Commissioner, Europass at first glance seems to be a simple tool where professional qualifications, skills and competences can be pooled, identified and communicated so that there is a better interconnection between those seeking education and work and those providing them. But it is well known that the tools are not neutral or operate autonomously, but implement specific policies. In essence, they are the means to implement political guidelines. Europass is therefore called upon to support and technically support the neoliberal policies of the European Union on education and employment. So what is the centre of gravity of this platform to be created? Will it be easier for workers to look for jobs and ensure decent and quality jobs? Will it be the strengthening of all-round education and culture? I'm afraid it won't be. On the contrary, the aim will be a collection of sterile pieces of knowledge ready for assembly according to the requirements of the market and the dominant economic interests. A skill auction that will act as a means of pushing wages down and worsening working conditions, since we will have high skills with low pay. In this context, the instrumental and utilisational approach to education is further strengthened. The economic crisis, unemployment, precariousness, non-rights work and the migration of young people, especially from Greece and the countries of the South, are not due to the lack of tools or to the mismatch of offered and requested skills. It is the result of the neoliberal policies of the European Union and its way in which it operates.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think we can say that we have We will have an effective regulatory tool for identifying, understanding and communicating skills and qualifications. Finally through a single portal, free and accessible to disabled people, various tools and services will be available to citizens to use and enhance, even at European level, competences and qualifications learned in the national sphere, with the recognition of skills acquired also in contexts of non-formal and informal learning, skills that are too often underestimated and difficult to communicate. The new regulatory framework will therefore only have a positive effect on European citizens studying and seeking work, as well as for employers and educational and training institutions, by favouring so transparency and mobility. In any case, I would like to remind you that much remains to be done in education, education and employment, especially for the younger group. Governments need to invest massively in long-term education and literacy policies, and labour policies aim to ensure stable, quality and adequately paid jobs, avoiding tampon and short breath measures, which are only good for campaigning.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: — (beginning of the intervention outside micro)... thank you to the Commission for its proposal, thank you to the co-rapporteurs for their quality work. The new skills strategy has one key objective: to leave no one on the edge of the road. At the heart of this, a tool will allow greater transparency: the Europass portfolio. More complete than a CV, it is a document that will help citizens to inventory their skills and qualifications. It already exists, but it was time to renovate it, to bring it to the taste of the day. In the future, it will be adapted to digital developments and will also reflect the needs and trends of each professional sector. Any experience has value and with Europass we will be able to value all the skills acquired in the different forms of learning, whether formal, non-formal or informal, or even volunteering or associative work. There is also a place for lifelong learning, and the mobility experiences promoted by the Erasmus Mobility Europass + will be highlighted in this new portfolio. Europass's revised services will be tailored to the needs and expectations of different actors, whether learners, jobseekers, employers, educational and training institutions, social partners, national Europass centres or competent national authorities. The success of these new tools is also due to the commitment of all to the same objective: to establish and advance towards a Europe that is truly a social Europe, listening to all learners, all workers but also all companies.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: — Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all the colleagues who have worked together to create a new Europass framework. I am pleased that, after more than ten years of existence, the Europass platform will be modernised and more accessible to its users. The review that Europass has now undergone was already needed to bring it closer to today's user habits and to take it one step further. Despite the fact that over 100 million CVs have been generated through Europass over the last decade, I believe that Europass needs more visibility. Among many, it is still unknown, which is why I would like it to be used more nationally. In particular, schools, universities, youth organisations can contribute to its greater usability. By creating a new Europass platform that reflects current technological innovations, users will have easier access to information that will benefit their career growth, the choice of educational track or the recruitment process. The Europass platform will be based on online tools with content and features that will be accessible to users while providing a high level of protection of personal data. Users will have many new options such as Europass, which is why I believe it will continue to be beneficial to everyone.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Mr. President, Europass tools and services will ensure easier exchange of information and better understanding of skills and qualifications. If we want citizens to make better use of career opportunities, the establishment of a quality information exchange network is of great importance. The possibility of going to the most developed countries in Europe for education or work is a great opportunity for many citizens of underdeveloped members and countries could prosper from this because one day the top educated staff who learned from the best could return to them. It all looks so beautiful in theory. In practice, people find it difficult to return because their home countries do not offer them the opportunities they expect and what they can get in developed members. It is their right to choose where they want to live and work and we should defend that right, but as a responsible legislator we must also take care of the interests of the weaker developed members who are rapidly losing their population, especially the young and educated, thereby putting their economic and demographic viability at risk.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs and thank my colleagues for their contribution to this important file. I am convinced that we have ensured that the new common framework will make the Europass services more user-friendly and will adapt them to the needs and expectations of both the users and the providers, while respecting the established national structures and its voluntary basis. In addition, the revised Europass services should now be better adapted to digital developments, which is essential in our technologically-driven society. Moreover, the accessibility of Europass for older people and persons with disabilities had to be improved in order to facilitate and encourage their participation in the labour market and in society as a whole. We will achieve that with the planned modernisation of the tools and expansion of the platform. One of the main objectives for our group was to improve significantly the understanding of learning, acquired not only in formal, but also in non-formal and informal settings, and through practical experiences, including mobility. The methods of teaching and learning are constantly evolving, and we need to ensure that the Europass services recognise those developments.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: Mr President, updating the Europass tool will be very necessary, especially at this time of high youth unemployment and the gradual digitisation of labour markets, where new types of qualifications are combined with new types of work. It is a step forward that this tool incorporates the possibility of including non-formal and informal knowledge, skills and qualifications in the curriculum. However, I think it is a pity that this reform does not include the possibility of establishing interoperability between different languages, again stumbling upon the same stone that made Europass never become entirely successful. If young people choose not to use Europass to update their curriculum or look for jobs, it is because they do not consider it a comparatively useful tool — as has been stated by various associations. But let's not forget that this tool is just a small piece inside a gear that is still broken. Our unemployed young people continue to train and access poor quality jobs, working conditions are increasingly precarious and in many countries exile is a real drama. It is urgent to find a solution and implement policies for quality in employment.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, a shared language to describe the competences of EU citizens in a transparent and interoperable way between Member States is essential in a common European space. Students and jobseekers, as well as employers and education institutions, should be able to convey and understand information easily on skills and qualifications. By supporting information sharing in this field in a consistent way across borders, Europass documents have already proven their usefulness, both for individuals looking for work or study opportunities throughout Europe, and for employers in selecting candidates with the appropriate skills to their needs. This is why it is so important to keep it relevant, in step with changing technologies and practices, interoperable with other EU instruments, and capable of describing skills acquired through non-formal learning. Having said this, I also welcome the report’s emphasis on keeping this instrument simple and effective and its objective of improving accessibility for older people and persons with disabilities. Evidence shows that people with lower digital literacy are less likely to use Europass, and therefore less likely to benefit from its advantages.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, the economic sun is shining in Europe, but for many Europeans it is still a clean appearance. Youth unemployment in a number of Member States is still high and many older people are on the sidelines of the labour market. Therefore, the Europass is a good addition to helping people get back to work: a free online platform where people can easily create a CV or add information to an official certificate, making it easier to understand for employers or institutions in the abroad. In an era where more and more work is being done across borders, job vacancies are increasingly found online and applications can also be sent digitally, a platform such as Europass is a logical choice. However, we must ensure that people lose their connection to the European labour market. Digibites run the risk of missing the connection and this group deserves our permanent attention. Nevertheless, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their work. I naturally support the proposal for the reformed Europass in the field of peoples.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs who have allowed such a rapid course of approval of the Europass revision. Europass is a very welcome free European service, serving for 12 years all interested people who want to get information on skills and qualifications, and it also helps to increase mobility within the common market for workers and services. At this point, I want to take advantage of the situation and say that I am glad that this legislation has not encountered the same problems as, for example, the e-card, which should also allow simplification for the provision of services in the internal market. Of course, there is a need for this modernization, because it does not use enough digital services, so in this direction it is a welcome upgrade of this tool. The work of Europass national centres should also be improved. Mr President, I believe I have had a minute and a half, but if not, I will be happy to end it by thanking everyone for their cooperation, and I believe that Europass will serve.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I very much congratulate the rapporteurs of the Committee on Culture and Labour and the shadow rapporteurs, and I thank very much for the excellent agreement with the Commission and the Council. This is really a concrete first step towards the implementation of the European agenda for new competences, but above all, it is the signal that now the real resources to focus on in Europe, including for a new pillar Social, for inclusion, but also for innovation and work, are human resources. I believe that it is, with this measure, to have adapted also through the online platform, with more accessible tools and services, also the possibility of recognizing each other's skills and also formal and non-formal competences, in a European framework of greater support, in particular, not only for new generations but also for adults who lose their jobs or seek new opportunities. What is interesting is that they give opportunities not only to individuals, but also to employers, to those involved in training. And we guarantee in particular three aspects that I want to remember only as titles: the greater protection of personal data than in the past, the greater access to the disadvantaged, volunteering — the competences are recognised — and above all, and I am closing, the recognition of the competences of third-country nationals.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr President! More than a decade since the adoption of the Europass's introduction decision, it urgently needs to be upgraded and adjusted not only to the new labour market situation, but also because of the technological revolution that took place during this time. I agree with the rapporteurs that making Europass a whole new instrument would be too radical. However, this system should focus more on improving the understanding of learning outcomes achieved in non-formal and informal settings, as well as through practical experiences, including mobility. The amendments proposed by the parliamentary committees are significant for several reasons. Europass's primary cuff is its poor recognition among potential beneficiaries. Therefore, it is a good idea to rename the national skills coordination points to the National Europass Centres. This seemingly simple move will promote the system in Member States' societies. Changes ensuring the participation of community organisations in the assessment of skills and qualifications are also worth supporting. This will increase the flexibility of the system, while maintaining the obligation to bind assessments to existing requirements. It is important to increase shares in the Europass system of disabled and elderly people. Given that these are socially discriminated groups in the labour market, it is necessary to facilitate them to demonstrate their education or skills, even those acquired in an informal or non-formal manner. Thank the rapporteurs for their excellent work.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, fellow Members, Europass is mainly known throughout Europe as the standard CV format, loved or criticised, but certainly used by many Europeans and beyond. We want to turn Europass into an online space for citizens who want to promote their skills and qualifications at European level, but also to find new opportunities for work, training or education. As a socialist MEP, I will always be a big supporter of European initiatives that directly support citizens in developing themselves personally and professionally. I strongly encourage access to this portal for all persons with disabilities or a lower degree of digital knowledge, but also to ensure better protection of personal data that will be stored on Europass. I also welcome the inclusion of the recognition of skills obtained through non-formal or informal education. I hope that Europass will thus boost Member States to implement these long-awaited recognition procedures, too. I consider the new Europass platform a successful idea of the European Union. That is why I urge you to ensure an efficient and quality development and implementation and, last but not least, adequate funding.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Mr President! For my part, my appreciation to the rapporteurs for the strategy adopted and work on adapting Europass to the requirements of the modern labour market. The European Union's legal basis for the Europass platform has been in place for many years, and was adopted even before the economic crisis. Therefore, changes are needed to reflect the opportunities and challenges facing today's workers and employers. Europass is a key initiative to increase the movement of workers in the European labour market by facilitating recognition of their competence at the level of different countries. Changes such as the introduction of an electronic portfolio or the ability to assess their own skills are crucial to the mobility of workers in the European Union, which is one of the pillars of the continent's economic integration. As a result, the revised decision will provide greater support than currently for those moving on the European labour market. Therefore, the document drawn up in the Tripartite Talks deserves the full support of Parliament.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, Europass is an instrument originally used by young people. Over time, the area of use has expanded to all age categories. The evolution of the way people work, learn or communicate today, as well as the instruments and services of the European Union must take account of rapid developments in society, precisely in order to meet current or future requirements and to be connected to the rapid progress of technologies emerging. The competences acquired at national level can now be used anywhere in Europe. It is normal that after ten years there will be an update of the Europass framework in order to be better correlated with the needs of the market, i.e. the needs of learners, jobseekers, education and training providers, recruiters and employers, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises. It will be beneficial for Europe to have a Europe-wide platform offering integrated services, covering the full range of European services on learning opportunities, vocational guidance and transparency of qualifications, as well as extending the use of a European classification of skills, skills, qualifications and occupations as a common language and operational tool for education, training and work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I would like to point out that, according to the programme, the debates will end at 10.30 p.m., so do not have any stress. We're not going to get there by midnight — so I can see from the computer system. In any case, the European Union, since with its policy of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment, has created millions of unemployed people, millions of poor people, is now giving them the Europass, the great solution. But Europass is a Europass for atypical forms of work. It's Europass for part-time work. It's Europass for rotating employment. In other words, these forms of industrial relations which have been established by decisions of the European Union and which do not guarantee real employment, do not guarantee real wages. It is a Europass for immigration. Five hundred thousand Greeks have left my country because of the memorandum. So I do not think that Europass resolves the real problem of unemployment.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much, sir. By sympathy, I want to say to you that I am in no hurry, but it is my duty to conduct a debate well and in an organized way. For that reason, I point out the time exceeding.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, I would like to support this proposal for a regulation and report because it regulates Europass's existing services to the needs and expectations of users and providers, students and applicants for employment, workers and employers. The main objective is its simplification, transparency, interoperability in each Member State and expediency. Because it turns out to be little-used by some social groups that are not digitally fully literate, it is, I think, very important to increase this property, that is, to have even digital use. Interest in Europass is also growing in the Czech Republic, with over two hundred thousand people already using it in 2015. On the other hand, I'm not entirely sure if the requirement of anonymous resumes to prevent discrimination, which I understand, is entirely correct. I'll still think about it.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I wanted to put on record my enthusiastic support for Europass. In my previous life, before I even thought about entering politics, I discovered Europass and have enjoyed using it ever since. I also encouraged the many young people with whom I used to work to use Europass. This included NEETs, and I can report that it was a very empowering experience for them. Now we have the prospect of an improved and updated Europass, and what is particularly good about the revision of this online tool is the way that it will be more inclusive and accessible for people with disabilities, for example. The new version will also enable migrants and refugees to log and showcase their skills and qualifications, and their formal and informal education. We know that they have much to offer. So we now need to see this excellent tool supported at Member State and European level, with a raft of socially progressive policies, programmes and resources in the area of education, lifelong learning, mobility and new employment initiatives.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you honourable Members for this debate and for the strong support you have shown. I think we can agree that in a fast-changing global economy the skills and know-how of our society are the sole basis for prosperity and for safeguarding our social achievements. Today marks an important step on how we prepare for the future of work and ensure that people have the support they need to grow their skills and put them to best use. This is not the only way to address the issues, but it is an important tool. Because this new Europass will support greater cooperation among stakeholders in the labour market and in the education and training sectors. It reaches out directly to people, offering them new tools and information to truly serve their needs. The Commission is looking forward to working closely with stakeholders on delivering on this new Europass. We see strong support here in the plenary, I also hope that the vote yesterday will show that. And we hope that, after it has gone to Council, it will enter into force before the summer. So again, thank you very much to the two rapporteurs, and the shadow rapporteurs, for the work you have done. It is rare to see such a broad consensus in the plenary for a proposal.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Commissioner! However, good proposals get support.

name: Thomas MANN
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to express my sincere thanks for what I think is a truly qualified debate. Some of them did not quite agree yet, but the large part has made that clear. What are we going to do with the Europass? We want to say: young people and students and experienced workers, show your talents, show your skills, imagine, make sure we have good data to help you get training so that you can find a job so you can change jobs too! That's the challenge we have. We have tried to modernise this important framework, which has already existed, to make it more inclusive, to become simpler, to become more user-friendly — I believe this is absolutely important — and to say that we need to use all the digital opportunities that exist in this way. Creating transparency is definitely an essential element. I think we have a good basis to work with. Whenever we say mobility is needed, there is such a good offer here, a qualified instrument with which we can work. Perhaps we can say afterwards that we have made our contribution to ensuring that more mobility can really take place.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: rapporteur. — I would like to share at the end of this successful debate that the beginning of work on the dossier was difficult. In fact, it was so difficult that the end was not in sight, it was not clear and whether there would be an end. Now is perhaps the time at the end of this process to share that many things could have been avoided if the European Commission's communication with stakeholders had started earlier and was better planned. We could have had a slightly bolder and slightly more decisive renewal of Europass. But now, at the end of this debate, I would like to thank for the patience, competence and dedication of all those who have worked for the successful renewal of Europass. It has been a pleasure to work not only with my colleague Thomas Mann as co-rapporteur, but also with all my fellow shadow rapporteurs, some of whom remained in this Chamber even at this late hour. Huge gratitude to the outstanding team of assistants, advisers, linguists who helped us, protected us from mistakes and managed to combine all the amendments, suggestions, concerns and hopes of those involved in the drafting of the changes in a whole. I would like to reassure all the Members who have taken the floor that we really wanted to achieve this tool: to make this instrument more suitable for the young, their capabilities and knowledge, to open it up to the more vulnerable and to the older, and to oblige as far as possible countries to do Europass more visible, even more popular, because indeed over 60 million CVs were made, over 120 million visits to the website, but still Europass is not popular enough, there are still people for whom it is not available. Most of all, I think that we have laid a very strong foundation for upgrade and modernisation, because the next redevelopment of Europass will not come in twelve years, but I think much sooner. We set a good foundation for the next revision. Otherwise, I am convinced that tomorrow our work will receive maximum support and a huge majority.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 15 March 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — This reform of Europass is certainly a technical improvement, since Europass candidates will now have access on a single platform to a full range of services, from online CV design to self-assessment tools or job offers. It is also commendable to dedicate the decisive role of national agencies in the operation of Europass and to provide a rigorous framework for the protection of personal data. However, it is regrettable that the Commission considers that in academic and vocational mobility it is a sesame to the real difficulties encountered in youth training and employment, since unemployment among the under-25 years of age stabilized in 2018 at a very high level of 18.4%. Professional mobility is a lure as the differences between Member States in training remain considerable, making it impossible in fact any strict equivalence of diplomas and competences. Furthermore, Europass is likely to increase immigration from Member States heavily affected by unemployment and where incomes are lower than the European average, leading to a brain drain that would exacerbate existing imbalances.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. — I welcome the regulation on the Europass review. Europass provides a standardised, more transparent framework for professional documents, such as CVs, to ensure that EU citizens' skills and competences are understandable in any EU country. Unified CVs are more transparent, making it easier for employers to compare candidates. The main objective of Europass is to ensure that EU citizens' qualifications and competences are transparent within and between Member States. Europass will ensure that learning learned in formal, non-formal and practical frameworks (e.g. mobility) is as accessible as possible. Europass has been used by over 100 million people since its launch in 2005, but it was necessary to adapt it because it was too complex and complicated to use. One of the main aims of these changes is to make Europass accessible to more people, especially people with disabilities. For the change we proposed the technical adaptation and digital accessibility of the online platform. In addition to the types of documents available to date (CV, language passport, mobility card, diploma annex, certificate supplement), additional elements are introduced. These are the new e-portfolio and the so-called Digital Skills Intelligence database. Over the past twelve years, more than 3.5 million Europass CVs and 26 thousand language passports have been produced in Hungary.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Although the EU provides a wide range of tools and services to support the exchange of information and a better understanding of skills to facilitate mobility and encourage the transparency of qualifications, these tools are yet to be exploited at their full potential. Evidence has shown that despite some success stories, such as the Europass CV, potential beneficiaries are generally unaware of the available services to facilitate mobility. Additionally, the development of these tools has not been in line with changes in the way people acquire skills, learn and communicate today. This affects the integration on the European labour market. I fully support the new proposal, which will modernise EU tools and services to ensure that the changing needs of all potential beneficiaries from the labour market are reflected. As the Europass will convert from a document-based facility into a service-based platform, its scope of activity will widen and will thus ensure that users’ needs will be the core of the framework services. I strongly believe that for an integrated and functional European labour market this is necessary, and from now on all potential users will constantly be updated to the technological developments and new forms of sharing information.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - This report on improved quality of service skills and qualifications concerns issues of relevance for the future. The aim is to ensure the transparency of the qualifications and competences of EU citizens within and between Member States, which includes online tools, information and the development of open standards to better ensure skills and qualifications, transparency and intelligibility. Europass should aim at improving understanding of learning, not only in the context of formal but also non-formal learning and informal learning, as well as learning from practical experience. Under the new Europass system provided for in this Regulation, existing Europass services are adapted to the needs and expectations of users and providers, i.e. learners, jobseekers, employers (in particular small and medium-sized enterprises), public employment services, vocational guidance professionals , providers of education and training services, social partners, volunteers, youth organisations, youth work providers, national Europass centres and responsible national authorities. All instruments and tools should be properly designed and harmonised in such a way that they do not coincide with their specific objectives and that Europass capabilities are not exceeded or interfere with other legal provisions.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Silvia Costa, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1295/2013 establishing the Creative Europe Programme (2014-2020) ( COM (2017) 0385 — C8-0236/2017 — 2017/0163 (COD)) (A8-0369/2017).

name: Silvia COSTA
text: rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today is a good day for young people, for music and for Europe. With this amendment to the Creative Europe Regulation and this three-year European co-financing we recognise the value, we give a future to the Youth Orchestra of the European Union, founded 40 years ago by Claudio Abbado and Lionel Bryer, set up by the European Parliament. I would like to thank my colleagues, the Council and the Commission again for their fruitful cooperation. This orchestra is one of a kind, because it consists of young musicians from all Member States of the Union, selected each year according to quality criteria. A real workshop of young talents that transcend cultural boundaries and collaborate to achieve excellence in the musical field. In fact, thanks to this extraordinary experience, which I would call European musical citizenship, a large part of the more than 3000 musicians who have been part of the orchestra to date are today, in Europe and in the world, conductors, soloists and teachers, but they also grew the musical culture of many young people. The orchestra was conducted by the greatest musicians, from Claudio Abbado to Barenboim, Bernstein to Rostropovič, performed in the most important music festivals of Europe and the world, earning the respect of the whole cultural community. I would say a true cultural ambassador of the European Union, who has enhanced the richness of our musical heritage, fostered intercultural dialogue and really created the premises for greater culture widespread music. At a time when Europe is facing so many challenges, it is nice that in the European year of cultural heritage we have found this agreement, because we must remember that music was the first language European common. But adequate funding is needed to allow all this. We have a very troubled time behind us for the orchestra since, in 2016, risked closing due to shortage of resources. For this reason I have fought, along with many of my colleagues, whom I thank, to first save the experience of the orchestra, and now to secure it until 2020, the year in which the new will be approved European programme dedicated to seven-year culture. On that occasion, I hope, Commissioner, that the European Ambassadors of Culture will be reinstated, including other excellent European institutions. Of course, we call on the EUYO to develop a greater capacity for the involvement of musicians from all Member States, who must make selections as properly advertised as possible, and also to diversify their revenue in order to ensure with sponsors and other contributions — and of course with their shows and tours — to ensure their sustainability and reduce reliance on Union funding. But as an European parliamentarian and as an Italian, let me also say that after Brexit the orchestra, which is based in London, also risked losing its legal status as a European body. For this reason, together with the Italian government, the Rai and the municipality of Ferrara, but also together with other collaborations, we have offered the opportunity to the Youth Orchestra of the European Union to move in Italy, also obtaining financial support from our country, but also to continue the experience of the Summer School in Austria, in Grafenegg, Bolzano, and to have an antenna also in Brussels, thanks to Belgian government, so in a really European logic. So the orchestra, I would say — and this I say this with a lot of pride, and we should all be proud of it, I think — is the first cultural institution since Brexit that was experienced by the world of culture in that country with great apprehension and with great concern — it is the first to be hosted in another Member State, in a logic of solidarity and for safeguarding the freedom of movement of many young people, sharing a European cultural and educational experience.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, the European Union Youth Orchestra was funded at the request of this House in 1976 and received the patronage of successive Presidents of the Commission, Parliament and heads of state and government. Since its creation, the European Union Youth Orchestra’s mission has been to unite Europe’s most talented young musicians under internationally renowned conductors in an ensemble that transcends cultural, social, economic, religious and political boundaries in the common pursuit of musical excellence. It demonstrates the vital role of culture and education in strengthening our European identity, a point which was strongly highlighted by EU heads of state and government at an informal summit in Gothenburg last year. In 2016, the European Union Youth Orchestra experienced very serious financial difficulties that threatened their existence. Since then, the Commission and the European Parliament, with the support of the Council, have worked together to find solutions allowing the orchestra to continue its activities on a sustainable basis. I am proud that we have found a solution to keep the European Union Youth Orchestra alive. You will vote on the amendment to the creative Europe programme that will ensure annual funding to the orchestra until the end of this financial programme in 2020. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Costa, and the shadow rapporteurs for their commitment and their excellent cooperation throughout discussions.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President! I would like to support the proposed amendments to the Creative Europe regulation, which also enables the provision of funding for the Union Youth Orchestra by the end of 2020. As has been said here, the orchestra is a unique initiative that has been enabling for many years to provide funding for the Union Youth Orchestra. young European artists together playing, touring and international performances at the highest level. So far, nearly 3,000 young musicians have come through its ranks, touring on four continents. The orchestra's long-standing contribution to developing musical talent and promoting European culture is unquestionable. Nevertheless, the exceptional treatment of this initiative by the Union institutions cannot come at the expense of new artistic endeavors, whose creators also solicit funds from the Creative Europe programme. For this reason, I believe that the negotiated text of the amendment, which calls on the Orchestra to diversify the sources of funding and stipulates that the appropriations are granted exceptionally by the end of 2020, is a good option and the document we have developed is a compromise that balances the interests of different parties. I therefore believe that he deserves the support of the European Parliament as much as possible.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: — Mr President, to thank my colleague Julie Ward, she will speak for our group. I have exchanged order with her because in five minutes I am online on Slovak television, so thank you very much, and now my speaking time. Creative Europe is a programme for all. For those who are actively involved and ask for support in the field of film industry, culture, translation of books and others, but it is also for those who are consumers of this culture. With today's legislative resolution, we will support the European Union Youth Orchestra, which consists of young musicians who have been selected in their Member States. The auditions for this orchestra are very demanding, it's not easy to get there, which testifies to the high quality of this orchestra. I am convinced that performances by young musicians at various festivals and tours both within the EU and internationally will be an enrichment for every listener with a cultural experience and will also enrich European cultural heritage. The Creative Europe programme is programmed and financially secured by 2020, and I firmly believe that it will also be in the new multiannual financial framework.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Madam, we're not stopping you anymore because I know you have to make it to Television.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (ES) Mr President, I would like to express my full agreement with the measures proposed to ensure Community support for the activities of the European Union Youth Orchestra. This orchestra spreads the Union's values using today's talent, that of our young performers, who spread a unique aspect of European cultural heritage. Our continent accumulates the world's largest catalogue of composers and classical musical works that tour and describe our history. Helping tell it by training young people to make the leap to the elite of music professionals and to do so by encouraging transversal and multicultural coexistence is a great idea. Now that the foundations are laid for growing this project, I want to encourage the deepening of the capacity of this orchestra to connect with European citizens. There are great musical works created by traditional European cultures and linked to their folk tradition: they should be more present in the programmes. Decentralising performances and using this asset to symbolize that the diversity that unites us in Europe is all diversity is another good idea, such as keeping antennas of this programme for these minorized cultures, whose cultural industries are able to succeed at the Goya Awards gala with films like Handia or send to the list of Oscar films like Loreak.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the cultural value of the Youth Orchestra of the European Union is undoubted and represents a concrete example of integration. The orchestra was founded under the patronage of the European Parliament in 1976, and is a unique opportunity for growth, human and professional, for the young musicians who take part in it, and is therefore a heritage of safeguard. The work we have done in trilogues has certainly improved the text: we have managed to get several concepts included, such as the fact that it is a provisional and exceptional measure that will end on December 31, 2020. Secondly, we have included the fact that the grant from the current financial allocation of Creative Europe will be borne by both the Culture sub-programme and the section transectoral. This has managed to prevent the Culture sub-programme from being penalised too much. And finally, we urged the orchestra to always achieve greater financial independence, increase its visibility in the media, perform in more concerts in the Member States and always ensure greater representativeness of the States in its composition. These are improvements, which together with my colleagues we have managed to get included, and which certainly make the text more balanced and circumscribed.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr President! Colleagues and Colleagues! Of course we support this orchestra. We support this initiative. In contrast, we also believe that some adjustments are needed in this mechanism of operation. First of all, the orchestra must take care of its own promotion, it is better to promote itself. He also needs to take care of alternative funding. He needs to take care of greater transparency. In short, it needs to do several steps so that post-2020 funding can continue. On the other hand, I'll point out my own experience — experience as culture minister. At that time, we built the I, CULTURE Orchestra, a young orchestra composed of Belarusians, Ukrainians, also Moldovans, Georgians, etc., so that they cooperate with each other, create new values, but mostly functioned under a very tight work regime. These requirements caused them to learn faster, get to know each other better, and the ventures they pursued were immediately better promoted. One note to Ms Silvia Costa: we have not agreed on the element involved in moving from London to another area of possible activity. This should be the subject of possible Commission work, but we are also counting on the Commissioner's proposal.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur Sylvia Costa, who is before me, for her long-term contribution and work on the Creative Europe programme. The preliminary agreement reached with the European Parliament on 25 January will secure the financing of the European Youth Orchestra until 2020, which is certainly good news and I fully stand by this decision. Since its establishment in 1976, the youth orchestra has repeatedly proved its European added value. It is the only one of its kind within the European Union, the composition of which is entirely selected by the countries of the Union. However, securing these funds by 2020 does not solve the problem of the need for long-term funding and the need to reduce dependence on the European Union in financial terms. In addition, additional efforts are needed to improve the geographical performance of musicians. My country, Bulgaria, for example, is among those groups of countries that are underrepresented geographically. We must also work to increase its popularity so that there is an equal and fair participation of musicians, soloists, conductors from across the European Union. The activities of the youth orchestra will have to be in tune with the priority of the Culture sub-programme for attracting new audiences among young people. Young people's reach of culture must be a priority at both European and national level. Unfortunately, culture is not among the priorities of the European Union, judging by the negligible budget allocated to it. In Bulgaria the situation is similar. A survey by the Bulgarian Association of Employers in the field of culture shows that 53% of young people do not attend cultural events because they have no money, 41% do not go simply because there is nowhere and 33% are not encouraged by their parents. The data is more than eloquent. However, the Borissov government ruled that young people in Bulgaria do not need a cultural check, it is more important to patch roads and build highways. You can draw your own conclusions.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: — Interessanti naqsam magkom il-fatt li proprju kif kien sar f'pajjiżi ora permezz tal-kampanja Save European Youth Orchestra, fil-belt Valletta f'Malta, li issa hi L-belt Capital Ewropea tal-kultura, sentejn beauty kienet saret protesta permezz tad-daqq tal-mużika maltin sabiex jitolbu lill-unjoni Ewropea tkompli tgilmoin b'mod finanzjarju Lill-orchestra Taż-żgtal-unjoni Ewropea.
