FL-aarnett la qed nitkellmu fuq il-programm Ewropa Kreattiva nagmel l-appell biex kif sar f'dan il-każ insibu dejjem aktar mezzi biex ngthe inu l-amajja kulturali ghalualiex il-the kulturali tmur lil hinn minn dik ekonomika u fl-opinjon tiegi tirrappreżenta l-vera ruu identità tagna bЂ‹ala Ewropej .

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Mr Costa and Commissioner Navracsics, because they ensure the continuity and valuable activity of the European Youth Orchestra. However, I think it is important, Mr President, that the Creative Europe programme is being discussed in the same week as the future of the European budget is shaping. I therefore note with great regret that, despite all the great words that are constantly being heard about European culture, its funding is only 0.15% of the total budget. It is therefore necessary, as others have said, to ensure that funding for the programme is substantially increased after 2020. I would like to conclude this brief speech by referring to the need to support music. Only 3% — yes, you have heard very well — of the programme goes to its support and, above all, of course, classical music. But music is a truly international language that unites peoples and cultures, and support for its diverse forms must be our priority. It is good that in February the Music Moves Europe initiative was launched, which I hope will be incorporated into the programme for stable funding.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I’m speaking on behalf of my political group, the S&D Group. I’m very glad that a temporary solution was found to sustain the work of the European Youth Orchestra, as it is the only organisation of its kind that brings together young people from all 28 EU Member States every year to work together culturally and artistically at the highest levels of excellence. The orchestra, established in London since 1976, recently moved its headquarters to Italy. Yet another illustration of the loss of cultural influence that Brexit is already bringing to the UK, with the Capital of Culture scheme sadly excluding UK cities. Since its formation, the orchestra has provided a route to employment for thousands of Europe’s young EU musicians and attracted a global reputation for its excellence. The amended regulation aims at ensuring the financial survival of the orchestra until 2020, given its unique institutional nature and its history. However, it is important for the sustainability of the organisation that it diversify its revenues and increase its visibility and ensure full transparency and greater geographical balance in its selection process. We must also ensure that we use this opportunity to debate the role of arts and culture in Europe’s development, and that we design stable and coherent funding schemes in the future Creative Europe programme. Ensuring better independence and transparency in decision-making also demands better involvement of the cultural sector in the assessment and implementation of creative Europe. And I hope, Commissioner, that you will revisit the list of concerns that I brought to you personally last year from Culture Action Europe.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, this year is the European Year of Cultural Heritage and I am very pleased that we can support young people's cultural activities. I will vote in favour of this regulation because I consider it necessary for the Youth Orchestra of the European Union to kick-start its transformation. I think we need to give him time to really turn into a sustainable project, independent of the funds that are allocated from the Creative Europe programme. Of course he can and should apply for public support after 2020, but he should be more independent, his funding should be transparent. We know well, colleagues and colleagues, that we have dozens of quality orchestras, young people's orchestras in Europe, and I really don't know why there should be one single one that is exclusively funded from the European means it has so guaranteed. Let them compete and fight for their quality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Mr President, the report by Mrs Costa for Creative Europe 2014-2020, I think it addresses the issues that this House should address, because it is, first of all, an important initiative, which concerns culture. Particular mention must of course be made of the Youth Orchestra of the European Union, which has so far shown a particularly interesting activity. However, the Orchestra must also open itself to other perceptions and problems and thoughts of cultural heritage and music, and at the same time it must also be representative of all states. Of course, new initiatives are needed to support culture, which requires an increase in the European Union's budget. Young artists must be supported, music, theatre, books and films must be supported. It is in this way that the European Union can move forward towards culture.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first let me thank you for all your very constructive and supportive contributions in this debate. I think this atmosphere is what we need in future negotiations about the next multiannual financial framework when we talk about the role and the place of culture in the next MFF. So I need your help to lobby for a more established position for culture for the next MFF. As for the European Youth Orchestra, which was established in in 1976 as one of the first building blocks of the future European identity. We’ve had some difficulties recently, but this report and this solution can fund a very solid and smooth financial background for the operations of the European Youth Orchestra, currently in the UK and in the future in Italy, because the European Youth Orchestra will move its administrative and operational headquarters from the UK to Italy in the second half of this year. So thank you for your support and thank you in advance for your future help in lobbying for culture and for a more solid place for culture in the next MFF.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the ten Members who have spoken, and this shows that there is still interest in culture in this Parliament, which is apparently a I would like to thank the Commissioner very much for his speech. I think they have been touched... although some are gone, I would like to respond very briefly: subject of resources. I would like to say that we have strongly shared an approach which is not only European co-financing the only resource of the European Orchestra, it is a part of their revenue, because there are also some countries , differently, cooperating, there are sponsors, there is hospitality. But certainly having three years with a certain co-financing also allows you to plan and have other good opportunities. As far as visibility is concerned, it is very right: we have asked, we have made a commitment with the European Broadcasting Union to give more visibility to an orchestra that is precisely European and which needs to be more known and have performances there too. With regard to the very right balance required by various colleagues, between countries, this depends on two things: involvement and greater, let us say, not just transparency, but the ability to involvement of individual Member States making preselection, and then of course a focus and also a geographical balance in the final selection. I would also like to say that the orchestra also carried out this year — I say this to my colleague Bilbao when she said about visibility in the various countries — I would like to reassure you: this year, just for the European year, they will be thirteen European countries where there will be tours, as well as countries also outside Europe. Of course, there is an underlying problem — we have said that in conclusion too — which is that of resources. We know that creative Europe, as Mr Grammatikakis rightly said before, is only 0.15% of the budget overall. We are calling for an absolute doubling of this figure at least, even if we know that there are difficulties, but it is a matter of finding priorities: culture is what makes Europe Europe, and that is what can also reconstructing a response to the crisis, which is also an identity crisis, is a crisis of intercultural dialogue, but also of meanings. I am only closing by saying that from this point of view, I would like to remind you that Parliament, some of us Members have already proposed a pilot project on music since last year, but we also want that in all the other European policies the cultural dimension is more present.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 15 March 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. — The European Union Youth Orchestra (EUYO) established in 1976 consists of young musicians from all member countries and has represented the European Union for 40 years. Since its inception, the orchestra has played a significant role in promoting European values, cross-cultural dialogue, mutual respect and understanding through culture. EU funding is crucial to the orchestra's survival. Without such support, EUYO could not operate and young musicians would be deprived of the unique opportunity to perform on international stages, continue to build careers and develop talent under the guidance of established conductors. In the past, programmes such as Creative Europe have financially supported EUYO in various ways. For example, for 2016 and 2017, the orchestra received a grant to operate as an organisation that seeks to achieve the objective of general interest of the EU or to carry out tasks belonging to EU cultural policy. I am pleased that, in view of the exceptional nature of this orchestra and its role in building common European values, the Commission proposes to consider it “the body identified in the basic act” and thereby provide stable funding for the next years of operation.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the common debate on: — Recommendation made by João Ferreira on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries on a draft Council decision denouncing the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Union of the Comoros (14423/2017 — C8-0447/ 2017 — 2017/0241 (NLE)) (A8-0058/2018) and — report by João Ferreira on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries containing a draft non-legislative resolution on the draft Council Decision on the termination of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and Union of the Comoros (14423/2017 — C8-0447/2017 — 2017/0241 (NLE) — 2017/2266 (INI)) (A8-0055/2018).

name: João FERREIRA
text: rapporteur. — (PT) Mr President, Commissioner, today we are facing an unprecedented debate. Certainly this is the fact that has aroused so much attention and so many attendance by Members. This Parliament is called upon to discuss and decide on a proposal to denounce an existing fisheries agreement with a third country. Bilateral fisheries relations between the European Union and the Comoros date back to 1988, that is to say, for three decades the European Union has had some kind of fisheries agreement with the Comoros, which gives it access to fishing resources in that country. The Comoros are part of the lot of the least developed countries. The fisheries sector, the second most important in the country, right after agriculture, represents a significant weight in both the country's GDP and employment. All domestic operations are handmade and small-scale and involved, not so long ago, about eight thousand fishermen. The stocks likely to be exploited in the Comoros exclusive economic zone are mostly large pelagic fish, tuna and swordfish. Annual catches by local fishermen account for less than half of the estimated stocks. The remaining quantities of fish are exploited by foreign industrial fleets, which land them elsewhere, and fish processing is also carried out outside the Comoros, including catches, in some cases catches from the local fleet. This is a framework that we must bear in mind when examining the European Commission's proposal to denounce the fisheries agreement between the European Union and the Comoros. This denunciation becomes inevitable in the light of the involvement of the Comoros in operations that violate the regulation on illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, IUU fishing, in particular by allowing the flag to exchange vessels involved in this type of fishing activity. However, we feel that we should draw the attention of the European Commission, through the resolution we are discussing here today, to a few questions. The fight against IUU fishing should not, in our view, focus solely on the identification of non-cooperating third countries. An effective fight against all forms of IUU fishing involves finding ways of helping countries, particularly small island developing states, such as the Comoros, to improve their marine management policies. To that extent, it is regrettable that, over almost 30 years in which the European Union has maintained fisheries agreements with the Comoros, it has not been possible to achieve more tangible results in the development of the Comorian fisheries sector, particularly in terms of control and surveillance capacity, scientific development and technical training for fishermen and observers, among other areas. It is also with deep concern that we note that assessments carried out by UN bodies criticise what they call the position of power of the European Union in the establishment of fisheries agreements and in setting fish prices, while also saying that the partnership agreements have failed in the support for the development of local industry, moreover an evidence. This justifies that, in the context of this resolution, proposals should be made to contribute to the continued support for the development of the fishing conditions sector in the Comoros, to the improvement of fisheries related activities, to the improvement of the quality of life of fishermen and, as well as, to combat IUU fishing. These, among other things, are some of the concerns that are contained in the resolution we are discussing today and we will vote on tomorrow.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, the Comoros was included in the list of non-cooperating countries in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing on 11 July 2017, because it failed to comply with undertakings to combat IUU fishing. The decision to include the Comoros on the list of non-cooperating countries was taken after a thorough analysis of the Comoros’ stance on the fight against IUU fishing, and following its pre-identification in October 2015 and years of discussions with the Comoros. The areas of concern haven’t been addressed by the Comoros and the Comoros haven’t fully implemented the measures agreed. The main shortcomings leading to this listing were related to, firstly, the flag-of-convenience policy pursued by the Comorian authorities and lack of control over its foreign-based fleet register; secondly, evidence of illegal long-distance fishing activities by the Comorian fleet; thirdly, the poor or non-existent monitoring and control capacities of the national authorities, and finally, the outdated Comorian legal fisheries framework also played a part in the decision. According to our rules against IUU fishing, the Commission must propose the denunciation of any bilateral fisheries agreement with such a country. Therefore, the Commission proposed a denunciation of the partnership agreement in the fisheries sector between the European Community and the Comoros. We share the issues raised by Parliament in the draft motion for resolution and welcome your support. The Commission remains fully open to working closely with the Comorian authorities to guide them towards a better fisheries management framework, if they express the wish to do so. We are fully conscious of the difficult social situation in the Comoros. Taking effective measures against illegal fishing is essential to protecting the valuable national resources that can be a significant source of economic and social development in the Comoros.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union is one of the main players in ocean governance and the fight against illegal fishing is one of its cornerstones. Thanks to its external action, it exports its sustainability standards and serves as an incentive to third countries to improve their fisheries management, a situation that is beneficial both for the Union and its consumers and for the sustainability of ecosystems and fisheries resources. Despite warnings about the Comoros's non-compliance in the fight against illegal fishing, as a yellow card had already been issued in 2015, they have not taken any corrective measures in breach of their obligations. I therefore consider the 2017 decision declaring them as a non-cooperating country correct, and I support the decision to terminate the fisheries agreement. I am aware that this decision will harm a number of Member States, including mine, but we need to send a clear and strong message, expressing strong commitment to the fight against illegal fishing, as well as the rejection of any business that comes from it. However, this decision should not mean the end of cooperation relations with the Comoros and it is important that this procedure be stopped in the event that its deficiencies are corrected, by removing the red card and allowing the Union fleet to return to the fishing ground.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Mr President, I formally and naturally approve the denunciation of the agreement with the Union of the Comoros. It is the appropriate decision in the context of dossiers that I have been given to examine. But having said this, I would remind you that this small Indian island state is considered one of the least developed countries in the world and that its economy is very dependent on financial and technical assistance from other countries. Combating IUU fishing is quite rightly a priority for the European Union. Last year's FAO report shows that illegal fishing is growing in East Africa, resulting in losses of EUR 325 million in unloading and around 800 million in processed products. At the meeting of ACP Fisheries Ministers in the Bahamas in September last year, the enormous economic and environmental losses due to unregulated and unreported illegal fishing were recognised. But denunciation of agreements, although inevitable, is not the solution to end these practices. Following the implementation of the card system, the denunciation of the agreements and the inclusion of countries on the IUU countries list, the European Commission should make closer cooperation efforts in full reforms. Furthermore, the Comoros are home to a large population of celacantes, a relic of biodiversity and world value, a living fossil threatened by illegal fishing in the Indian region. Strengthening the need for the Commission to intensively promote aid for the development of management, fisheries governance and marine biodiversity in the Comoros. A history of almost 30 years of agreements between the European Union and the Comoros, with no visible improvements in activity, shows that something has failed and failed on our part. The fact that the agreement is now denounced must therefore be an incentive to improve, as far as possible, the monitoring of development cooperation in this archipelago, which has been said to be discovered by the Portuguese in 1505, and then colonized and administered by France for several centuries.

name: Czesław HOC
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! I would like to express my concern about the impact of the termination of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Union of the Comoros, which will greatly affect the currently difficult social situation in this country. I draw attention to the fact that cooperation in fisheries between the European Union and the Comoros has been ongoing for almost 30 years, and the financial counterpart — in particular the sectoral support allocated by the European Union — has not sufficiently guaranteed the development of the fisheries sector in the Comoros. It is therefore advisable for the European Union to contribute responsible sustainable fisheries in Comoros waters, to active scientific and technical cooperation and, above all, to active, concrete assistance in combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing (IU), and also in combating the increased activity of Somali pirates. Please note that in these types of partnership agreements, benefits are mutual and added value is the development of infrastructure and fish industries in third countries. In such cases, it is necessary to act very prudently and perspectively and not allow the economy of third countries to be degraded.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to ask you for your support for a decision that we have taken for the first time in the history of fisheries agreements between the European Union and third countries: it is a question of denouncing the agreement we have with the Comoros Islands, which grants 70 fishing licences to vessels in Spain, France and Portugal in the waters of these islands. The Agreement is part of the network of agreements of this nature which allow our fleet to fish for tuna in Indian waters. This measure responds to the Union's strong will to maintain its global leadership in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, and leadership is consistently acquired between what we say and what we do, and it is based on our credibility. The Comoros Islands are engaged in a “red card” procedure which could identify them as a non-partner country in the fight against illegal fishing. This is due to the fact that vessels with this flag have been found to engage in illegal fishing practices. Its authorities put very little energy and means to monitor and control fishing activity; they also do not update their obsolete fisheries legal system, which is in contravention of international law obligations. For these reasons, we propose this decision for the first time. Until now, the European Union has never terminated a fisheries agreement and, although the economic and social impact of this measure will not be great, we are obviously facing a failure, but a necessary failure, because to continue this is incompatible with the Union's values. The European Union advocates sustainable fishing based on clear rules, but it must also show its firm commitment to the fight against illegal fishing globally. Today we are turning this commitment into action and we do so with two objectives: the first, to contribute to stimulating other behaviour in the sector and fishing activities in the Comoros, but we also send a message to other countries that may fall into the same temptations: if they want to continue working with the world's first fishing power, they must assume their responsibilities, reform their fishing industry and take all legal and material measures to eradicate this type of fishing illegal.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) Mr President, what we are being asked is to blacklist a poor, very poor country, which Europe criticises for failing to pay enough attention to the interests of the European fleets which, in the clean waters of that country, arrogate themselves the right, against a few euros, to plunder resources. I denounce these fisheries agreements. I also denounce logics that then lead to denouncing them. I denounce this zeal, always a little easy, with which the European Union likes to assert itself strong with the weak and weak with the strong, because, meanwhile, in the waters of French Guiana, Brazilian fleets continue to fish illegally. I will pay particular attention to the fact that the fleets, after these agreements, which will be denounced, do not retreat to the waters of Mayotte and Reunion Island, considering that they have a natural right to fish. The plundering of Indian Ocean resources must cease.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, Mr Ferreira's report clearly sets out the problem of illegal fishing and the practice of the flag of convenience, which now call into question the fisheries agreement we had with the Comoros. Nevertheless, we must continue a constructive dialogue with that country so that it can begin to fight seriously against illegal fishing. But beyond the Comoros, large countries such as Vietnam, China, Russia, Brazil and Thailand are also regularly involved in illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, and, for some, in slavery of seafarers, without being worried about it. For example, Vietnam has received only a yellow card, while the blue boats, mainly from that country, have long plundered the waters of the Indian Ocean and the Pacific. Pacific small island States are suffering from a deteriorating situation and witnessing the looting of their exclusive economic zones. This is also the case for our European and, more precisely, French outermost regions. In New Caledonia, for example, Vietnamese blue ships are regularly boarded by the French national navy. In Guyana, illegal fishing vessels are sometimes armed, and everywhere there is an increase in the number of mother vessels stationed at the border of maritime borders and supplied by smaller vessels. On this issue, the Commission can only be credible if it penalizes all countries that practice or tolerate illegal fishing and if it completely frees itself from the policy of the fort with the weak and the weak with the strong.

name: Werner KUHN
text: Mr President, Commissioner. This is actually a sad evening when today we have to talk about the denunciation of the fisheries agreement with the Comoros as the last item on the agenda. This archipelago has an economy that has only USD 1 000 per capita income in gross national product. It is located in a very fish-quiet area between Madagascar and Mozambique, and we have had partnerships since 1988, as colleagues have already pointed out. That is 30 years, including development aid, so to speak. But this economy has not evolved at all. This is certainly also due to the state system prevailing in the Comoros, and this is autocratic. The EUR 1.8 million that we added to the Comoros budget each year under this fisheries agreement so that we could obtain the 70 licences went somewhere, but certainly not in the construction of our own small artisanal fishing fleet. And that's where the problem lies. In the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas — including the Indian Ocean — the Japanese, Chinese and South Koreans are gathered there every year and set the quotas, including for Bigeye tuna, for Bluefin tuna, for Bluefin tuna, in the Indian Ocean, for swordfish et cetera pp. illegal fishing can also be fought together, as ships are placed on the chain. These are not Comorian fishing vessels fishing illegally there, so to speak, which may be Chinese, Russians or others. We need to intervene together so that this can no longer happen.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: Mr President, as other Members have said, this is the first time that the European Union has terminated a cooperation agreement on fisheries for reasons of illegal fishing. It's an important reason, what happens is that the situation in the country is a drama. I deeply regret that the Comorian authorities have not put in place corrective measures to resolve the problems identified, and that in these 30 years, in agreement with the European Union, they have not been able to implement a monitoring and surveillance system for the control of illegal fishing. The Union of the Comoros is a group of three islands in south-east Africa, in the Indian Ocean, which stands out as one of the poorest countries in the world. I would also like to stress the importance of effective measures to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, which is one of the basic pillars of our fisheries policy. The Union should ensure that these fishing activities, both inside and outside, are based on the same principles and regulatory rules for the conservation and management of marine resources. I stress what the European Parliament emphasizes in its report: that the conclusion of the fisheries agreement must never mean the end of cooperation with the Comoros. We call on the European Commission to continue its dialogue with them, to ensure that cooperation with the fisheries sector can be revived as soon as possible and thus contribute to ending the poverty in which citizens live there.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, the European Union develops different types of fisheries relationships with third countries. Multilateral actions, as well as bilateral agreements, are at the core of such relationships. The common denominator for all of them is responsible and sustainable fishing. Unfortunately, this is no longer the case with the Union of Comoros. Their involvement in operations breaching the IUU Regulation means that we have to act. We cannot conduct business as usual with countries that do not follow the law or share the same values as we do. The European Union is committed to combatting illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing. We have to do everything in our power to fight against the depletion of fish stocks and the detriment of maritime habitats. Such a situation distorts competition and puts honest fishing operators at an unfair disadvantage, as well as weakening coastal communities, especially in developing countries. That being said, I fully support the proposal of the Commission. I think it’s time we put our foot down and strongly say no to IUU fishing in places like Comoros.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Comoros base their survival on a subsistence economy that is heavily dependent on foreign countries. However, an exception is the fisheries sector, which is strategically prioritised, but which has setbacks due to shortcomings that inhibit the intelligent exploitation of opportunities offered from the waters of the archipelago. The denunciation of the agreement is heavily damaging the already fragile economy of the Comoros, but we have to question what happened, because if exploitable fish reserves are estimated at 33 000 tonnes per year and the volume of the local catch stands today at less than half, it is because the remaining part continues to be exploited by foreign fleets that are enriched on the shoulders of the small community. What didn't work? If all this has happened, we must ask ourselves this: how much the European Union has actually done for the protection of local fishermen and against illegal fishing, and now commit ourselves to actions that can fight against these practices and contribute to the development and improvement of fishing conditions in the small archipelago.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the Comoros are a cluster of three volcanic islands between Madagascar and Africa. These are poor islands with 850,000 inhabitants, low GDP and, of course, rich stocks of fisheries, especially for tuna and swordfish, and it is a fact that illegal and unreported fishing and flag change are also being carried out and therefore the agreement with the European Union is not being respected. Union. But we have to ask ourselves: Firstly, what was the added value of this agreement between the European Union and the Comoros? has this agreement been able to help poor local populations? — does the European Union have a power in this cooperation, as the United States has said — and, finally, what about Koreans, Japanese, Chinese, who fish illegally in this area? In the end, it must be put in order, but the European Union must also put order in the face of those who are strong and who violate the rules and fish in this area. And I'm talking about Chinese, Japanese and Korean. Something has to be done with them, too.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the denunciation of this fisheries partnership agreement is, sadly, a first for the EU under the implementation of the regulation combating illegal, unreported and undocumented fishing (IUU) and measures forcing therein. This is a legal obligation, and it shows that the Commission is looking globally at its external policy. The EU cannot continue with fisheries agreements when third-country partners do not take effective action to combat IUU fishing. The decision is fully consistent with the EU’s ocean governance agenda under which the Union cooperates with third countries with the purpose of improving compliance with international measures, including on combating IUU fishing.

name: João FERREIRA
text: rapporteur. — (PT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank everyone for their speeches and to underline a final message to the European Commission, which I believe is clear from the various speeches. This complaint should not mean the end of a cooperation relationship with the Comoros in the fisheries field, which is why we urge the European Commission to work to restore this relationship as soon as possible, considering fishing communities and small-scale artisanal fisheries as a factor central development of this cooperation, promoting investments and technical assistance in areas as different as the fisheries administration and governance system, monitoring, coast protection, surveillance and surveillance capabilities, the activation of structures to support the refrigeration sector, of the distribution and processing of fish, the construction of landing and safety infrastructures, the renovation of the Comorian small-scale fleet, strengthening safety conditions and the ability to stay at sea, in short, among many other aspects. The sustainable fisheries agreements concluded by the European Union with other countries, in our view, should bring mutual benefits. Strengthening the sovereignty of these countries over their resources, the development of economic activities associated with fisheries, the protection of marine resources and the promotion of the development of fishing communities should be central objectives of this cooperation relationship, and not, as has also been pointed out here, depletion of resources. If we go in this direction, it will be an effective way of combating IUU fishing as well.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 15 March 2018.
